		What to do with someone's belongings after they die
		https://untanglegrief.com/belongings-after-a-death/
		Fri, 30 Jul 2021 14:44:32 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=1
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It’s normal to feel a lack of motivation after losing a loved one, and sorting through their belongings can seem like a daunting task while you’re grieving. Perhaps you’re unsure what to do with everything or how quickly you need to get it done. We’ve put together some suggestions to help you decide what to do with the rest of someone’s belongings after they die.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Remember that your loved one may have left some of their belongings to named people in their will, and you are legally obliged to carry out their wishes. You might also need to consider other family members when deciding what to do with the belongings not mentioned in the will.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Packing up the house</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Packing up the house after losing a loved one can be both physically and emotionally demanding. Most people have accrued many items throughout their lifetime, and sorting through them can be quite a big job. You might want to emotionally prepare to discover sentimental items and relive memories of time spent with the person who has died. It can help to ask other family members to accompany you for support, or you might prefer to look through meaningful possessions alone before asking for help with furniture and general belongings.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There is no time limit on when you have to pack up the house, so if it feels too much, delay it until you feel ready. Just remember to check whether there are any financial implications of waiting, such as ongoing mortgage repayments.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Once you have gone through your loved one’s belongings, you can decide what to do with the items. Here are some of our suggestions:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Sharing possessions with family</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You are likely to come across many items that have sentimental value rather than monetary value, and you can discuss who will keep which items with your family members. This process can be a lovely way to hear about each other’s memories with the person who has died, and you’ll often find that items have a different meaning for each person.<br /><br />If you need help deciding how to share out items, everyone in the family can have a pack of stickers and can stick them onto the items they’d like to keep as they go round the house. You can then discuss any overlaps and come to a decision.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When sharing out items with monetary value, some families allocate an equal ‘allowance’ to each person and place a price or value on each item, which they then ‘bid’ on. This works best when family members get on well and can keep it lighthearted.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Donating items to charity</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>After sorting through your loved one’s belongings, you’ll probably have plenty of things you could donate to charity. Choosing a charity that meant something to your loved one can be a nice way to <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/remembering-a-loved-one/">honour their memory</a>. Or, you might want to support organisations that helped care for your family member in some way, such as a local hospice or Age UK.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Before taking your donations to the charity shop, find out which items they will or won’t accept. For safety reasons, many charity shops won’t accept electrical goods and will only accept furniture with fire safety labels still attached (If you do have electrical goods, Cancer Research UK is one of the few charities that will take them, but they don’t accept white goods).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Charities say that they appreciate clothing, accessories, homeware, linen and books, as they sell particularly well. Some charities will come to collect larger items, such as wardrobes and beds.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Another option is to sell items, then donate the money you raise to the charity as a cash donation (they can also claim gift aid if you’re a taxpayer).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Selling items</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You may have items that are in a good, saleable condition that you decide to sell; this could be anything from large furniture, like wardrobes and dressers, to smaller items like clothing or crockery. eBay and local social media selling sites can be good places to list items for sale. For smaller, less valuable items, you might decide to hold a car boot sale.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Once you have sorted through their possessions, you need to decide what to do with their house. You need to check whether they owned the house outright or if there is an outstanding mortgage to pay to the bank. After this, you might decide to keep their house, to either live in, rent out or sell. We’d recommend taking advice from a solicitor. before making a decision, particularly if family members disagree on the best option.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		Returning to work after a bereavement
		https://untanglegrief.com/returning-to-work-after-a-bereavement/
		Tue, 03 Aug 2021 08:33:31 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=80
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Returning to work after a bereavement can be really tough. Here are some tips around taking time off after a loss, and ideas to help you settle back into working life.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Your first day back at work</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When you feel ready to return to work, talk to your employer about how they can make it as easy as possible for you. Going in for a coffee or lunch with your manager and/or colleagues before your first day back can help to get the potentially uncomfortable conversations out of the way. Discuss how others can support you, and how you would like difficult moments at work to be managed. For example, would you prefer to be left alone if you get upset, or would you want company? Ask your manager or HR representative for regular catch ups and check-ins to help you settle back in.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>When should I go back to work?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are no set rules for when you should go <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/bereavement-leave/">back to work after a bereavement</a>; it will depend on a lot of personal factors, as well as the rules that your employer sets out for bereavement leave. Work may offer a welcome distraction from your grief, but it can also seem very overwhelming. Make sure that you have an honest conversation with your employer about how you’re feeling, and how they can best support you with your return to work.  <br />If you are struggling to cope with bereavement at any point, see your GP. Feeling depressed and anxious after a loss could count as illness, which entitles you to statutory or occupational sick pay.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Set your own boundaries</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When it’s time to go back to work after a bereavement, think through what you need your colleagues and employer to do to support you:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Do you feel fit to work full time or would you prefer a phased return (i.e. working half days to start with)?</li>
<li>How do you want others to treat you – would you like your colleagues to express their condolences and ask how you are? Or would you prefer them not to mention your loss, or not to know about it at all? It is completely up to you how much you choose to share with others.</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Keep up a routine</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sticking to a regular daily routine, including exercise and regular meals before, during and after work, can really benefit your mental health and give your days some structure while you’re coping with bereavement. Grief can have a huge impact on your ability to concentrate, so having a to-do list that breaks down different tasks at work (and at home) can give you a sense of focus and help you feel more in control as you ease yourself slowly back to work. Asking a close colleague to check any important work could also be helpful - remember it is totally normal at the start for the quality of your work and the amount you can get done in a day to have decreased since your loss.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Looking after yourself</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Going back to work after a bereavement can feel overwhelming, so thinking through potential coping strategies can help in case it all suddenly feels too much.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>If you get upset, is there a room you can retreat to, or a kind colleague you can talk to?</li>
<li>What can you do to avoid getting stressed? For example, block off time in your diary every day to take a break, go for a walk, have lunch, stretch, switch off for a bit</li>
<li>Think up some standard responses to questions such as: ‘How are you doing?’. That way you won’t be caught off guard and can move the conversation on swiftly if you don’t want to talk about it</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>With all this in mind, you can feel prepared and ready for your first day back at work after bereavement.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		Bereavement Leave
		https://untanglegrief.com/bereavement-leave/
		Tue, 03 Aug 2021 08:34:14 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=81
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>After experiencing the loss of a loved one, knowing what to expect from your employer can help relieve some of the pressure around returning to work. In this article, we’ve outlined what to expect from your employer, bereavement leave law, and how your workplace can support you after a loss.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Am I entitled to workplace support?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In the UK, employers are not legally obliged to offer paid bereavement leave, but many do. Most are very understanding in the event of bereavement and will do their best to support you in any way they can. Your workplace may have a Bereavement Policy that outlines your entitlement to bereavement leave, pay and ongoing support.<br />There is no set number of days that an employer must offer for bereavement leave, but they are obliged to allow a ‘reasonable’ number of days as unpaid leave.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Typically, employers in the UK allow 3-5 days bereavement leave for the loss of a close family member, like a spouse, parent, or sibling; less for other relatives, such as grandparents, aunts, and uncles.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you have experienced a stillbirth or the loss of a child, you are legally entitled to two weeks’ Parental Bereavement Leave with Statutory Parental Bereavement Pay. Your employer may choose to provide additional child bereavement support and top up this payment to replace your full wage during this two week period. You can read more at <a href="https://www.gov.uk/time-off-for-dependants" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">gov.uk</a>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>People need different amounts of time to process their loss enough to return to work. If you feel that you need longer than allocated, you can discuss extending your bereavement leave with your HR department or manager, or using holiday leave to give yourself some extra time. If this isn’t an option, your GP may be able to support you in taking time off as sick leave until you <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/returning-to-work-after-a-bereavement/">feel able to return.</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>How can my workplace support me after a loss?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When you inform your workplace of your bereavement, a good manager will offer their condolences and reassure you that taking the time to grieve takes priority over work. You can use this initial conversation to ask if they have a Bereavement Policy for you to read through to get a clear idea of how you can expect to be supported.<br />Depending on the nature of your work, your manager might ask if there is anything they need to do in your absence. They may also offer to tell your colleagues about your loss, so you don’t have to explain it again when you return. Your employer shouldn’t make you feel guilty about taking time off or try to rush you back to work before you’re ready.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When you do return to work after bereavement leave, you may find that you struggle to concentrate or are not able to manage your full duties straight away. Your manager should support you as you settle back into the workplace, including discussing whether a phased return is an option if you feel it may help.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Your workplace might also offer a counselling service that offers bereavement counselling.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image -->
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://d1muf25xaso8hp.cloudfront.net/https%3A%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Fappforest_uf%2Ff1615908039446x493088574549351200%2FGroup?w=1024&amp;h=76&amp;auto=compress&amp;fit=crop&amp;dpr=1.5" alt="" /></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Advice from our community</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We asked some of our current members of our community to share their stories about how they dealt with returning to work while coping with grief after a bereavement.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Tsungai - "My advice would be - speak. Say what you need and ask for a day off when you need to and if that’s not possible take a break and do whatever you need to do to be okay."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Shannon - "If you’re like me and work doesn’t provide a distraction, my advice would be to communicate your needs as best you can from the start. You might need a gradual return to ease yourself back in. My workplace was very sympathetic and accommodating with helping me until I gained some focus back."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Melanie - "I was very fortunate, my employer encouraged me to take as long as I needed before returning to work. Work is my sanctuary and I find it a really good way to cope. I was lucky to manage a new team of people who don’t know what has happened to me. As long as I keep busy I can generally keep the grief at bay."</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		Registering a death
		https://untanglegrief.com/registering-a-death/
		Tue, 03 Aug 2021 08:34:59 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=82
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This article outlines what to expect when registering a death in England and Wales</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When a person dies, a doctor will verify their death and issue a certificate stating the cause of death. Once you receive the death certificate, you must officially register the death with a registrar within 5 days, including weekends and bank holidays. If the death is referred to a coroner, you have to wait for their permission before registering the death, even if this takes longer than five days. If the person died abroad, the death must be registered in the country in which it happened and in the UK.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>How to register a death</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A registrar office is a government building where officials register births, marriages and deaths. In England and Wales, you can register a death at any registrar office, but it is usually more straight forward if you use the one closest to where the person died. You should receive the contact details of the nearest registrar office when you receive the death certificate from a GP or hospital doctor.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It’s best to contact the registrar office as soon as possible, as you will usually need to book an appointment to attend. You can book by telephone or complete an online form which you access through your local authority website. Appointments typically last for around 30 minutes.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Who can register a death?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A death should be registered by a relative, anyone present at the death, an owner or occupier of the building in which the death happened (hospital staff, for instance), or someone arranging the funeral who knew the person who died.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>How much does it cost to register a death?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You do not have to pay to register a death, but you will need to pay for any additional copies of the death certificate required to settle the person’s affairs.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Important information</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When you register a death, the registrar will give you two documents. The first is a Certificate for Burial or Cremation (known as the ‘green form’), which gives permission for burial, or for you to apply for a cremation. You give this form to your appointed funeral director so that they can legally plan the funeral. The second is the Certificate of Registration of Death (form BD8), which you may need to fill in and return if the person was getting a State Pension or benefits (the form will come with a pre-paid return envelope). Your registrar should also give you a unique number to use for the Tell Us Once service that informs all government departments of the death. If you wish to hold a burial within 24 hours for cultural or religious reasons, contact your registrar for advice.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We recommend getting 8-10 copies of the death certificate, as you will need to provide evidence of the death to various companies and organisations, <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/notifying-banks-death-notification-service/">including banks</a> and <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/notifying-insurance-companies-of-a-death/">insurance companies</a>. You also need a death certificate to appoint a <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/applying-for-grant-of-probate/">Grant of Probate</a> to execute the will.</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p>Last updated: 16/06/22</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		How to write a eulogy
		https://untanglegrief.com/how-to-write-a-eulogy/
		Tue, 03 Aug 2021 08:35:48 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=83
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>One of the most challenging parts of <a href="/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/">funeral planning</a> is writing a fitting tribute to your loved one.</strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How can you find the words to capture just how much your friend or family member means to you? It’s harder still because you’re grieving, so emotions are running high, concentration is low, and the pressure may be overwhelming. <strong>That’s why we’ve created this guide on how to write a eulogy, complete with examples to get you started.&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Jump to section:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><a href="#tips">How to write a eulogy - 6 tips</a></li><li><a href="#structure">An example structure</a></li><li><a href="#parent">Eulogy for a parent</a></li><li><a href="#sibling"></a><a href="#sibling">Eulogy for a sibling</a></li><li><a href="#grandparent"></a><a href="#grandparent">Eulogy for a grandparent</a></li><li><a href="#grief"></a><a href="#friend">Eulogy for a friend</a></li><li><a href="#examples">More eulogy examples</a></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","fontSize":"large"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-left has-large-font-size"><strong>What is a eulogy?</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>A eulogy is a short speech given at a funeral or <a href="/how-to-memorial-ceremony/">memorial service</a> for a person who has died. </strong>The tradition originates from ancient Greece, and the word literally means “praise”. The key is to write the eulogy in a way that does their life justice and respects their loved ones’ memories and feelings of grief.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","fontSize":"large"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-left has-large-font-size"><strong>Who should deliver a eulogy?</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Speaking about someone who has died in front of their family and friends is a courageous thing to do. If you feel daunted by the prospect, ask people around you for support. <strong>While a close relative or friend usually writes the funeral speech, it can also be delivered by an official, such as a religious leader.</strong> Do what feels right and keep it flexible. For example, if you want to write the eulogy but worry about <a href="/preparing-yourself-for-the-funeral/">breaking down in tears</a>, ask someone else to be on standby to read it for you if need be.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","fontSize":"large"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-left has-large-font-size" id="tips"><strong>How to write a eulogy - 6 tips</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>1. Make it personal</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Introducing yourself in relation to the person you are remembering can be a good place to start.</strong> Describe what they meant to you, and what qualities defined them in your eyes. This will establish a connection with other people at the service and put you in the picture for those who might not know you very well.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>2. Cover the essentials</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When thinking about how to write a eulogy, it’s a good idea to structure it with a beginning, a middle and an end. And while it is not the same as an obituary, <strong>it usually includes brief aspects of the late person’s life, such as their early beginnings, their education and career, and particular skills, achievements or interests.</strong> Saying something specific about their family life, and mentioning their partner and/or children by name, can feel particularly important to their closest relatives.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>3. Get personal stories from others</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Just like our relationships with a particular person differ, so do our <a href="/stages-of-grief/">feelings about them when they die</a>. To make sure you write a good eulogy that will feel meaningful to others, <strong>ask a few close friends or relatives to contribute by sharing a favourite memory, personal story, or anecdote</strong>. A range of perspectives will enrich your speech and help strike the right tone right with your audience. You might also discover a true gem in the process, like a beautiful quote that perfectly captures your loved one’s personality, qualities, and quirks.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>4. Consider the length</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How long should a eulogy be?<strong> Some funeral speeches are very brief and there are no set rules for length, but 3-5 minutes is common.</strong> Make it long enough to properly honour the person and say what needs to be said, in proportion to the rest of the funeral service. To get it right, try reading it out loud a few times while timing yourself and editing accordingly.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>5. Make it honest</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It is possible to talk about someone’s achievements and qualities without glorifying them and mention shortcomings or disappointments in a kind and accepting way. None of us are perfect, and we remember those we have lost in all their human complexity. <strong>Follow your instincts, even using some gentle humour if it feels right and relevant.</strong> And if you’re not sure, ask someone else for their honest feedback before you finalise your eulogy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>6. End on a touching note</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ending a eulogy on the right note can be tricky. <strong>One option is to finish with a poem or <a href="/the-35-greatest-grief-quotes/">quote</a> that feels consoling and meaningful, even if it happens to come from a movie such as <em>Pretty Woman</em> or <em>Lord of the Rings</em>!</strong> You might find inspiration in famous eulogies, such as Matthew’s tribute to his partner Gareth in <em>Four Weddings and a Funeral</em>, Oprah Winfrey’s speech for Rosa Parks, Mona Simpson remembering her brother Steve Jobs, or in books and online quote collections.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center"><strong>Eulogy examples</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"background":"#fffdea","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fffdea;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="structure"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>An example structure</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">With the tips above, a ‘template’ for your loved one’s eulogy starts to come together. But if you’re not quite sure how to structure it, here’s a framework you can follow when you start writing:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Introduction</strong>:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li><strong>Give a brief background on the person who has died.</strong> Mention any nicknames they might have had; talk about their work or the things that were most important to them.</li><li><strong>Mention your relationship</strong> to them and what they meant to you and others.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Talk about some of their best qualities</strong> and values they held dear.&nbsp;</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Mid-section:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li><strong>You might want to include an anecdote here.</strong> Depending on the tone, you could make this funny, heart-warming, and/or even inspirational.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Dive deeper into the things they cared about most</strong>: this could be family, friends, a pet or even a hobby.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Cover their biggest accomplishments or life events.</strong> If they have a partner and/or kids, talk about them. You could even speak directly to them in parts.</li><li><strong>Capture what that person meant to others.</strong> This would be a good place to add personal stories or short quotes from their friends and family members.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Closing:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li><strong>Start closing the eulogy with a final takeaway</strong>, whether it’s a saying your loved one often used or something that ties back to the eulogy’s overall theme.&nbsp;</li><li>At this point, you could speak directly to the loved one you have lost, and tell them ‘thank you’ and that you love them.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>You could also thank those at the funeral</strong> or memorial service for being there, and remind them how much your loved one admired them all.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Think about ending with a quote, a poem, or a lyric from your loved one’s favourite song. You can keep it short and meaningful, a touching end to a funeral speech.</strong></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join Untangle's free grief community</a></strong> - </p>

<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#cee6f2"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#cee6f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="parent"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Eulogy example for a parent</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Talk about:&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li>What your mother or father <strong>meant to you</strong> and your siblings</li><li><strong>What they did</strong> both for your family and a living</li><li>How they raised you and the <strong>values</strong> they passed on</li><li><strong>Funny stories</strong> or <strong>touching memories</strong> that you’ll always remember</li><li>Something they once told you or <strong>a saying they had</strong></li><li><strong>The people who meant the most to them</strong></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Example eulogy:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>My dad was my hero. No matter how busy things got, he always made time for the people he cared about, and showed us that family always comes first – no matter what. Everyone who knew him knew how proud he was of the people he loved, of his dog, Buddy, and of his car… of course. You never had to ask what he was doing on a Sunday – he’d be outside washing the car </em><strong><em>again</em>.&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>I’m going to miss my dad so much, <strong>but I’m grateful for the wonderful memories I have of him.</strong> The happy trips to Cornwall when we were kids, the walks we used to go on, even just sitting on the sofa watching TV together. He made everything fun, and he knew just how precious our time on Earth is. <strong>He was always reminding me and my sisters to “enjoy life”, and that’s what he did, every day.&nbsp;</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>I know a lot of you will be feeling as heartbroken as I am right now, and I also know that if there was anything my dad wanted me to say today, it’s this: thank you, to all of you. Everyone sitting here today meant so much to him; his work friends, his childhood friends, his whole family. He often talked about how lucky he was to have you all. I hope he knew how lucky we were to have him too. <strong>I love you Dad, thank you for being the best father we could have ever hoped for.&nbsp;</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:spacer {"height":"21px"} -->

<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#fbe0c3"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="sibling"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Eulogy examples for a sibling</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Talk about:&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li>What your mother or father meant to you and your siblings</li><li>What they did both for your family and a living</li><li>How they raised you and the values they passed on</li><li>Funny stories or touching memories that you’ll always remember</li><li>Something they once told you or a saying they had</li><li>The people who meant the most to them</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Example eulogy:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em><strong>There will never be enough words to sum up my big sister. She was funny, kind, smart, determined… In the eyes of me and my parents, she lit up every room she walked into.</strong> [Name] threw herself at every opportunity – she never did anything by halves. When she was 21, she signed up for the marathon because she’d seen some running shoes she liked – and, of course, she smashed it. When she was 26, she went to the dog shelter ‘just to take a look’, and came home with two pups, Charlie and Bubbles, who adored her.&nbsp;</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>So it was no surprise that she took so naturally to becoming a mum. I can’t describe the joy of seeing [Name] raise her two girls – my two favourite people – with the same care and kindness she had always shown me as her little sister. They were her pride and joy, and there is so much of [Name] in both of them. They share her generosity, fierce loyalty, flawless sense of style, and quick wit. [Kids’ names],<strong> I know nothing will ever erase the heartbreak of losing your mum, but I hope you know that we are all here for you always.&nbsp;</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>[Name] was also a brilliant friend. She knew anyone and everyone. Sometimes it felt like there was nowhere we could go where she wouldn’t bump into at least one person who saw how brilliant she was. People were drawn to her, and her passion for life. But no matter how many friends she made, she’d never be without her best ones: Amy and Scott. She loved you both so much, and your wild stories will live on forever.&nbsp;</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>[Name], thank you for everything. For being the life of the party, for always knowing how to make us all laugh, and for showing us how to live life to the fullest. <strong>There will never be a day we don’t miss you, but we’ll carry your love wherever we go, and your girls will never stop hearing stories about their magical mum.</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join Untangle's free grief community</a></strong> - </p>

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#f9f5f2"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f9f5f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="grandparent"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Eulogy examples for a grandparent</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Talk about:&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li>Your grandmother or grandfather’s life and the people they loved</li><li>Their personality, their humour and their values</li><li>The role they played in your upbringing</li><li>Heartwarming memories of time spent with them</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Example eulogy:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em><strong>There was nobody funnier or more quick-witted than my grandmother. </strong>She was a force of nature who never failed to surprise people with her sharp one-liners and her teasing sense of humour. But she was also incredibly warm and kind. I’ll never forget our visits, Frank Sinatra playing in her living room, bowls of sweets on every surface, and her asking me, “so, what’s the latest gossip?”</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>She loved to chat, travel and see friends. Nan had a more active social life than anyone I know, and was always the ‘hostess with the mostest’, finding literally any reason to throw a party. <strong>Her love for her family was such a gift; something that my brother, parents, cousins, aunts, uncles and I were so lucky to experience every day.&nbsp;</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>But Nan’s love for people didn’t just stay in her family. She was extremely charitable, hosting fundraisers, volunteering at charity shops, and offering help to anyone in need. When our grandad passed, she dedicated so much of her time TO raising money for the hospice that looked after him, as well as the RNLI in tribute to his time as a lifeguard.&nbsp;</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>My nan and grandad’s love is something my brother, cousins and I all aspire to. Their adoration for one another was clear, and I can still hear them singing together in the kitchen. <strong>I like to think that now they’re finally back together again, having a song and a dance and big knees up.</strong> We love you Nan – thank you for everything.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->

<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#e8f5ee"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#e8f5ee;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="friend"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Eulogy example for a friend</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Talk about:&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, &quot;Segoe UI&quot;, Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, &quot;Helvetica Neue&quot;, sans-serif;">How you met your friend and what your first impressions </span>were</li><li>What made them such a wonderful friend</li><li>Their passions and hobbies</li><li>Their other friends and family</li><li>Funny stories or memorable anecdotes</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Example eulogy:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>I’ll never forget the first time I met [Name]. I’d just moved into our halls at uni and found him in the kitchen, wearing nothing but a towel, panicking because he’d flooded his shower on day one. I quickly realised that these kinds of mishaps followed him pretty much everywhere, from the time he turned up at the airport three weeks late for a flight, to when his dog really did eat his coursework. There was always a story with [Name].</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em><strong>But beneath the constant jokes, mayhem and penchant for Hawaiian shirts, [Name] had the best heart. </strong>He was a true friend who backed all of us – even when we were definitely in the wrong! [Name] was the first person who called me when my dad passed away, the most dedicated best man at 3(!) of our friends’ weddings, and when he found [partner’s name], he became the most devoted boyfriend and fiancé.&nbsp;</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>Anyone who knew [Name] knew how much he adored [partner’s name], how strong his bond was with his brothers, and how he loved nothing more than a hungover Sunday roast at his parents’ house. <strong>We’ll all miss him terribly, but it’s impossible not to smile when we think of him. [Name], you were a true friend. We’ll keep on making mischief in your honour.</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center" id="examples">More eulogy examples</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The short eulogy examples above will have hopefully given you some inspiration on how you can structure your loved one’s funeral speech or the kinds of things you can talk about. We also wanted to share some well-known examples to give you extra ideas to work with. Here are a few that have stuck with us, and might help you too:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/30/opinion/mona-simpsons-eulogy-for-steve-jobs.html" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Mona Simpson’s eulogy for her brother Steve Jobs</a></li><li><a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/CXHMhmookOd/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Stacey Heale’s eulogy for her late husband Greg</a></li><li><a href="https://www.funeralwise.com/celebration-of-life/eulogy/irwin-bindi/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Eight-year-old Bindi Irwin’s eulogy for her dad Steve Irwin</a></li><li><a href="https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/mother-s-eulogy-for-daughter-iris-goldsmith-15-at-funeral-love-like-she-loved-and-live-like-she-lived-a4193786.html" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Kate Rothschild’s eulogy for her 15-year-old daughter Iris Goldsmith</a></li><li><a href="https://www.funeralwise.com/celebration-of-life/eulogy/chapman/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">John Cleese’s eulogy written for George Chapman</a></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Looking for more advice on dealing with a loss? Read our guide on <a href="/what-to-say-someone-grieving/">what to say when someone dies</a>. If you’re planning a funeral, our round-up of the <a href="/funeral-songs/">most popular funeral songs</a> will also be useful to you.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		Preparing yourself for the funeral
		https://untanglegrief.com/preparing-yourself-for-the-funeral/
		Tue, 03 Aug 2021 08:39:18 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=84
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There is no escaping the fact that the funeral will be hard, but finding ways to alleviate your nerves and process your thoughts and feelings can help you feel ready to face it. We want to share a few ways you can emotionally prepare yourself in the run up to a funeral.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Be kind to yourself</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The lead up to a funeral is often a particularly stressful and upsetting part of the grieving process. The <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/">practical aspects of funeral preparation</a> and the worry about how you’ll feel on the day can be overwhelming while you’re coping with grief. It’s completely natural to feel apprehensive about attending a funeral. If you had a close relationship with the person who has died, you might have intense waves of grief that can sometimes be quite overwhelming. Worrying about how you’ll manage your feelings and whether you’ll ‘hold it together’ on the day of the funeral can bring added pressure.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Be kind to yourself and don’t expect too much. It’s normal to cry and express sadness at a funeral, and no one will expect you to hold it all in. You might find it comforting to share your grief and memories of the person who has died with other mourners. In a recent survey, our community members said that hearing other people’s stories about the deceased was one of the things they like most about funerals. It’s also important to know that there is no ‘right way’ to grieve. You might feel numb at times, and that can be a normal part of the grieving process, too.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Accept offers to help</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>After a loss, the people around you will often pull together to support you in any way they can. This could be with practical help, such as taking responsibility for part of the funeral preparation, or by simply being there for you as a listening ear and a shoulder to cry on. Accepting offers of help can give you the time and headspace to process your thoughts and focus on emotionally preparing for the funeral.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Along with offers of support from family and friends, you might find that some colleagues, neighbours and acquaintances also want to help with funeral preparations. Don’t worry about bothering someone or being a nuisance - people are offering help because they want to be there for you. Contributing to the funeral in some way may also help them in their grieving process. Often, people want to help but don’t know how. They may well be grateful to be given specific things to do. Read <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/">our advice for planning a funeral</a> for some suggestions of which tasks you can delegate.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When you look back at this time, it can be comforting to remember the people around you who reached out and were there to support you when you needed them.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Don’t numb your feelings</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Waves of grief can be uncomfortable and intense, but dealing with them as they come, rather than pushing them away, can help the grieving process in the long run. Burying your emotions can impact your mental and physical health over time.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Try to resist numbing your feelings with alcohol or drugs. Unhealthy or harmful coping mechanisms only mask your feelings and will very likely make you feel worse. If you’re struggling to process your feelings around your loss, you might want to consider <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/events/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><strong><u>bereavement counselling</u></strong></a>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Consider joining a support group</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you think you may find comfort from meeting other people going through a similar experience to you, <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/events/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><strong><u>we host in-person and online grieving groups</u></strong></a> that bring together people who are coping with loss. These can be particularly helpful for people who have experienced an unexpected, complex, or traumatic bereavement, such as losing a child. Some grief groups are run by counsellors, therapists, or other professionals who can offer specialist bereavement support.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Take advice from the funeral director</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You might feel that fear of the unknown is one of the most upsetting parts of preparing for a funeral. What will happen on the day? What if something goes wrong? What if I go to pieces?<br />This is where a good funeral director is invaluable. Most good funeral directors will walk you through the steps and timings of the day, so you know what to expect. They work hard behind the scenes to make sure the day runs smoothly, so you can focus on saying goodbye to your loved one. You can find a funeral director through our funeral booking service.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Preparation is key</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When attending a funeral, the little things can become big things if you leave them until the last minute. It’s best to be organised and ready, so you don’t have any decisions to make or jobs to do on the day.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Choose your outfit and make sure it’s ready to wear</li>
<li>Plan what you’ll have for breakfast</li>
<li>Delegate tasks to family and friends so you don’t have to remember anything on the day</li>
<li>Double check with the funeral director that nothing is outstanding</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Being organised can help to relieve nerves and will prevent any last-minute panic on the day. If you plan to read<a href="https://untanglegrief.com/how-to-write-a-eulogy/"> a eulogy</a> or reading at the service, it can be a good idea to practice at home beforehand. You may become emotional when reading some parts, and it can be good to get some of this emotion out at home. You might still get upset when speaking on the day, and that’s ok; don’t put pressure on yourself to hold it all in.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		Our guide to planning a funeral
		https://untanglegrief.com/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/
		Tue, 03 Aug 2021 08:43:51 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=87
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In the early days and weeks after a bereavement, the process of planning a funeral can feel quite overwhelming. There can be difficult decisions to make, including honouring the wishes of the person who has died, which type of funeral service to choose, and whether to opt for burial or cremation. It can help you know what to expect, so you can make decisions that are right for you and your family.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What are my options for planning a funeral?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You will have a choice between a religious or non-religious funeral service. Anyone can legally conduct a funeral or memorial service, although a member of the clergy will usually officiate a religious ceremony, and a civil celebrant will usually officiate a non-religious ceremony (also known as a humanist ceremony).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The funeral service is followed by either a burial or cremation. Often, the person who has died will have expressed a preference for one or the other when they were alive. If not, you may wish to abide by certain religious beliefs and cultural values to help you decide.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you have a special place where you would prefer to remember your loved one, that may influence your decision on whether to choose a burial or cremation. With a burial, there is a grave to visit and maintain. After a cremation, the <a href="/scattering-ashes/">ashes</a> are returned to the family for them to keep at home or scatter at a meaningful location.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What happens at a burial?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>After the funeral service, the mourners will assemble at the graveside for the burial. The grave will be prepared and ready before you arrive. A short ceremony takes place, usually led by a religious leader or celebrant. It can involve readings and prayers at the graveside. When the time comes, the casket or coffin is lowered into the ground by nominated family bearers or funeral directors. Mourners are invited to throw flowers or scatter soil onto the coffin as a final goodbye. Some people might choose to stay at the graveside for quiet reflection after the ceremony.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What happens at a cremation?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A cremation is held at a designated crematorium. Sometimes the funeral service itself is held in the crematorium, or it can take place in a religious venue. You will arrive at the crematorium at your designated time slot, and as the service starts, sometimes you will follow behind the coffin to enter the chapel and take a seat.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The moment of taking the body away for cremation is called the committal. You will be asked beforehand whether you prefer curtains to be left open, or to close in front of the coffin as it is committed. Once the coffin is taken out of view, mourners are invited to view the flowers left in memory of the person who has died before going to attend a reception or gathering.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What can I expect when planning a funeral?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As you are in the very early days and weeks of coping with grief, <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/preparing-yourself-for-the-funeral/">it’s normal to feel apprehensive and overwhelmed</a> at the thought of planning the funeral. Go easy on yourself during this time and spend some time preparing yourself emotionally.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Your chosen funeral director can guide and support you throughout the funeral planning, including advising of the options available within your budget. They can help make sure all the necessary paperwork is completed, provide appropriate transport to and from the funeral, arrange music for the ceremony, recommend and liaise with a florist, and much more.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Following a bereavement, the stress of planning a funeral can sometimes cause conflict between family members. It can help to resolve tensions by thinking about what the person who has died would have wanted and following any instructions in the Will. You could also get an impartial opinion from your funeral director, who will have experience in supporting grieving relatives.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What else do I need to know?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The estate of the deceased can cover the costs of the funeral. The person responsible for the estate administration (usually named in the Will) will have access to the funds once probate has been completed, a process that can take several months.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A funeral service is usually held within 2-3 weeks of death in the UK, but there can be some delay if a coroner’s inquest or post-mortem is ordered.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>How can I give my loved one the best send-off?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Funerals can bring together distant relatives or friends not seen for years, and in some ways, it can be comforting to know that you have all come together for the same reason: to celebrate the life of the person you loved.<br><br>You can personalise the funeral service to reflect the tastes and personality of the person who has died. Maybe you could arrange for their favourite song to play or ask mourners to wear a bright colour instead of black.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The <a href="/funeral-wake/" data-type="post">wake</a> is an opportunity to celebrate the life of the person who has died; to raise a toast to them and share memories and stories. Some people like to display photographs around the venue or arrange a video slideshow of happy memories. You can plan the wake in any way you choose, and after the heaviness of the day, people are often ready to give the person who has died a good send-off.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		How to notify utility companies of a bereavement
		https://untanglegrief.com/notifying-utility-companies-of-a-death/
		Tue, 10 Aug 2021 14:33:28 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=195
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946">To connect with others who share a similar experience of loss, as well as access to step-by-step guides for navigating death admin, <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">download the Untangle app</a>. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Notifying all the utility companies that your loved one held accounts with can be quite a long process.  It might help to go through their documents and list all of the utilities you find letters from. For example, most people hold the following accounts: water, electricity and/or gas, phone, broadband, television packages, and subscription services.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Most providers have a designated bereavement support customer service team who should explain the next steps to you once you’ve reported the death.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Who can do this?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In most cases, the utility companies will need to speak to the <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/wills-and-probate/">executor of a will</a> or the next-of-kin/administrator if your loved one died without leaving a will.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>When to do this?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ideally, notifying utility companies should happen within the first few months of your loved one’s death, once you have a death certificate.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What you will need:</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Your loved one’s personal details - name, address, date of birth</li><li>A copy of the death certificate</li><li>The account number</li><li>Up to date meter readings (if applicable)</li><li>In some cases, a grant of probate or letter of administration showing that you are allowed to make changes to the account - although you can make the initial contact with a company before either is granted</li><li>Your contact details and a proof of identification/address</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Step 1 - Decide what to do with each account</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>If the account is solely in the deceased's name and you want to continue the policy:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You will need to ask the utility company if you can change the lead name on the account. Occasionally, the company might ask you to create a new account in a new name depending upon its policy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>If the bills were paid from your joint bank account:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Your account will continue as normal as long as the joint payment bank account remains open.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>If you want to cancel the account:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Each provider has its own cancellation policies. In most cases, you will need to pay any outstanding balance or pay up until the end of a contract. If you are planning to sell the person’s property, we recommend keeping the utilities active (gas, water, electricity) and changing the account details into your own name.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>If the account is in both your name and theirs:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You might decide to take their name off the utilities account but this can be done at a later date.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>If the payment comes from the deceased's account:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>f you have already notified the bank of the death, your loved one’s bank account will probably be frozen. Therefore, you’ll need to contact the utilities company and arrange for payments to come from your account, to avoid any late payment fees.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Step 2 - Contacting the companies</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Gather the information above and contact each utility company in turn to notify them of the death. Some have online forms you can use to make the process faster, but you can also contact them via telephone if you prefer.<br>The utility provider should then guide you through the next steps and tell you if they need any further details or documentation.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Our advice for notifying utility companies</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Make sure you have your own personal details to hand if you are contacting the company over the phone</li><li>Think about what you would like to do with the policy ahead of the call</li><li>If you want to keep the account but face a charge to create a new account in your name, you may decide to shop around for different providers</li><li>Have a pen and paper to hand to note down details and any important timeframes. Don’t be afraid to ask the company to confirm any changes or closing of accounts in writing</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

		How to notify insurance companies of a bereavement
		https://untanglegrief.com/notifying-insurance-companies-of-a-death/
		Tue, 10 Aug 2021 15:05:10 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=200
		
		<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Life, car and home insurance providers</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Notifying the insurance companies that your loved one held policies with is one of the first tasks to complete in the administrative process. Most providers have a designated bereavement support customer service team who should explain the next steps to you once you’ve made the initial contact.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Who can do this?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In most cases, the insurance companies will need to speak to the executor of a will or the next-of-kin/administrator if your loved one died without leaving a will.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>When to do this?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ideally, you should notify insurers within a month of your loved one’s death once you have a death certificate.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Claiming life insurance</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Step 1 - How to find out if your loved one had a life insurance policy</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Firstly, check their will (if they had one), their bank statements, or ask their solicitor (if they had one). You can also visit the Unclaimed Asset Register, which is a database of thousands of life insurance policies, unclaimed pensions, shares, dividends, dormant savings accounts and lottery winnings. It costs £25 to run a search for a life policy. Access it here: <a href="https://www.uar.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">uar.co.uk</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Step 2 - Contacting the insurer</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Contact the insurance provider to make them aware of your situation and to let them know you are going to make a claim. You will need:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Your loved one’s name, last address and date of birth</li>
<li>The policy number (found on the policy documents or a bank statement)</li>
<li>The cause and place of death</li>
<li>Medical reports from a doctor if you are claiming for a terminal illness</li>
<li>An original death certificate</li>
<li>Your contact details and relationship with the person who died</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you cannot find all this information, call them with what you do have.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Step 3 - After the initial contact</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>After the first contact about the claim, an assessor will let you know of any extra information or documents they need from you. They will probably ask for a copy of the death certificate, information from the doctor of the deceased, and/or legal documentation, depending on the type of policy and circumstances of the death.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Notifying their home insurance provider</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Contact your loved one’s home insurance provider with the following information:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Your loved one’s name, last address and date of birth</li>
<li>A certified copy of their death certificate (if you have one at this stage)</li>
<li>The policy number</li>
<li>Your own proof of identity, for example, a valid driving license or passport</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The insurer should then guide you through the next steps and advise you of any further details or documentation needed.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Notifying their car insurance provider</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Contact your loved one’s car insurance provider with the following information:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Your loved one’s name, last address and date of birth</li>
<li>A certified copy of their death certificate (if you have one at this stage)</li>
<li>The policy number</li>
<li>The vehicle registration number</li>
<li>Your own proof of identity, for example, a valid driving license or passport</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you’re a named driver on the car insurance policy, check with the insurers whether you’re still covered. If you are not, you will need to get a new policy in place.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Watch out - most policies terminate on the death of the main policy holder and this will leave the car uninsured. Ideally, the car should be parked in private parking instead of on the road.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The provider should then guide you through the next steps and advise you of any further details or documentation needed.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Our advice for contacting insurers</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Make sure you have your own personal details to hand if you are contacting the insurance provider over the phone</li>
<li>It might be worth thinking ahead of time about what you would like to do with the policy - for example, whether you want to cancel it or change it into a different name. There may be extra costs for this</li>
<li>Have a pen and paper to hand to make notes of the call and any important timeframes. Don’t be afraid to ask the company to confirm any changes or closing of accounts in writing</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

		How to notify banks of a bereavement
		https://untanglegrief.com/notifying-banks-death-notification-service/
		Tue, 10 Aug 2021 15:13:15 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=207
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946">To meet others who share a similar experience of loss, as well as step-by-step guides to navigating the practical admin that comes after a loss, <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">join the Untangle app</a>. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>One of the first administrative tasks is to notify the banks and building societies where your loved one held accounts. Most banks and building societies have a designated bereavement support customer service team, and they should explain the next steps to you once you’ve made the initial contact. The Death Notification Service covers most of the common banks and building societies in the UK - this is a useful tool to avoid having to contact multiple organisations.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Who can do this?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In most cases, the banks and building societies will need to speak to the executor of a will, or the next-of-kin/administrator if your loved one died without leaving a will.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>When to do this?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This is one of the first tasks you'll need to complete. Once you have a death certificate, contact the bank or building society so they can temporarily freeze any payment in or out of the account. Joint bank accounts can continue to be used as normal. Any funds in the account can be used to pay for the funeral and probate fees or Inheritance Tax, if applicable.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Introduction to the Death Notification Service</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We recommend using the Death Notification Service to start the process of notifying financial organisations. This service allows you to inform several banks and building societies of your loved one’s death at the same time. You just have to fill out one form and it will notify all the providers for you.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>The organisations that are covered include:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Using the Death Notification Service (DNS)</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->


<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Step 1 - Gather the following details about your loved one:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->


<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Their full name </li>
<li>Their date of birth</li>
<li>The date of their death</li>
<li>Their last address</li>
<li>The Death Certificate number (also called a ‘System Number’ which can be found at the bottom left hand side of the death certificate)</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->


<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Helpful, but not mandatory, details include: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->


<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Bank account number(s) and sort code(s)</li>
<li>Building Society account number(s)</li>
<li>Confirmation of any credit cards </li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
</div>
<!-- /wp:column -->
