<!-- /wp:heading -->


<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Head to the DNS Website: <a href="https://www.deathnotificationservice.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Death Notification Service</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->


<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Scroll down to the bottom of the page and click the yellow button that says ‘Submit Death Notification’ to begin. We recommend you create an account afterwards so you can add other accounts that you might have forgotten about at a later date.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->


<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Step 3 - Next steps</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->


<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Within 10 working days, you should receive instructions of what to do next from each of the individual financial organisations. For example, you may need to provide a copy of the death certificate.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->


<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Contacting companies directly to notify them of a death</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->


<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The following organisations are not covered by the Death Notification Service. We have included links to the customer support team on their websites, so you can find the information to contact them yourself:</p>

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When notifying a bank or building society, make sure you have the following information to hand: </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->


<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Your loved one’s full name, date of birth and last address</li>
<li>A copy of their death certificate </li>
<li>Bank account details (e.g. account number and sort code) if you have them</li>
<li>Your relationship to the deceased, plus a form of identification</li>
</ul>

		The probate/ letter of administration process
		https://untanglegrief.com/wills-and-probate/
		Tue, 10 Aug 2021 16:17:14 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=212
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Managing wills and probate can be complicated, so here is a guide to the steps you will need to take - whether you are working with a solicitor or doing it yourself.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>If your loved one had a will: You'll need to apply for a grant of probate</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>The probate process: how long does probate take, and who can do it?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Obtaining a grant of probate allows you to access your loved one’s assets and distribute them in accordance with their will. The executor of the will should apply for probate within a few months of your loved one’s death, as it may be necessary to access and close certain accounts that your loved one held. The probate process can vary in length, but on average, administration takes 6-9 months.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>You don’t need it if:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>The person had no assets outside the UK, and</li>
<li>All assets were jointly owned (eg. Mr &amp; Mrs Jones’s bank account), <strong>or</strong></li>
<li>The value of the estate is less than £10,000 - but make sure you check with the financial providers!</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>You are likely to need probate if any of these apply to you:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>If your loved one had any assets overseas - this includes property or financial accounts</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>If your loved one had financial assets valued at over £10,000 that were not jointly owned e.g stocks, shares, savings</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>If the value of your loved one’s estate (everything they owned) is more than £10,000 - this includes property, money and possessions. Each bank has its own threshold to determine whether you need probate to access your loved one’s account with them</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>To find out the thresholds for probate, contact the account provider(s). If you do need to apply for grant of probate, follow the steps in our guide below:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/calculating-the-value-of-the-estate-probate/">Step 1 - Estimating the value of the estate</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/do-i-need-to-pay-inheritance-tax-probate/">Step 2 - Do I need to pay Inheritance Tax?</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/applying-for-grant-of-probate/">Step 3 - Applying for probate and next steps</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>If your loved one didn't have a will: You'll need to apply for a letter of administration</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>What is letter of administration and who can do it?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Obtaining a letter of administration allows you to access your loved one’s assets and distribute them in accordance with their will. The executor of the will should apply for probate within a few months of your loved one’s death, as it may be necessary to access and close certain accounts that your loved one held.<br />In this situation, the person who deals with the estate is usually the deceased’s next-of-kin, such as a spouse or child. You should apply for a letter of administration within the first few months of your loved one’s death if you need to access or handle their accounts.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>You don’t need it if:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>The person had no assets outside the UK, and</li>
<li>All assets were jointly owned (eg. Mr &amp; Mrs Jones’s bank account), <strong>or</strong></li>
<li>The value of the estate is less than £10,000 - but make sure you check with the financial providers!</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>You are likely to need a letter of administration if any of these apply to you:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>If your loved one had any assets overseas - this includes property or financial accounts</li>
<li>If your loved one had financial assets valued at over £10,000 that were not jointly owned e.g stocks, shares, savings</li>
<li>If the value of your loved one’s estate (everything they owned) is more than £10,000 - this includes property, money and possessions. Each bank has its own threshold to determine whether you need a letter of administration to access your loved one’s account with them</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>To find out the thresholds for removing assets from your loved one's accounts, contact the account provider(s). If you do need to apply for a letter of administration, follow the steps in our guide below:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/calculating-the-value-of-the-estate-probate/">Step 1 - Estimating the value of the estate</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/do-i-need-to-pay-inheritance-tax-probate/">Step 2 - Do I need to pay Inheritance Tax?</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/applying-for-grant-of-probate/">Step 3 - Applying for a letter of administration and next steps</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		Calculating the value of the estate
		https://untanglegrief.com/calculating-the-value-of-the-estate-probate/
		Tue, 10 Aug 2021 16:23:57 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=216
		
		<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>What is an estate?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>An estate is everything your loved one owned. This includes property, money in their financial accounts (eg. bank, building society, pension pot) and possessions.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>First, you need to value the money and all financial assets they owned</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You might have already contacted all the financial organisations your loved one held accounts with. Just as a reminder, organisations to contact often include:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Their bank or building society - ask them to freeze any payments into or out of the account until you have applied for probate</li>
<li><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/finding-lost-pensions/">Their pension provider</a></li>
<li>Any companies with which they held stocks or shares</li>
<li>Their employer - they may be owed wages</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ask each of the organisations for a statement of the value of the assets and any debts held by the deceased. If they had a mortgage, ask their mortgage lender if they require payments to continue while you are completing the probate process.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Make a list of all the information you receive from the financial account providers. Include any lump sums from pensions or life insurance.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Then, you will need to consider any gifts made by the person who has died, which took place within the 7 years prior to their death.</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Any gifts which totalled less than £3,000 in any year are exempt, as are any gifts made to charity or to a spouse or civil partner.  There are some other exemptions which apply to smaller gifts for weddings or special occasions, and where the gifts have been made out of surplus income.  If you have any doubt, you should seek professional advice.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Next, value your loved one’s possessions</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Make a list of all the possessions they owned and whether these were privately or jointly owned. The list might include property, furniture, artwork, jewellery and cars</li>
<li>Estimate the value of each of these possessions on the day that your loved one died. This is a rough price that each item could realistically be sold for, not the price they paid. You can research this online, or get a professional valuation. If the estate is liable to inheritance tax (see below), you are likely to need a professional valuation</li>
<li>Divide any assets jointly owned with your loved one’s spouse or civil partner by two. For any assets owned by more than two people, divide the asset by the number of owners</li>
<li>To value a property for probate or letter of administration:
<ul>
<li>a) If you know the value is not close to the Inheritance Tax threshold of £325,000, you can carry out a property valuation for probate yourself by searching for it on Zoopla, or searching for the value of similar properties in the same area</li>
<li>b) You can use a local estate agent, but if you think the property may be valued near to the Inheritance Tax threshold (£325,000), it is recommended that you use a chartered surveyor as they will have more experience valuing a property for probate and Inheritance Tax purposes</li>
</ul>
</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Add these figures together for an estimation of the total value of the estate for probate or letter of administration.</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Feeling a bit stuck?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We understand that calculating the value of an estate for probate is complicated. Although this guide will help you, others have said that using a solicitor takes away the pressure of dealing with estate laws and wills. Take a look at our trusted solicitor partners.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Next Step: <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/do-i-need-to-pay-inheritance-tax-probate/">Do I need to pay Inheritance Tax?</a></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

		Do I need to pay Inheritance Tax?
		https://untanglegrief.com/do-i-need-to-pay-inheritance-tax-probate/
		Tue, 10 Aug 2021 16:35:53 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=225
		
		<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What is Inheritance Tax?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Inheritance Tax is a tax you have to pay upon inheriting the estate of someone who has died, including all of their property, possessions and money. It needs to be paid by the executor. Inheritance Tax must be paid or partially paid before probate or letter of administration can be granted, although there are some exceptions. Inheritance tax is sometimes referred to as Capital Gains tax.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What is the threshold for paying Inheritance Tax?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You will need to pay Inheritance Tax if the estate is valued at over £325,000. Usually, anything over this threshold is taxed at a rate of 40%. However, there are many exceptions to this.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For more information: <a href="https://www.gov.uk/inheritance-tax" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">gov.uk</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are many other possible assets that might need to be added to the value of the estate to comply with estate law. These include interests in trusts (which might have arisen on the earlier death of a spouse), transfers of value within the last 7 years, or gifts made at any time where the person who has died retained some kind of benefit in the asset given away,  An example of this might be putting a house in the name of children, but continuing to live there or visit on holiday.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Typically, no Inheritance Tax is due if:</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/calculating-the-value-of-the-estate-probate/">The value of the estate</a> (taking into account all of the issues above) is below £325,000 - this is known as the Nil Rate Band (NRB)</li>
<li>Everything above the threshold is left to a spouse or civil partner, <strong>or</strong></li>
<li>Everything above the threshold is left to an exempt beneficiary such as a charity</li>
</ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You are obliged to file a report with HMRC even if there is no tax to pay. You can do this here: <a href="https://www.gov.uk/inheritance-tax" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">gov.uk</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>If you don’t need to pay Inheritance Tax, skip to Step 3: Applying for Probate or Letter of Administration</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Where do you get the money to pay?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Banks or building societies may release money out of your loved one’s account before probate or letter of administration has been issued if it is being used to pay Inheritance Tax directly to HMRC. If you are paying Inheritance Tax on property, HMRC may accept staggered payments spread over a period of time. If you pay the Inheritance Tax out of your own money, you can get a refund from the estate once probate has been granted.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>How to pay:</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list {"ordered":true} -->
<ol>
<li>Value your loved one’s estate (Step 1)</li>
<li>Decide whether it is likely that you will need to pay any Inheritance Tax based on the information in Step 2</li>
<li>Report the estimated value of the estate to HMRC (even if you will not need to pay Inheritance Tax)
<ul>
<li>You can do this here: <a href="https://www.gov.uk/valuing-estate-of-someone-who-died/tell-hmrc-estate-value" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">gov.uk</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>If you think you need to pay Inheritance Tax, apply for a reference number. This needs to happen at least three weeks before you make a payment.
<ul>
<li>You can do this here: <a href="https://www.gov.uk/paying-inheritance-tax/get-a-reference-number" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">gov.uk</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
</ol>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Feeling a bit stuck?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Sometimes getting a professional to take over helps moves things along. We offer a range of solicitors who can help take away the pressure of dealing with estate law and wills.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->

		Applying for grant of probate or letter of administration
		https://untanglegrief.com/applying-for-grant-of-probate/
		Tue, 10 Aug 2021 16:49:36 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=232
		
		<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>You will need:</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>The original will (if you have one)</li><li>The original death certificate or an interim death certificate from the coroner</li><li>A completed estimation and report of <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/calculating-the-value-of-the-estate-probate/">the value of the estate</a> from HMRC, as completed in Step 1</li><li>Depending on the value of the estate, a notice from HMRC saying that you’ve either paid Inheritance Tax or have no tax to pay, as completed in Step 2 or 3 (this can be corrected if necessary after <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/wills-and-probate/">the probate/ letter of administration</a> application is complete).</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Things to note:</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The application fee is £273 if the value of the estate is £5,000 or over. There is no application fee if the estate is under £5,000. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Extra copies of the grant of probate or letter of administration cost £1.50 each. It is worth getting a few copies - we would recommend one for each account you still have to close, so you are able to send them to different organisations at the same time. This should help you to complete the process faster.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>How to apply for probate:</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Once you have gathered all the documents from the list above, you need to complete the PA1P form and check whether you are eligible to apply for a grant of probate online
<ul>
<li>You can do this here: <a href="https://www.gov.uk/applying-for-probate/apply-for-probate" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">gov.uk</a></li>
</ul>
</li><li>If you are not eligible, you will need to submit the forms via post
<ul>
<li>You can do this here: <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/form-pa1p-apply-for-probate-the-deceased-had-a-will" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">gov.uk</a></li>
</ul>
</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>How to apply for letter of administration:</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Once you have gathered all the documents from the list above, you need to complete the PA1A form and check whether you are eligible to apply for letter of administration online
<ul>
<li>You can do this here: <a href="https://www.gov.uk/applying-for-probate/apply-for-probate" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">gov.uk</a></li>
</ul>
</li><li>If you are not eligible, you will need to submit the forms via post
<ul>
<li>You can do this here: <a href="https://www.gov.uk/government/publications/apply-for-probate-by-post-if-there-is-not-a-will" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">gov.uk</a></li>
</ul>
</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What's next?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul>
<li>Probate/ letter of administration usually takes <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/wills-and-probate/">around 8 weeks to be granted</a>, but might take longer at the moment due to coronavirus</li>
<li>If you have already contacted financial organisations to inform them of your loved one’s death, the accounts should be frozen to stop payments going in or out. You can now go back to these providers to inform them that you have a grant of probate to act on the behalf of your loved one</li>
<li>Once you are able to access your loved one’s accounts,  you can make an accurate assessment of the value of their estate and can correct any under or overpayments of Inheritance Tax with HMRC</li>
<li>If you are doing this without a solicitor, you can find further information on the Government website
<ul>
<li>You can do this here: <a href="https://www.gov.uk/valuing-estate-of-someone-who-died/tell-hmrc-estate-value" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">gov.uk</a></li>
</ul>
</li>
<li>Depending upon the financial situation of your loved one, you can now pay off any debts from the estate and distribute their assets according to their will (if there is one)</li>
<li>If the estate is complex, or if there are multiple beneficiaries, it would be sensible to keep detailed records or accounts showing the assets of the estate, all payments in and out, and the ultimate distributions to the beneficiaries</li>
</ul>
<p><em>Last updated: 16/06/22</em></p>
<!-- /wp:list -->

		Understanding grief and trauma
		https://untanglegrief.com/grief-and-trauma/
		Wed, 11 Aug 2021 09:12:08 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=262
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>After experiencing bereavement, grief can feel so overwhelming that it can be hard to know whether your feelings are normal or whether you may be suffering from trauma. Understanding the difference between <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/symptoms-of-grief/" data-type="post" data-id="4410">grief symptoms</a> and trauma can help you recognise a trauma response and know when and how to seek help.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>The distinction between grief symptoms and trauma</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Grief is a painful and complex set of emotions and can involve feelings of numbness, sadness, anger, and distress. It is a natural, human response to loss. There is no set grieving process, but over time, your feelings around your loss ebb and flow, and you find healthy ways to remember your loved one as you settle into a ‘new normal’.<br>Trauma is an emotional response to a distressing or disturbing event. Sometimes, bereavement can result in trauma, for example, if the death was unexpected, a result of violent crime, or was out of the expected natural order, such as the death of a child or young person. In these cases, you not only have the loss to process, but also the circumstances around the death. A prolonged trauma response is known as Post Traumatic Stress Disorder (PTSD).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A trauma response is your body’s attempt at protecting you from perceived danger. It puts you into a state of hyperarousal, or ‘shock’, linked to the fight/flight/freeze responses. PTSD can present as agitation and aggression (fight), anxiety and hyperactivity (flight), and feelings of disconnection or numbness (freeze). Trauma can also produce physical effects, such as headaches, nausea, digestive problems, sleep disturbances, changes in breathing or swallowing, and panic attacks.<br><br>As your brain continues to revisit the trauma, you might experience flashbacks and vivid dreams or nightmares. The impact of these distressing symptoms can be emotionally, psychologically and physically exhausting, and if left untreated, can cause long-lasting impacts on your health, relationships and daily life.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>When should I seek help?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It’s normal to feel a range of emotions as you grieve. As long as you can continue to move forward by working through your thoughts and feelings about your loss and leaning on friends and family if you need to, therapy isn’t usually necessary.<br>However, if you have any of the psychological or physical signs mentioned above or dealing with grief is stopping you from living your day to day life, you may be experiencing trauma and should seek advice from a professional. Using alcohol or drugs to help you manage your grief can be another sign that you may need to ask for help. Sometimes, people might not spot the signs of trauma in themselves, but the people around them start to pick up on changes in their personality or behaviour and suggest that they seek help.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you suspect you have trauma, a trained therapist or counsellor can carry out an assessment involving a series of questions designed to identify signs of trauma. They can then work with you to help you manage the symptoms and start to heal. <strong><a href="https://join.untanglegrief.com/therapy/?utm_source=article&amp;utm_medium=seo&amp;utm_campaign=grief-and-trauma">Find your perfect therapist or counsellor with Untangle.</a></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Who can help me?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are various ways of addressing and treating trauma and PTSD. When considering the available options, look for a service that delivers trauma-informed care, using specific techniques that avoid the risk of causing further trauma.<br>Trauma therapy or bereavement counselling can provide specialist treatment for PTSD. Two treatment modalities have been shown to be particularly effective in treating trauma: EMDR (Eye Movement Desensitisation and Reprocessing) and trauma-focused CBT (Cognitive Behavioural Therapy).&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Medication is not generally used as a first-line treatment option for PTSD but can sometimes be used alongside talking therapies. Your GP can advise you further.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Grief groups can provide additional support while you work through trauma and grief. We arrange various <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/events/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><strong><u>online support groups</u></strong></a> that can help connect you with other people going through similar experiences.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image -->
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://d1muf25xaso8hp.cloudfront.net/https%3A%2F%2Fs3.amazonaws.com%2Fappforest_uf%2Ff1615908039446x493088574549351200%2FGroup?w=1024&amp;h=76&amp;auto=compress&amp;fit=crop&amp;dpr=1.5" alt=""/></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Stories from our community</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We asked some of our current members of our community to share their stories about how they come to terms understanding their grief and trauma.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:quote -->
<blockquote class="wp-block-quote"><p>Linn- "I personally liked not being pushed; it was great to know I could come back anytime if I changed my mind. You don’t want to think about things when you’re in that headspace; you want very few options - you want to do the very minimum to get where you want to be, and because of the simple form, I didn’t feel overwhelmed. The therapist I am matched with is great. I never felt like I had to stick with someone I didn’t like."</p></blockquote>
<!-- /wp:quote -->

<!-- wp:quote -->

It was one of those things that you don’t realise you need until you’ve had it. It was a nice, easy process that made dealing with it at a time of high emotion easier. Without Untangle, I wouldn’t have known who to contact. I didn’t know that grief counselling was a thing."</p>
</blockquote>

		Is therapy right for me?
		https://untanglegrief.com/is-therapy-right-for-me/
		Wed, 11 Aug 2021 09:22:24 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=266
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you are considering counselling or therapy to deal with grief and bereavement, here are some pointers from two experts to help you think it through. Like unwelcome visitors, loss, bereavement and grief will inevitably turn up and insist on becoming part of our lives at some point. When they do, there’s no right or wrong way to feel or act - we are all different. But if life feels like too much to cope with, talking to a professional can really help. “A lot of people find it difficult to express themselves with family or friends,” says Adetoun Adams, an NHS psychotherapist and a counsellor for the charity Mind in East London. “Talking to a stranger allows people to open up and can make things feel lighter.”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Talking therapies</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>“Grief counselling is often the go-to approach rather than therapy,” says Dr Iain Jordan, a consultant in psychological medicine at Oxford University Hospitals. “Just talking through your problems and experiences in counselling, especially very painful ones, is very valuable.” However, some types of loss are more complex and traumatic than others, and there are many other types of ‘talking therapies’ that you can explore or request to be referred for, including clinical behavioural therapy (CBT), mindfulness-based cognitive therapy, and dynamic or interpersonal psychotherapy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Exploring your new identity in therapy after a loss can be vital, for example – such as figuring out who you are once you are no longer someone’s wife, daughter, or sister. Iain recommends therapy after a traumatic event as “you can recover by telling a different story, learning strategies for behaving differently, or changing unhelpful beliefs and assumptions.”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Choosing a therapist</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you’ve decided to try therapy, Iain recommends doing a little research and having a brief phone call with a few different therapists to see if there’s chemistry: “A mutually trusting relationship is fundamental – without it nothing will happen.”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>“It is OK to ask for someone who matches your life experience,” says Adetoun. “A black person might feel more comfortable seeing a black therapist, for example. Or you can ask to see a woman because you have issues with men.” However, Iain suggests thinking through the reasons behind your preference. “Are you avoiding something that you should be experiencing? Or is it because only this person can understand my experiences? “For example, if I am a man with a toxic attitude towards women, it might be a good idea for me to see a female therapist to focus on that.”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Accessing therapy</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In the UK, your GP can refer you for free NHS support, or you can self-refer through the Improving Access to Psychological Therapies (IAPT) programme which will assess you before assigning you to a therapist. You can also go through your local Mind branch. In some areas there is often a long NHS waiting list, but it depends on the severity of your needs as to how long it will take to get seen by someone. For a recent loss, you can get three sessions of early bereavement support and then go back on the list to a wait for a therapist in the longer term.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you want to go private and pay, Adetoun and Iain recommend looking for a therapist or counsellor on trusted websites including <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/psychologytoday.com" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u>psychologytoday.com</u></a> and the British Association of Counsellors, or <strong><a href="https://join.untanglegrief.com/therapy/?utm_source=article&amp;utm_medium=seo&amp;utm_campaign=is-therapy-right-for-me">Untangle's counselling and therapy services</a>.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Virtual support</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Counselling and therapy are increasingly available online and becoming more popular in this time of social distancing. But does online grief counselling work? “The evidence so far suggests that online works as well as face-to-face therapy,” says Iain. However he feels that deeper and more intense types of therapy might be more difficult online. “Some things happen in a room that would be harder to create at a distance, and it feels like a richer encounter when you are together.” Adetoun thinks that taking part in therapy online or over the phone is better than going without, as “at least you are talking to someone.”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Medication - or exercise?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Some of us might consider drugs to tackle issues like depression, but Iain isn’t a big fan of prescribing medication for people who are grieving, sad or anxious. “There should be a clear indication for it,” he explains. “Even if you have clinical-level disorder the effect is only slightly better than with a placebo”. Instead, he suggests putting an emphasis on exercise and eating well, keeping up connections with your loved ones, and making time to enjoy small day-to-day activities are probably more effective when combined together. “But if you are suffering terribly, talk to your doctor about medication to help you through a difficult period,” he continues. “You can then go on to get better in other ways, including therapy.”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>So does grief counselling work?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Telling a complete stranger your innermost thoughts can feel scary, but Adetoun’s advice is to try it before making your mind up: “Therapists have to provide a safe environment,” she explains. “You will be listened to, not judged, and everything is confidential.” Iain agrees: “Be curious. If you are suffering, want to behave differently or understand yourself better, any kind of therapy is useful. And you should grieve. You are supposed to stop and reflect. You’ll miss out if you don’t. It allows for a new period of transition.”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>“There’s an old joke that goes ‘how many therapists does it take to change a lightbulb’? The answer is: ‘Only one - if the lightbulb wants to change’. If you are willing to open yourself up to a different way of seeing yourself, it is almost always the right thing.” Often you won’t need long-term therapy: “after a bereavement some people just need one or two good sessions,” says Adetoun.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And your courage to take the plunge will pay off: “If people are brave enough to try, it can help them work through the different phases of their grief, or just come out feeling lighter,” she continues. “And they’ll know that although they are no longer thinking about the person they’ve lost every minute of the day, they still carry that person around in their heart.”</p>
<p>&nbsp;</p>
<p style="text-align: center;"><strong><a href="https://join.untanglegrief.com/therapy/?utm_source=article&amp;utm_medium=seo&amp;utm_campaign=is-therapy-right-for-me">Find your perfect grief therapist today with Untangle</a></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		Finding unexpected information about your loved one
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=319
		Wed, 11 Aug 2021 12:04:07 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=319
		
		<h3>Things to remember about discovering secrets</h3>
<ul>
 	<li>Secrets are a normal part of every person’s life. Nobody shares every aspect of themselves even with those closest to them.</li>
 	<li>It’s OK to feel overwhelmed or angry at a new revelation, but those are just feelings. They don't mean you didn't know the person.</li>
 	<li>This is just a new thing you now know about your loved one. It makes them more, not less.
Once you face your feelings, you will likely realize this wasn't really a surprise. It was always consistent with the person you knew.</li>
</ul>
<blockquote>
<p style="text-align: center;">It doesn’t mean you didn’t know them; it just means they weren’t what you thought – they were more than you thought.</p>
</blockquote>
<h3>Things to remember about discovering secrets</h3>
Once someone you loved is gone, you might think there’s nothing left to learn about them. After all, you cannot create any new memories together. But sometimes you discover new information that casts everything you thought you knew about them into a whole new light.

If you are one of the family or friends responsible for sorting through the contents of a home, a storage locker, or a safe-deposit box, you might expect to find familiar trinkets or long-hidden treasures. But there is always a chance you will find documents or mementos you never even suspected existed.

Closing out the material aspects of a loved one’s life can often be overwhelming or even painful. When you remove their belongings from their physical space, it can seem like losing them all over again, and heightened emotions can leave you crushed by memories that flood back all at once. If in the midst of all that you also discover secrets you weren’t meant to see or facts that your loved one neglected to mention, it can feel too huge to manage. Even if they’re happy secrets, the revelation can be very unsettling.

		20 things you can do to honour your loved one: Death Anniversary Ideas 2022
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=1718
		Thu, 04 Nov 2021 10:35:26 +0000
		yasin.mammeri
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=1718
		
		<span style="font-weight: 400;">Since the dawn of time humans have used landmarks to navigate their environment (and they’re not the only animal to do so). Even time itself has been landmarked to help us to overlay meaning onto its infinite passing. From birthdays to <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/surviving-christmas-whilst-grieving/">Christmas</a>, from New Year's day to an anniversary, we come back year after year to these meaningful moments. And though we often think of anniversaries as opportunities for celebration, some anniversaries can be quite challenging. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">One such challenging anniversary is the anniversary of a loved one passing away: The Death Anniversary; Deathday. It’s not often a topic at the dinner table, nor is it something explored in the zeitgeist. Instead, as with most things related to grief, it is often brushed under the carpet. We reckon it’s about time that we pull back that carpet and explore ways in which you can more easily navigate the challenges of The Death Anniversary and find some opportunities to celebrate and honor your loved one, that's why we've listed below our favourite 20 death anniversary ideas.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Before we get into the ways in which you can make a Death Anniversary special, it’s important to first acknowledge that some people believe the best thing to do on the anniversary of a loved one’s passing is to forget, distract, and suppress. Ignoring the things that make us feel bad can seem logical. If you stick your head under the sand for long enough, maybe one’s troubles will dissolve into sweet nothingness. Of course, it never quite works out that way. Suppression has long been known to extend the lifespan of unwanted feelings. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Like a wound left untreated leads to gangrene. It’s why women heal from breakups much sooner than men (on average): they confront the tough feelings head-on; they sit in the discomfort; they ask for support from their friends and family; they cry. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Whereas men tend to distract from PRG (Post Relationship Grief) with casual flings; drink; constant socialising; extended work hours; etc. So, as hard as it may be, if you can, try not to avoid your feelings or distract yourself from what you know is an important day (you wouldn’t be reading this if you didn’t think so).&nbsp;</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Below we’ve compiled a list of the most popular ways people choose to remember their loved one’s deathday. Go with what resonates with you most, and feel free to get creative and venture off the list. These are just meant as a starting point. The more the experience honors the unique relationship you had with them, the more cathartic and memorable it will be. Remember though, that the experience is for you and so can be as simple and unassuming or as complex and extravagant as you want it to be.</span>

&nbsp;

<b>20 things you can do on a death anniversary:</b>

&nbsp;
<ol>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Take the day off and just give yourself the time and space to grieve.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Write a letter to your loved one. You can explore a range of things: things you miss; things you resent; traumas; things you’re grateful for; things that were left unsaid; regrets; funny things you wish they’d been there to see; things they’d be proud of; gossip; questions; things you’ve let go of or forgiven; things that still make you laugh.&nbsp;&nbsp;</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Scatter some of their ashes somewhere meaningful. On a favourite walk or at the top of a mountain you used to climb together.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Do something you liked to do together – bring a friend or family member if you need support.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Travel to somewhere that’s been on your bucket list for a while.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Plant something in their memory. It can be extremely comforting to watch it grow over time.&nbsp;</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Throw a dinner party with people that knew your loved one well. Share stories. Laugh. Cry. Console. Connect.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Make it a potluck with your family, with everyone bringing your loved one’s favourite foods.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Go for a long walk. Take a friend or two and talk out your feelings, or walk alone and have some quiet time to think.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Look at their photos, videos, letters, journals, clothes, jewellery, books, and anything else they left behind. Maybe add some of these things to a scrap book.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Have a duvet day and watch their favourite films or TV shows.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Take a class to learn to do something your loved one enjoyed - this can be particularly connecting and help you to continue to get to know them.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Go somewhere that was special to the two of you. Leave them flowers and a note.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Spend the day helping others: do a charity run, or organise a fundraiser for a cause that mattered to the person you’ve lost.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you are religious, go to a service, spend the day with your community or take part in a memorial ritual.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Have a big gathering and set off some fireworks in their memory.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Go see one of their favourite bands play live.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Make a mix tape or Spotify playlist of tracks that they loved and listen to them.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">&nbsp;Do something you used to do together: snowboarding, hiking, ultra distance running, traveling, dancing, singing etc.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">&nbsp;Paint, draw, write a poem, or play a song to celebrate your loved one.</span></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">BONUS:&nbsp;</span>
<ol start="21">
 	<li><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Call up or visit someone who knew your loved one well and have a long chat. They may also be struggling.</span></li>
</ol>
<h2><b>Other Death Anniversary Ideas</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">It’s really up to you how you acknowledge the anniversary of the death of someone you love. The list of Death Anniversary Ideas above is far from exhaustive, so just use them to get the creative juices flowing. If you come up with something you think others could benefit from, let us know in the comments below and we’ll add it to the list! And be sure to remember that the grieving process is unique, so as long as you’re going into it with self-compassion, grieve in the way that feels most right to you.</span>

<a href="https://untanglegrief.com/sign-up/">Sign up for access to free grief support.</a>

		The 200 Best Funeral Songs of All Time - 2022 Edition
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=1835

		<h1><b>The 200 Best Funeral Songs of All Time</b></h1>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Music has been with us for about 35,000 years. To put that into perspective, we’ve farmed for just 12,000 years. So we were singing and making beats with sticks long before we ever considered planting wheat seeds. </span>

All this to say, music is deep in our bones. And it has a way of transcending all other things; of perfectly encapsulating a feeling or an emotion and bringing people together.

<span style="font-weight: 400;">It’s not uncommon for us to use songs like bookmarks for the landmarks of life. We hear a song at a wedding or a funeral and then the next time we hear it, it transports us back. We are there again, remembering it like it were yesterday.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">That’s why music is such an important consideration for a funeral. Pick funeral songs that capture the feeling of the moment and you’ll immortalise your loved one. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Given the gravity of your funeral song choices, it’s easy to get stuck deciding between a thousand different songs. We recommend in these instances that you try choosing songs that most closely match the song preferences of your loved one rather than random songs you hear on the radio.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Below we have the 200 best funeral songs for mum, funeral songs for dad, and the best funeral songs for grandparents. We’ve included a wide range of songs from old-school classics to modern hits, from the Top of the Pops to the gems off the beaten track - so there’s something for everyone. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Tip: If you’re looking to book a funeral service or want a funeral planner, reach out to us and we’ll be happy to provide free advice. </span>

&nbsp;

You may prefer uplifting and happy funeral songs, or maybe some classical funeral music.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">As funerals become more tailored to reflect the life of the person who has sadly passed away, families are opting for modern songs to be played at the service.</span>

		<span style="font-weight: 400;">It can be hard to know </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">what to say when someone dies</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">, especially if you have a different faith or cultural heritage to the bereaved person. This quick guide can help you to send the right </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">message to someone who has lost a loved one</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">, from Islam and Christianity to atheists and agnostics, across the continents.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Death and grief are universal experiences, but our cultural and religious traditions for showing empathy with people who have lost a loved one can vary widely.&nbsp;</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Supporting a grieving friend or relative can bring you closer together, as long as you respect their boundaries and beliefs. Keep an open mind and remember that we all process grief differently.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">A good starting point is to find out if the person grieving is religious or not. If you are afraid to ask, </span><a href="https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2019/03/this-is-the-best-and-simplest-world-map-of-religions"><span style="font-weight: 400;">this map</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> showing the size and spread of the world’s biggest faiths might give you some clues.&nbsp;</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">By doing some research you’ll have a good chance of getting it right and showing that you care.</span>
<h2><b>Christianity</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">As the world’s largest religion, Christian traditions surrounding death and grieving are interwoven with local ones. A </span><a href="https://www.cypresslawn.com/blog/mexican-funeral-traditions/#:~:text=In%20Mexico%2C%20after%20a%20death,their%20clothing%20and%20important%20possessions."><span style="font-weight: 400;">Mexican Catholic</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> may invite you to offer gifts and prayers at a 48-hour vigil, while an </span><a href="https://www.frazerconsultants.com/2017/08/cultural-spotlight-ethiopian-funeral-traditions/#:~:text=Expression%20of%20Grief&amp;text=And%20crying%20shows%20that%20the,harmful%20acts%20to%20express%20grief."><span style="font-weight: 400;">Orthodox Ethiopian</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> might expect to be cared for by their community ahead of a final celebration on their 40th day of mourning. As all Christians base their faith on the Bible, offering a </span><a href="https://www.kathleenfucciministries.org/blog/50-bible-verses-for-a-grieving-heart"><span style="font-weight: 400;">verse</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> or prayer for their loved one, or a </span><a href="https://futureofworking.com/what-to-write-in-a-sympathy-card-religious/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">simple message</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> of kindness and support in a card, could be a real source of comfort.&nbsp;</span>
<h2><b>Islam</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Muslims see death as a transition to the afterlife, and funerals take place as quickly as possible after someone passes away. Traditions vary between countries and groups, however mourners usually </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">avoid colourful clothes and jewellery</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">, express their feelings quietly during the funeral or prayer service, and always take their shoes off beforehand. You can </span><a href="https://www.quora.com/How-do-you-give-condolences-in-Arabic"><span style="font-weight: 400;">offer your condolences</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to the family afterwards. The mourning period can last up to 40 days, during which bereaved families often appreciate flowers, cards, words from the </span><a href="https://www.islamicity.org/5278/the-islamic-way-of-expressing-condolence-and-sympathy/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Qur’an</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, charity donations and gifts of (halal) food.</span>
<h2><b>Atheists and agnostics</b></h2>
<a href="https://www.pewforum.org/2012/12/18/global-religious-landscape-exec/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Around 16 per cent</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> of the world’s population are unaffiliated with any religion, including </span><a href="https://humanism.org.uk/humanism/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">humanists</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2013/sep/26/atheist-grieving"><span style="font-weight: 400;">atheists</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><a href="https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=cRmX9RVeNkU"><span style="font-weight: 400;">agnostics</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, now forming the second biggest belief system in Europe and </span><a href="https://www.nationalgeographic.com/news/2016/04/160422-atheism-agnostic-secular-nones-rising-religion/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">North America</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Ways of grieving vary, however many choose to celebrate their loved one’s life, our connections with each other and the planet, and see death as a final destination. Try keeping things simple and heartfelt, such as sharing a favourite memory of the deceased, sending flowers or a card expressing your sympathy and support.&nbsp;</span>

<a href="http://condolencepro.com/?page_id=861"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Messages like these</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> also work well if you aren’t sure how to refer to someone’s religion sensitively.&nbsp;</span>
<h2><b>Hinduism</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Most of the world’s 1 billion+ Hindus believe that the soul reincarnates into another being after death, depending on our Karma or actions in our previous life. Funeral mourners wear white (never black) and can expect an open casket followed by a cremation. You can send the family flowers ahead of the service but avoid sending food. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Hindus observe </span><a href="https://gal-dem.com/how-the-hindu-way-of-grieving-helped-overcome-losses/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">13 days of mourning</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, during which family, friends and community members visit to pay their respects. You can express your sympathy in </span><a href="https://www.quora.com/What-are-some-condolence-expressions-in-Hinduism"><span style="font-weight: 400;">many ways</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> – including by simply offering your heartfelt condolences.</span>
<h2><b>Buddhism</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Buddhists believe that when we die we go through the process of </span><a href="https://www.learnreligions.com/samsara-449968"><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">samsara</span></i></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, or reincarnation, before we are reborn according to our thoughts and actions in our previous life. Fu</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">neral customs vary widely, with a common thread of peace and serenity.&nbsp;</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">You can offer the family white or yellow flowers or a charity donation. Avoid anything red as it symbolises happiness. You can express your </span><a href="http://condolencecoach.blogspot.com/2015/02/the-4-immeasurables-for-condolence-to.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">condolences</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> in a card or in person, for example, by referring to </span><a href="https://tricycle.org/magazine/four-immeasurables/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Buddhism's four perfect virtues or ‘immeasurables’</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">: equanimity, love, compassion and joy.&nbsp;</span>
<h2><b>Judaism</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Many Jewish groups have their own distinct grieving traditions, along with similarities such as burying their dead within a day whenever possible. Avoid sending flowers, wear dark clothes during the funeral, and feel free to </span><a href="https://www.shiva.com/learning-center/death-and-mourning/placing-a-stone/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">place a small stone</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> on the grave with your left hand. Most families observe</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">&nbsp;“</span><a href="https://www.shiva.com/learning-center/understanding/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Shiva</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">” – the mourning period – during which visitors can send or bring (kosher) food baskets.&nbsp;&nbsp;“</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">May God console you among the other mourners of Zion and Jerusalem</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">” is one of many ways to </span><a href="https://www.myjewishlearning.com/article/jewish-words-of-comfort/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">offer your condolences</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to a Jewish person.&nbsp;</span>

<i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Is there a particular religious or cultural tradition that you’ve found comforting? Let us know.</span></i>

		The stages of grief myth
		https://untanglegrief.com/the-stages-of-grief-myth/
		Wed, 11 Aug 2021 09:37:09 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=269
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You are probably aware of the theory that after experiencing bereavement, we go through stages of grief. The well-known theory describes five stages, while others describe six, or seven stages. But, what if this widely accepted theory is merely a myth and there is no set grieving process at all? What if everyone grieves in their own way?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Here at Untangle, we believe that the long-standing stages of grief theory is misleading and unhelpful and fails to accurately represent how most people experience grief.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>The Five Stages of Grief Theory</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><p>The 5 stages of grief model was developed by psychiatrist Kübler-Ross in 1969. Although grief models had been discussed before this time, it was Kübler-Ross’s theory that gained traction and made it into the public psyche.</p>
<p>The 5 stages of grief described in the model are denial, anger, bargaining, depression, and acceptance.</p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><p>Over time, people came to think of the 5 stages of grief as the ‘correct’ way to grieve, believing that mourners must pass through each stage to complete the grieving process. In the years since its first publication, the theory has been debunked by many professionals. In fact, it’s reported that before her death, Kübler-Ross herself expressed regret at how her model was viewed. She said that it was never intended to suggest a linear progression through grief, but rather to explore the various reactions we might have after loss.</p>
<p>But despite her regret, the stages of grief myth persisted.</p></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>David Kessler: The Sixth Stage of Grief</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><a href="https://www.davidkesslertraining.com/">Kessler is a death and grief expert</a> who co-wrote two books with Kübler-Ross, as well as many &nbsp;of his own books. One of his theories builds upon the 5 stages of grief to add a sixth stage: finding meaning. Kessler argues that after we pass through the grieving process, we can transform grief into peace and hope by finding meaning in our life.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Seven Stages of Grief</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At various times over the years, others stages have been added to Kübler-Ross’s model, too. You might have heard of the 7 stages of grief, which adds ‘shock and disbelief’ as stage one, and ‘reconstruction’ before the final stage of ‘acceptance’. Just as with the 5-stage and 6-stage grief theories, this presents a rather linear process that we don’t think is true to life.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Other Theories</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In more recent years, many counselling and bereavement experts have looked for other ways to describe our experience of grief. Most acknowledge that grief isn’t a linear process and that people experience it in different ways.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>1. Tonkin’s model: Growing around Grief</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Lois Tonkin is a grief counsellor who coined the term ‘growing around grief’ after counselling clients who had experienced loss. She describes that rather than grief disappearing over time, it stays roughly the same, and the life of a bereaved person grows around it as they have new experiences and begin to look forward. At times, that grief can feel just as painful as it did at the beginning, and at other times, it’s in the background.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>2. Worden’s theory: Tasks of Mourning</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>William Worden, a psychology academic and child-bereavement expert, identified four ‘tasks’ that he says are an active part of grieving. He stresses that the tasks are not completed in a linear fashion and that people often return to each of the tasks at different times of their lives.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The fours tasks are:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>To accept the reality of the loss</li><li>To work through the pain of grief</li><li>To adjust to a world without the person who has died, and</li><li>To find an enduring connection with the person who has died, even when moving forward with life.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>3. Stroebe and Schut: The Dual Process Model of Coping</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Stroebe and Schut’s Dual Process Model breaks down grief into loss orientation and restoration orientation. Loss involves recognising and accepting that the person has died and how that affects other areas of life such as friendships and finances. Restoration focuses on the moments we can put grief aside to rebuild a life without the person who died. People frequently move between the two as they grieve.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>The Stages of Grief Myth: Why it matters</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The stages of grief model has become so widely accepted that it influences our cultural beliefs and attitude towards supporting people who have experienced loss. These misconceptions not only impact our ability to offer good bereavement support, but also give the impression that if you’re not moving through the stages of grief then you’re not grieving properly.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A 2010 study found that the majority of undergraduate psychiatric nursing textbooks contain myths about the grieving process:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>87% said that there are stages or a predictable course of grief</li><li>70% said that negative emotions such as depression are inevitable</li><li>65% said that there is a specific timeline for when grieving will occur</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>None of these statements is backed with evidence, but they are presented to psychiatric nursing students as fact. The fact that the stages of grief myth is perpetuated in these environments means that even our healthcare professionals are not taught how to handle grief effectively.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Part of our passion at Untangle comes from recognising the gaps in the current bereavement support provision. We provide <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/what-to-expect-at-a-grief-support-group/">wellbeing support</a> and <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/bereavement-guides/">practical help</a> for our community of people who are rebuilding their lives after loss. And we understand that every grief experience is as unique as the person experiencing it.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		Supporting grieving people in different religions
		https://untanglegrief.com/grieving-different-religions/
		Wed, 11 Aug 2021 09:47:51 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=272
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It can be hard to know what to say when someone dies, especially if you have a different faith or cultural heritage to the bereaved person. This quick guide can help you to send the right message to someone who has lost a loved one, from Islam and Christianity to atheists and agnostics, across the continents.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Death and grief are universal experiences, but our cultural and religious traditions for showing empathy with people who have lost a loved one can vary widely. Supporting a grieving friend or relative can bring you closer together, as long as you respect their boundaries and beliefs. Keep an open mind and remember that we all process grief differently.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A good starting point is to find out if the person grieving is religious or not. If you are afraid to ask, <a href="https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2019/03/this-is-the-best-and-simplest-world-map-of-religions" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>this map</strong></u></a> showing the size and spread of the world’s biggest faiths might give you some clues. By doing some research you’ll have a good chance of getting it right and showing that you care.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Christianity</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As the world’s largest religion, Christian traditions surrounding death and grieving are interwoven with local ones. A <a href="https://www.cypresslawn.com/blog/mexican-funeral-traditions/#:~:text=In%20Mexico%2C%20after%20a%20death,their%20clothing%20and%20important%20possessions." target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>Mexican Catholic</strong></u></a> may invite you to offer gifts and prayers at a 48-hour vigil, while an <a href="https://web.frazerconsultants.com/2017/08/cultural-spotlight-ethiopian-funeral-traditions/#:~:text=Expression%20of%20Grief&amp;text=And%20crying%20shows%20that%20the,harmful%20acts%20to%20express%20grief." target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>Orthodox Ethiopian</strong></u></a> might expect to be cared for by their community ahead of a final celebration on their 40th day of mourning. As all Christians base their faith on the Bible, offering a <a href="https://www.kathleenfucciministries.org/blog/50-bible-verses-for-a-grieving-heart" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>verse</strong></u></a> or prayer for their loved one, or a <a href="https://futureofworking.com/what-to-write-in-a-sympathy-card-religious/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>simple message</strong></u></a> of kindness and support in a card, could be a real source of comfort.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Islam</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Muslims see death as a transition to the afterlife, and funerals take place as quickly as possible after someone passes away. Traditions vary between countries and groups, however mourners usually avoid colourful clothes and jewellery, express their feelings quietly during the funeral or prayer service, and always take their shoes off beforehand. You can <a href="https://www.quora.com/How-do-you-give-condolences-in-Arabic" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>offer your condolences</strong></u></a> to the family afterwards. The mourning period can last up to 40 days, during which bereaved families often appreciate flowers, cards, words from the <a href="https://www.islamicity.org/5278/the-islamic-way-of-expressing-condolence-and-sympathy/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>Qur’an</strong></u></a>, charity donations and gifts of (halal) food.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Atheists and agnostics</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Around 16 per cent of the world’s population are unaffiliated with any religion, including humanists, atheists and agnostics, now forming the second biggest belief system in Europe and North America. Ways of grieving vary, however <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/how-to-memorial-ceremony/">many choose to celebrate their loved one’s life</a>, our connections with each other and the planet, and see death as a final destination. Try keeping things simple and heartfelt, such as sharing a favourite memory of the deceased, sending flowers or a card expressing your sympathy and support.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><a href="http://condolencepro.com/?page_id=861" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>Messages like these</strong></u></a> also work well if you aren’t sure how to refer to someone’s religion sensitively.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Hinduism</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Most of the world’s 1 billion+ Hindus believe that the soul reincarnates into another being after death, depending on our Karma or actions in our previous life. Funeral mourners wear white (never black) and can expect an open casket followed by a cremation. You can send the family flowers ahead of the service but avoid sending food. Hindus observe 13 days of mourning, during which family, friends and community members visit to pay their respects. You can express your sympathy in <a href="https://www.quora.com/What-are-some-condolence-expressions-in-Hinduism" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>many ways</strong></u></a> – including by simply offering your heartfelt condolences.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Buddhism</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Buddhists believe that when we die we go through the process of samsara, or reincarnation, before we are reborn according to our thoughts and actions in our previous life. Funeral customs vary widely, with a common thread of peace and serenity. You can offer the family white or yellow flowers or a charity donation. Avoid anything red as it symbolises happiness. You can express your condolences in a card or in person, for example, by referring to <a href="https://tricycle.org/magazine/four-immeasurables/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>Buddhism's four perfect virtues or ‘immeasurables’</strong></u></a>: equanimity, love, compassion and joy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Judaism</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Many Jewish groups have their own distinct grieving traditions, along with similarities such as burying their dead within a day whenever possible. Avoid sending flowers, wear dark clothes during the funeral, and feel free to place a small stone on the grave with your left hand. Most families observe “Shiva” – the mourning period – during which visitors can send or bring (kosher) food baskets.  “May God console you among the other mourners of Zion and Jerusalem” is one of many ways to <a href="https://www.myjewishlearning.com/article/jewish-words-of-comfort/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>offer your condolences</strong></u></a> to a Jewish person.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Is there a particular religious or cultural tradition that you’ve found comforting? <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/contact/">Let us know.</a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		How do I keep a loved one's memory alive after their death?
		https://untanglegrief.com/remembering-a-loved-one/
		Wed, 11 Aug 2021 10:28:07 +0000
		creativebrains01
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=275
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Grief after bereavement doesn’t end with the funeral, and there are lots of ways to continue honouring the person who has died and find comfort in the process. <em>By Hannah Jackson-McCamley, Funeral Celebrant </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>Hannah is an <a href="https://www.hannahthecelebrant.com/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><u><strong>experienced celebrant who specialises in unique services</strong></u></a> that truly reflect the person that has died and the needs of those left behind. She is passionate about people, music, literature and travel and is training to be a psychotherapist.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When someone you love dies, it might seem as if life returns to “normal” for those around you once the funeral is over. Relatives might check in less often, and offerings of flowers or food dry up as friends assume you’re starting to ‘get over’ your bereavement.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Death, unfortunately, isn’t something we ever get over. But we can try to make peace with what has happened and even find joy when thinking of the past.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What does it mean to memorialise someone?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>My experience as a celebrant has taught me that finding different ways to remember the person that has died can really help us cope with our grief. When everything feels chaotic and the world is a little emptier than before, creating rituals that hold meaning can give you a sense of control and positivity.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It might be hard to look at old photos of happier times or listen to songs your lost person played when you were a kid. But a simple memorial rite can also alleviate pain and give you a sense of the person still being present in your life.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A memorial may sound a little grand - I’m not talking about unveiling a statue or starting a foundation in their name (although if that’s how you want to create a legacy, go for it – see below for more ideas!).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Memorials can be simple things that you hold close or share just with family and friends. Here are some suggestions:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Memorialising someone by yourself</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Watch the sunset or light a candle for your loved one when you miss them. Sunlight and flames are symbolic of life, create a warm atmosphere, and are also very peaceful to watch.</li><li>Say your person’s name, drop them into conversation, and share memories with your children and others who might never have met them.</li><li>Create an altar or small area devoted to your lost one - it can be as simple as a photo, or a snow globe they brought back from a trip, or a letter they sent you, etc.</li><li>Make a memory box or scrapbook of mementoes - ticket stubs, photos, birthday cards, dried flowers, etc.</li><li>Go to a place you both loved, alone, with the dog or other people, have a picnic there on birthdays and anniversaries, or whenever you feel like it.</li><li>Create a playlist of their favourite music and play it when you want to feel their presence.</li><li>Reupholster a piece of their furniture, give it pride of place at home, and use it every day.</li><li>Recycle their clothes, wear their watch or a jewellery. you can always update them by adding a new strap or recycling stones to create a new piece from the past. I got my Dad’s overcoat tailored to fit and I feel him with me whenever I wear it.</li><li>Plant a tree or a flower in a meaningful place or in your garden or grow a rosemary bush on your windowsill. It’s delicious to cook with and a traditional symbol of remembrance.</li><li>Write their life story or note down your favourite memories in a memory book. Ask others to contribute and add photos. On the first anniversary of their passing, send a bound version to people they loved.</li><li>Write a letter to your person on your birthday, telling them your news.</li><li>Give blood or register as a donor – it could help save someone else’s life.</li><li>Volunteer at the hospital or home that cared for them. This may be triggering for some, but cathartic to others.</li><li>Use art to express your feelings - poetry, painting, music, writing… let it all out.</li><li>When you travel, leave a flower or note in a special place or light a candle in a faraway sacred space, like a church or synagogue.</li><li>Try things your person liked - gigs, foods, bungee jumping - experiencing things they enjoyed might make you feel closer.</li><li>Talk to them. Let them know how you’re getting on.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Memorialising with others</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Build a shared online photo album with friends and family. Ask others to contribute and update it whenever memories of your lost person come to mind.</li><li><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/how-to-memorial-ceremony/">Set an annual day of celebration</a> – small or big – to honour their life.</li><li>Host a dinner party (on Zoom or Skype if necessary) and cook a meal they used to love. Ask others to bring a dish that reminds them of the person or cook their favourite recipe together.</li><li>Host a party on their birthday or anniversary - e.g. a “Dead Dad Party” - remembrance doesn’t need to be sad!</li><li>Make a quilt or toys from their clothes to pass on to the next generation, inviting others to contribute a square or two.</li><li>List their favourite films and host screenings in their memory.</li><li>Get together and talk about your loved one - the good, the bad and the ugly, joy as well as sorrow.</li><li>Give people they loved their best loved books as gifts.</li><li>Toast them on holidays and festivals.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Memorials that involve money</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Make a charitable donation or join a charity fundraiser, like a run, in your loved one’s name.</li><li>Start an annual event with friends to raise money for a good cause in their memory.</li><li>Sponsor a seat at a theatre or a football club, a park bench or a space in an art gallery.</li><li>Create a legacy fund with a charity close to their heart or set up a fund for a cause that meant something to them.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->
