		30 (ish) best books on grief 2023
		https://untanglegrief.com/grief-books/
		Wed, 03 Nov 2021 12:19:33 +0000
		emma.harvey
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=1649
		
		We asked members of our community what they think are the best books on grief and loss.

Ranging from psychotherapist studies to books for children, here is a list of 30 books that you might find useful whilst grieving yourself, or as a thoughtful gift to send to a loved one who might be going through a loss.

Let us know if we’ve missed any good ones!
<h2>1. A Grief Observed by C.S. Lewis</h2>
The Chronicles of Narnia author C.S. Lewis had been married to his wife for four blissful years. When she died of cancer in 1960, he found himself alone, inconsolable in his grief. In this intimate journal, <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Grief-Observed-Faber-Paperbacks-ebook/dp/B009R66YUI?crid=IJMESZEBTJBU&amp;keywords=a+grief+observed&amp;qid=1678360855&amp;s=digital-text&amp;sprefix=a+grief+%2Cdigital-text%2C83&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=01d4dfb37bf6540ff5edee4b74f4e0d8&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">A Grief Observed</a> chronicles the aftermath of the bereavement and mourning with blazing honesty. He grapples with a crisis of religious faith, navigating hope, rage, despair, and love - but eventually regains his bearings, finding his way back to life.
<h2>2. A Half Baked Idea by Olivia Potts</h2>
At the moment her mother died, grief pushed Olivia into the kitchen. She came home from her job as a criminal barrister miserable and tired, and baked soda bread, pizza, and chocolate banana cake.

She found comfort in jams and solace in pies, and what began as a distraction from grief became a way of building a life outside grief, a way of surviving, and making sense of her life without her mum. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Half-Baked-Idea-courtroom-Cordon-ebook/dp/B07KMR6PT8?crid=1U3WMD5OSB3RI&amp;keywords=a+half+baked+idea&amp;qid=1678360913&amp;s=digital-text&amp;sprefix=a+half+baked+idea%2Cdigital-text%2C79&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=9cd3bf67044f13824e96ccdcc5c0ffaa&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">A Half Baked Idea</a> follows Olivia’s journey through her grief, whilst studying at Le Cordon Bleu - despite not being able to cook!
<h2>3. All At Sea by Decca Aitkenhead</h2>
On a hot still morning on a beautiful beach in Jamaica, Decca Aitkenhead's life changed forever. Her four-year-old boy was paddling peacefully at the water’s edge when a wave pulled him out to sea. Her partner, Tony, swam out and saved their son’s life then drowned before her eyes. Exploring race and redemption, privilege and prejudice, <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/All-at-Sea-Decca-Aitkenhead-ebook/dp/B015DLWSUU?crid=Q7MHGFFJXKQ9&amp;keywords=all+at+sea&amp;qid=1678360946&amp;s=digital-text&amp;sprefix=all+at+sea%2Cdigital-text%2C84&amp;sr=1-2&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=25d31b199f80ab48d37d9548b3003a42&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">All At Sea</a> is a remarkable story of love and loss, of how one couple changed each other's lives and of what a sudden death can do to the people who survive.
<h2>4. Being Mortal by Atul Gawande</h2>
<a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Being-Mortal-Medicine-Wellcome-Collection/dp/1846685826?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=1678360985&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=53dd285cd19b9b097e71570d358d1c21&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Being Mortal</a> is a book about the modern experience of mortality – what it’s like to get old and die, how medicine has changed this and how it has not, where our ideas about death have gone wrong. With his trademark mix of perceptiveness and sensitivity, Gawande outlines a story that crosses the globe, as he examines his experiences as a surgeon and those of his patients and family, and learns to accept the limits of what he can do.
<h2>5. Bird Therapy by Joe Harkness</h2>
When Joe Harkness suffered a breakdown in 2013, he tried all the things his doctor recommended: medication helped, counselling was enlightening, and mindfulness grounded him. But nothing came close to nature, particularly birds.

The positive change in Joe's wellbeing was so profound that he started a blog to record his experience. Three years later he became a spokesperson for the benefits of birdwatching, spreading the word everywhere from Radio 4 to Downing Street. In this groundbreaking book filled with practical advice, <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Bird-Therapy-Joe-Harkness/dp/1783528982?crid=1XD271K0FKH3S&amp;keywords=bird+therapy&amp;qid=1678361027&amp;s=books&amp;sprefix=bird+therapy%2Cstripbooks%2C81&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=ba04534d8b15fa45384f6d93e4b86b94&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Bird Therapy</a> explains the impact that birdwatching had on his life, and invites the reader to discover these extraordinary effects for themselves.
<h2>6. Cheer the F**k up by Jack Rooke</h2>
Part comedic memoir, part advice guide, this book is a fresh and timely take on a huge issue very close to Jack’s heart – in 2015, while working as an ambassador for a male mental health charity, he lost one of his best friends to suicide.

Taking you on a journey through his life and experiences with grief, sexuality, depression and more, Jack offers his own frank and powerful advice on how best to have meaningful conversations about a loved one’s state of mind. Hilarious and heart-breaking in equal measure, <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Cheer-Up-Save-your-Friend/dp/1529108241?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=1678361068&amp;sr=1-3&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=a0d74cf6b1cb67e0bcf895fb8c0e25d0&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Cheer the F**K Up</a> will definitely make you laugh and might just make you cry, but it could also help save a life.
<h2>7. Everything Is Horrible and Wonderful: A Tragicomic Memoir of Genius, Heroin, Love and Loss by Stephanie Wittels Wachs</h2>
A memoir of family, addiction, and grief from the sister of Harris Wittels, the Parks and Recreation writer whose death shocked the comedy world. In <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Everything-Horrible-Wonderful-Tragicomic-Memoir/dp/1492669857?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=&amp;sr=&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=94aa6a53a25812b6d4d668c22105a817&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Everything Is Horrible and Wonderful</a> Stephanie Wittels Wachs alternates between her brother's struggle with addiction, which she learned about three days before her wedding, and the first year after his death, in all its emotional devastation. A profound exploration of the love between siblings, it will make you laugh, cry, and wonder if that possum on the fence is really your brother's spirit animal.
<h2>8. Finding Joy by Gary Andrews</h2>
When his wife, Joy, died very suddenly, a daily drawing became the way Gary Andrews dealt with his grief. From learning how to juggle his kids' playdates and single-handedly organising Christmas, to getting used to the empty side of the bed, Gary's honest and often hilarious illustrations have touched the hearts of thousands on social media. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Finding-Joy-Gary-Andrews/dp/1529338131?crid=1FYZGFOKOSF61&amp;keywords=finding+joy+gary+andrews&amp;qid=1678361179&amp;s=books&amp;sprefix=finding+joy+gary%2Cstripbooks%2C79&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=251b2979e1bfbd7dab4634cbb2776523&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Finding Joy</a> is the story of how one family learned to live again after tragedy.
<h2>9. Grief Is the Thing with Feathers by Max Porter</h2>
A Sunday Times ‘Top 100 Novel of the 21st Century’, this story centres around two young boys in London who have just lost their mother suddenly. Their father cannot imagine life moving forwards without this deep sadness. In a moment of despair, the family are visited by Crow - and they are unsure whether he is an antagonist, a trickster, a babysitter - or indeed a healer.

The bird becomes attached to the family in the depths of their grief, and promises he will stay until they no longer need his guidance. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Grief-Thing-Feathers-Max-Porter/dp/0571327230?crid=U1T170GXEKFB&amp;keywords=grief+is+the+thing+with+feathers&amp;qid=1678361211&amp;s=books&amp;sprefix=grief+is%2Cstripbooks%2C87&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=6d63e7696db797ef33868f420e2eb75b&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Grief Is the Thing with Feathers</a> is full of humour and emotional depth, and the truths about grief will stay with you for a long time.
<h2>10. Healing After Loss: Daily Meditations For Working Through Grief by Martha Whitmore Hickman</h2>
A collection of thoughtful words to provide comfort and inspiration - for anyone who has lost a loved one. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Healing-After-Loss-Meditations-Working/dp/0380773384?&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=33f6c0e484ce3b04f8293608268ef7c4&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Healing After Loss</a> would also make a great gift!
<h2>11. How to Grieve Like a Champ by Lianna Champ</h2>
Lianna Champ is a bereavement counsellor, and has over forty years experience in funeral care. Lianna is passionate about improving our relationship with our own mortality, and feels strongly that if we have a good life, we can die well too. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/How-Grieve-Like-Champ-Lianna-ebook/dp/B0BS717LSZ?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=1678361319&amp;sr=1-1-fkmr1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=c2ae9319404ff1f9d822f28cb5d2f3a1&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">How to Grieve Like a Champ</a> is both emotionally comforting and practical, and presented in a way that even those in the depths of grief with a short attention span can easily digest the information and be comforted by her inspirational words.
<h2>12. Humankind: A Hopeful History by Rutger Bregman</h2>
A Sunday Times and New York Times bestseller, <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Humankind-Hopeful-History-Rutger-Bregman/dp/1408898950?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=1678361353&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=307e69d31c473e36fe03cf975f7afc1a&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Humankind</a> argues against the classic narrative that human beings are all naturally selfish and self-interested. Bregman argues that the trust and cooperation, rather than distrust and competition, can be traced back to the beginning of humanity. Bregman takes some of the world’s most famous case studies and events and frames them in a positive light, showing how believing that people can be altruistic and kind can help achieve real change in society.
<h2>13. It's OK That You're Not OK: Meeting Grief and Loss in a Culture That Doesn't Understand by Megan Devine</h2>
Megan Devine explores why our culture treats grief like something to be cured as quickly as possible, even though it is ‘a natural and sane response to loss.’ Devine has experienced grief from both sides - as a therapist and also as a woman after losing her partner in a tragic accident.

Using her experience, she writes truthfully about love, loss and healing, and debunks the myth of returning to a ‘normal’ life - instead preferring to invite you to build life alongside your grief. A mixture of stories, tips, research and mindfulness, <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Its-That-Youre-Not-Understand/dp/1622039076?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=1678361392&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=7509cb23f66ffd5d38b9e7a01af872df&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">It’s Ok That You’re Not Ok</a> offers a unique guide to the experience we will all face at one stage or another in our lives.
<h2>14. Languages of Loss: A Psychotherapist's Journey Through Grief by Sasha Bates</h2>
From her lived experience as a therapist, and after unexpectedly losing her husband Bill at only 49 years old, Sasha Bates finds a way to manage her pain by looking back over all she has learnt from her psychotherapeutic research and theories of grief, to help her navigate this new reality.

<a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Languages-Loss-psychotherapists-journey-through/dp/1529317169?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=1678361424&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=3f63692e02bee0a9fb3d4ad126fca7ee&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Languages of Loss</a> breaks down taboos and tries to find light moments and humour in the necessary conversation about what death and loss means. Highly recommended for those in the first few months of their loss, this book supports readers through the pain and gives them permission to explore all their feelings. The main message is that everyone grieves differently, but knowing more about the theory can help you feel less alone and reflect upon how far you’ve come.
<h2>15. Man’s Search For Meaning by Viktor E. Frankl</h2>
Frankl, a Holocaust survivor and prominent Viennese psychiatrist, tells his story and observations on the ways both he and others coped in Auschwitz, noticing that often those who provided comfort and showed kindness towards others survived for the longest.

He notes that even when everything is taken away from us, we still have the ability to choose how we behave and react. He concludes that humankind’s biggest wish is to search for a sense of purpose. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Mans-Search-Meaning-classic-Holocaust/dp/1844132390?crid=2M0EEXT5DJP55&amp;keywords=mans+search+for+meaning&amp;qid=1678361450&amp;s=books&amp;sprefix=mans%2Cstripbooks%2C86&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=98f73df95dfa6fd5af24c438de273e87&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Man's Search For Meaning</a> gives us a way to transcend our pain and suffering, and find reasons to keep on living.
<h2>16. Modern Loss: Candid Conversation about Grief. Beginners Welcome by Rebecca Soffer and Gabrielle Birkner</h2>
From the two co-founders of the website Modern Loss that ‘redefined mourning’ according to the New York Times, this collection of essays and tips guides the reader through grief in the modern age. Taken from insights and stories from the Modern Loss community, this book changes the dialogue around grief with wise and funny anecdotes that help the reader to cry, laugh, identify and grieve, and most importantly find empathy.

A host of guest contributors also give their unique takes on all aspects of grief and loss, including secrets, inheritance and triggers. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Modern-Loss-Conversation-Beginners-Welcome/dp/0062499181?&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=0a42ac6bf15df486a509ec87f2e1b4ec&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Modern Loss</a> invites you to talk openly and intimately about grief, confronting our own mortality with some humour along the way. Beginners welcome.
<h2>17. Not That Kind of Love by Clare and Greg Wise</h2>
Based on Clare Wise’s blog that she started after receiving a cancer diagnosis in 2013, this book follows the ups and downs of the last few years of her life. Full of candour and warmth rather than despair, Clare’s positive energy and dynamic personality fill every page.

In the later stages when she became too weak to type, her brother Greg took over, and the book offers poignant thoughts of the beauty of life, and the necessity of talking about death. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/That-Kind-Love-Clare-Wise/dp/1786488965?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=1678361508&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=024d6720176e09b250924fd4bfb8c441&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Not That Kind of Love</a> focuses on celebrating the small things, such as wearing ‘matching socks as you leave the house in the morning’ - and anything above that is a bonus in the act of living.
<h2>18. On Grief and Grieving: Finding the Meaning of Grief Through the Five Stages of Loss by Elisabeth Kubler-Ross and David Kessler</h2>
A famous and celebrated psychological study from the late twentieth century, <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Grief-Grieving-Finding-Meaning-Through/dp/1471139883?crid=3TLYDYHQK9YDA&amp;keywords=on+grief+and+grieving+elizabeth+kubler+ross&amp;qid=1678361541&amp;s=books&amp;sprefix=On+Grief+and+Grieving%2Cstripbooks%2C88&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=434c3d5ad90796ee72ac50c597934c8b&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">On Grief and Grieving</a> came out of Dr Elisabeth Kubler-Ross’ renowned seminar on life and death. It explores the five stages of grief - denial and isolation, anger, bargaining, depression and acceptance. Kubler-Ross gives you a better understanding of how death affects everyone involved, and hopes to bring hope to the reader.
<h2>19. Option B: Facing Adversity, Building Resilience, and Finding Joy by Sheryl Sandberg and Adam Grant</h2>
Sheryl Sandberg lost her husband Dave suddenly in 2015, aged only forty-eight. The lives of her family were turned upside down and she couldn’t imagine finding any joy or meaning again.

When she was talking to her friend about how she felt whilst missing Dave, her friend told her: "Option A is not available. So let's just kick the s*** out of Option B." Sandberg explains that we all face Option B at points in our lives - whether that’s dealing with losing jobs, losing love or losing lives.

<a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Option-Adversity-Building-Resilience-Finding/dp/0753548291?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=1678361569&amp;sr=1-2&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=90dfd9ebfa08bd178124479c051e2426&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Option B</a> mixes Sandberg’s experiences with research findings from Adam Grant and other social scientists, featuring stories from those who overcame hardship - personal and professional. It offers tips on how to deal with hard times in our own lives, and how to help others too. It also looks into pre-traumatic growth, and how we can raise resilient children and create strong communities - to find real joy and love in life.
<h2>20. Signs: The Secret Language of the Universe by Laura Lynne Jackson</h2>
Signs is a hopeful book, teaching you how to recognise and interpret messages from loved ones and guiding you through spiritual connections.

A psychic medium, Jackson has the ability to communicate with those who have passed away, send messages of love and gain a better understanding of these connections. She believes everyone can have these abilities, using the ‘secret language of the universe’ and recognising the signs.

<a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Signs-language-Laura-Lynne-Jackson/dp/0349424217?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=1678361600&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=5fd9c65f4b288e039aceaa57c5920b2a&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Signs</a> relays a mixture of stories from those who have found spiritual connections with their loved ones, and also draws from her own experiences - creating a book that is comforting, practical and motivational. Once we notice these signs, we can see light in the darkness and find meaning where before there was only confusion, allowing us to engage with life in a different way and pursue joy.
<h2>21. Surviving the Death of a Sibling: Living Through Grief When an Adult Brother or Sister Dies by T.J. Wray</h2>
After losing her brother aged 43, T.J. Wray found that sibling grief often went unacknowledged, and this type of loss is rarely socially recognised. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Surviving-Death-Sibling-Through-Brother/dp/0609809806?&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=822dd6b990418fa151195b3c8d4f4c8a&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Surviving the Death of a Sibling</a> helps others who have lost a brother or sister feel that they are not alone, and to understand their unique grieving process.

Warm and insightful, with tips such as using a grief journal and how to deal with insensitive remarks from others, this book offers rich guidance and ways to cope.
<h2>22. The Boy, The Mole, The Fox and The Horse by Charlie Mackesy</h2>
A book of hope, <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Boy-Mole-Fox-Horse/dp/1529105102?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=1678361661&amp;sr=1-3&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=e01929d86b7f26349096c08919b574e9&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">The Boy, The Mole, The Fox and The Horse</a> follows four unlikely friends as they tell their stories and share the life lessons they’ve learnt along the way. A mixture of beautiful illustrations and poignant thoughts, Mackesy explores feelings that we can all relate to.
<h2>23. The Heavy Bag by Sarah Surgey</h2>
A book for children, <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Heavy-Bag-Sarah-Surgey/dp/1838263012?&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=eab94cfd583a6ba3a1a9f8cafa1812c0&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">The Heavy Bag</a> follows a little girl named Enid who has recently lost her grandad. She feels the weight of all her emotions and feelings in her bag that she carries whilst on walk.

Along the road, she meets different people who encourage her to take out an item from her bag, and share how she is feeling. Each item represents a stage of grief, and as she unloads them, it gets easier and she continues walking with a lightness.
<h2>24. The Midnight Library by Matt Haig</h2>
Nora finds herself in <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Midnight-Library-Matt-Haig/dp/1786892731?crid=10MPM9PLSKFB5&amp;keywords=the+midnight+library&amp;qid=1678361719&amp;s=books&amp;sprefix=the+mid%2Cstripbooks%2C80&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=be931faddb082be05af0348b9cd27b2d&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">The Midnight Library</a>, a place between life and death. Her life has so far been filled with regret and misery, and letting all those around her down. But now she has the chance to change things around. The books in the library allow her to see what would have happened if she’d made different choices.

Helped by an old friend, she corrects all her past mistakes and tries to create the perfect life, but things are not always as she’d imagined. Before her time in the library runs out, she must answer the question - ‘what is the best way to live?’
<h2>25. The Swallow, the Owl and the Sandpiper: Words of Courage, Wisdom compiled by Claire Maitland</h2>
A collection of poetry, words and stories, this anthology is the perfect companion to your grief to dip in and out of on the hard days. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Swallow-Owl-Sandpiper-Courage-Wisdom/dp/0956374441?crid=3CMJKC6YIEC11&amp;keywords=The+Swallow%2C+the+Owl+and+the+Sandpiper&amp;qid=1678361745&amp;s=books&amp;sprefix=the+swallow+the+owl+and+the+sandpiper%2Cstripbooks%2C81&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=e42245eff1f340791104ac6bd8d5f2b4&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">The Swallow, the Owl and the Sandpiper</a> would make a wonderful gift for yourself or a loved one going through loss. This book offers comfort and a chance to reflect.
<h2>26. Wild: From Lost to Found on the Pacific Crest Trail by Cheryl Strayed</h2>
A number one New York Times bestseller, and now a film adaptation starring Reese Witherspoon, <a href="https://uk.bookshop.org/books/wild-a-journey-from-lost-to-found/9781782394860">Wild</a> follows Cheryl’s eleven-hundred mile walk along the West Coast of America. Aged 26 and following the loss of her mother from cancer, a crumbling marriage and a family in disarray, she makes an impulsive decision to hike alone in the hope of finding the answers on how to piece her life back together.
<h2>27. Tiny Beautiful Things: Advice on Love and Life from Someone Who’s Been There by Cheryl Strayed</h2>
Following on from her memoir Wild, the former agony aunt offers advice whilst answering a collection of letters from people who were confused, afraid or anxious. Her responses come from an array of personal experience of the good and the bad things in life, often with hilarious and heartbreaking moments mixed in. Creating the perfect guide to those who are struggling or feeling lost, <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Tiny-Beautiful-Things-Advice-Someone/dp/1782390693?_encoding=UTF8&amp;qid=1678361815&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=a893585646cfa0e77ec11201bf7990ee&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Tiny Beautiful Things</a> offers insight, compassion and above all absolute honesty.
<h2>28. When Life is Not Peachy: Real-life lessons in recovery from heartache, grief and tough times by Pip Lincolne</h2>
Written during a tough time in her own life, Pip Lincolne offers a gentle guide for processing and navigating the sad times in life - for those who are struggling themselves or offering support to a loved one.

She gives advice on how to eat and exercise when you don’t feel like it, working through relationships with family and friends, and how to keep yourself going when you’re feeling at your lowest. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/When-Life-Not-Peachy-Real-life/dp/191163237X?crid=302DJXP4BJYXB&amp;keywords=When+Life+is+Not+Peachy&amp;qid=1678361855&amp;s=books&amp;sprefix=when+life+is+not+peachy%2Cstripbooks%2C80&amp;sr=1-1&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=72b2cdb62c609a8a99409de5def985ee&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">When Life is Not Peachy</a>, it’s natural to question everything, but Pip hopes to provide a helping hand and travel the journey with you.
<h2>29. Wife, Widow, Now What?: How I Navigated the Cancer World and How You Can, Too by Rachel Engstrom</h2>
Aged only 28, Rachel’s husband Grayson was diagnosed with leukemia. The diagnosis changed both of their lives, as Rachel became ‘a cancer wife, manager, team cheerleader and expert juggler at life’, supporting her husband through his illness until he died just under three years later. She had to restart her life as a widow, with no guidebook on how to do this.

<a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Wife-Widow-Now-What-Navigated/dp/B08KBV5DBL?&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=9250ff2b6b3ece9121db29815576725a&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Wife, Widow, Now What?</a> follows Rachel’s journey from her social media posts at the time, whilst also providing advice on how to navigate a cancer diagnosis, the treatment process, insurance, money, support for carers and all the emotions one goes through during this time. This book is the first of its kind to be written half as a memoir, and half a self-help book - along with the music she listened to that helped her through this difficult time.
<h2>30. Where are you Lydie? by Emma Poore</h2>
It’s Lydie’s birthday today but she’s not here. In this honest and heartfelt story two brothers go on an emotional journey to find a way to connect with their baby sister. <a href="https://www.emmapoore.co.uk/shop">Where are you Lydie?</a> is a special picture book, sensitively written and illustrated for children between 3 and 7 years old.

It is a facilitative story and guide for young children and their parents to explore death and bereavement together and to start those difficult conversations or explore the questions that may come up after the death of a baby in a safe and inspiring space.
<h2>31. <span id="productTitle" class="a-size-extra-large">Good Mourning: Honest conversations about grief and loss</span></h2>
<span class="a-text-italic">Sally and Imogen met after both losing their mother's suddenly. This led them to launch their podcast <em>Good Mourning</em>, and write this book. <a href="https://www.amazon.co.uk/Good-Mourning-Honest-conversations-about/dp/1922616311?&amp;linkCode=ll1&amp;tag=untanglegrief-21&amp;linkId=c146fa021d34d1ba65b788b71072c811&amp;language=en_GB&amp;ref_=as_li_ss_tl">Good Mourning</a></span> is a compassionate survival guide for anyone dealing with grief, shining a light on the many ways grief can impact our lives. Along with expert advice from a clinical psychologist and warm words and insights from hundreds of others who've experienced grief, this book offers practical tips on coping with isolation and loneliness, navigating grief at work, managing milestones and so much more.

And there you have it - our community's guide to the best books on grief. Let us know in the comments below what your favourite is.

		What to do When Someone Dies - A Complete Guide
		https://untanglegrief.com/what-to-do-when-someone-dies/
		Thu, 11 Nov 2021 16:35:42 +0000
		yasin.mammeri
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=1787
		
		<h1><span style="font-weight: 400;">What to do When Someone Dies</span></h1>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Working out what to do when someone dies can feel overwhelming. There are certain practical tasks that are time-sensitive, but most tasks can wait at least a little while. Knowing what is important to do right away and what you can take off your plate for now, will really help you avoid unnecessary overwhelm. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">In this article I’ll guide you through all of the practical and emotional steps you’ll need to take when a loved one passes with all the resources and information you’ll need. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Rather than trying to get through it all in one go, we recommend taking what you need for now (usually the First Bits to Do and Planning the Funeral sections are all you’ll need to start), and then returning when you’re ready to take on the next set of tasks. </span>
<h2></h2>
<h2>First bits - what to do when someone dies</h2>
<h3><b>Telling work and discussing bereavement leave</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Unfortunately, bereavement leave isn’t a legal requirement for employers in the UK. Most companies do give between 3-5 days paid leave, but this has to be taken from the time of death. If you have a good relationship with your manager and/or you’ve been working at the company for a while, you may be able to request more time off, but this is entirely at your employers discretion. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">There are a number of ways around this restriction:</span>
<ol>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Dependant leave</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Compassionate leave</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Take holiday leave</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Sick leave for mental health  </span></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">*We’re working hard to help change the laws around bereavement leave. Grief doesn’t happen on a timeline, and healing almost never happens in just 5 days.*</span>
<h3><b>How to tell government services</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">To inform government services requires just 2 things:</span>
<ol>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">First, </span><a href="https://www.gov.uk/register-offices"><span style="font-weight: 400;">register the death at the local council register</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> office in the area where the death took place. You’ll be given a unique number for the Tell Us Once service.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Then </span><a href="https://www.gov.uk/after-a-death/organisations-you-need-to-contact-and-tell-us-once"><span style="font-weight: 400;">use Tell Us Once</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, a free government service that allows you to report a death to all other government departments.</span></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">When you use Tell Us Once, the services notified will include:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">DWP pensions and benefits</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Personal tax</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Council tax</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Passport</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Driving licence</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Blue Badge</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Electoral register</span></li>
</ul>
<h3></h3>
<h3><b>A guide on telling others</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you have to tell others about the death of a friend or family member, the way in which you deliver the bad news can make all the difference difference. We’ve outlined the main points below:</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The where’s and when’s:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If possible, break the news face to face. If not possible - because of distance, for instance, pick up the phone and call them.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Make sure your schedule is clear. It’s best not to rush these things.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Choose a safe, comfortable and confidential setting where you won’t be interrupted. </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re calling an elderly or vulnerable person, you might want to call them at a time when there’s going to be someone else with them, so they won’t be on their own afterwards.</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The what’s:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Writing down what you want to get across can really help you make sure you say what you need to say. </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Use simple, clear language. Euphemisms like ‘they’re no longer with us’ can be confusing, especially for those with a different first language to you.   </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Make sure they’re seated as the shock of bad news can cause some people to feel faint.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Start by letting them know you have bad news as this can prepare them for what’s to come.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">As hard and unintuitive as it might be, it’s usually best to avoid easing in. People can tell when something is wrong, so delaying the inevitable only leads to additional stress.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Regardless of the delivery, some people will get confused when receiving such shocking and sad news. They may only b able to process a small amount. In these instances, it’s a good idea to check that they understand what’s happened and encourage them to express their feelings.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">It’s usually best to leave discussions of practical things for a separate conversation. </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Not everyone wants to be held after hearing such news so it’s always best to ask before if they want to be touched. </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you have to leave but the receiver of the bad news becomes very distressed, it’s a good idea to reach out to someone who can support them in your absence.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Visiting or calling lots of people can be emotionally exhausting. If you have a long list of people to call, it’s best to spread it out over a few days or share the calls with someone close. </span></li>
</ul>
<h3></h3>
<h3><b>How to find the will</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">When someone dies, arrangements have to be made to administer their estate. This includes dealing with their house, bank accounts, investments and tax affairs, and ensuring that whatever is left is correctly distributed to those entitled to inherit it.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Many people will </span><a href="https://www.co-oplegalservices.co.uk/making-a-will/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">write a will</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> during their lifetime, which is a legal document setting out how they would like their estate to be distributed after they die. The will firstly appoints an executor, who is the individual with the legal authority to administer the estate. The executor may have to obtain a grant of probate to carry out their duties in full. The will then names beneficiaries and sets out what they should inherit from the estate.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If the deceased didn't leave a will, or if the will cannot be located, then the estate will be distributed in line with inheritance laws called the </span><a href="https://www.co-oplegalservices.co.uk/probate-solicitors/the-rules-of-intestacy-explained/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">rules of intestacy</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. These rules are strict and may not align with the deceased's wishes. This is why it's so important to establish whether there is a will, and to successfully locate it if so.</span>
<ol>
 	<li><b> Search the house</b></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The first place you should look for the will is in your loved one’s home, as it’s a common place for people to store their will. If you know where they kept paperwork, then this would be a sensible place to start. </span>
<ol start="2">
 	<li><b> Ask their solicitor</b></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If the deceased hired a solicitor to write their will, it is possible that they are storing the will on their behalf. If you know which solicitor they used, give them a ring. Otherwise, call all the local solicitors and see if they ever dealth with your loved one.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The executor is entitled to obtain the will from whoever is storing it. You’ll be asked for the death certificate and proof of your identification. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If the solicitor is no longer in business, contact the </span><a href="https://www.sra.org.uk/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Solicitors Regulation Authority</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. This organisation holds records for all currently active and once active solicitors in England and Wales. They’ll have a record of solicitor's practice and will be able to help you find where the will is being stored now.</span>
<ol start="3">
 	<li><b> Ask their bank</b></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Banks occasionally store wills on behalf of individuals. If you are the executor of the estate, you could ask your loved one’s bank if they have a copy of the will. You’ll need the deceased’s death certificate and proof of your identification.</span>
<ol start="4">
 	<li><b> Use a company to do a will search</b></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’ve tried the above 3 strategies to find the will but can’t, there are companies that can carry out searches to locate missing wills on your behalf. These companies will search through will databases that are used by solicitors and will writers all over the country; as well as carrying out a search of the National Wills Register.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Finally, you can also contact the </span><a href="https://www.theprobatedepartment.co.uk/find-the-nearest-probate-registry/the-principal-registry-office-london/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">London Principle Probate Registry</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to ask if they’re storing the will in their wills storage facility.</span>
<h3></h3>
<h3><b>What to do if there is no will</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’ve conducted a thorough search for the will, including searching with any solicitors your loved one dealth with, but are unable to find the original document, the estate will be administered by the next of kin under the assumption that the deceased didn’t leave a will - called intestacy. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re unable to find a will of your loved one or only have a copy will, </span><a href="https://www.co-oplegalservices.co.uk/probate-solicitors/request-a-callback/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">contact a probate specialist</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to get personalised advice.</span>
<h2>Planning the Funeral</h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">When planning a funeral, </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">the first thing to consider is whether you want a religious or non-religious funeral service</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Anyone can legally conduct a funeral or memorial service, although a member of the clergy will usually officiate a religious ceremony, and a civil celebrant will usually officiate a non-religious ceremony (also known as a humanist ceremony).</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The funeral service is followed by either a burial or cremation. Often, the person who has died will have expressed a preference for one or the other when they were alive. If not, you may wish to abide by the religious or cultural beliefs of the deceased.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you have a special place where you would prefer to remember your loved one, that may influence your decision on whether to choose a burial or cremation. With a burial, there is a grave to visit and maintain. After a cremation, the <a href="/scattering-ashes/">ashes</a> are returned to the family for them to keep at home or scatter at a meaningful location.</span>
<h3><b>Who covers the cost of a funeral?</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The estate of the deceased can cover the costs of the funeral. The person responsible for the estate administration (usually named in the Will) will have access to the funds once probate has been completed - a process that can take several months.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">A funeral service is usually held within 2-3 weeks of death in the UK, but there can be some delay if a coroner’s inquest or post-mortem is ordered.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">This can often mean that the cost of the funeral will have to be paid for by the person in charge of the estate and will get paid back when the probate process is complete. Though, often the entire family chips in and in instances where the estate can cover the costs of the funeral, gets reimbursed. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">For more on planning a funeral, </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">check out our complete guide</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>
<h3><b>How to write a Eulogy</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Ultimately, no one can tell you how you </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">should </span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">write your Eulogy nor what it should contain - there is no one size fits all approach to writing a eulogy. The best Eulogies are unique, personal and come from the heart. So instead of telling you </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">what </span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">to write, we’ll just tell you how we like to think about eulogy writing. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">A eulogy is like a greatest hits album: they have a story arc (beginning, middle, and end); and they cover things like accomplishments, personality traits (and quirks), and memorable stories. Just like with greatest hits, it doesn’t always have to be sunshine, lollipops and rainbows - you can explore the harder parts of your history with your loved one. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Maybe they were always late. Or forever forgetting things. Or really loud. Often this authenticity can make a eulogy even more beautiful and heartfelt - and, in some cases, will have the room roaring with the laughter of acknowledgement. Just try to remember that you’re there to honour the deceased, so feel free to explore the aspects of them that weren’t so great, but maybe through the lens of love and respect.    </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Poems, songs or quotes can alos be a great way to encapsulate a feeling about your loved one. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">And a touch we really like, is thanking everyone that’s travelled from all over to be there to honour your loved one.    </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">For a more complete guide on how to write a eulogy, </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/how-to-write-a-eulogy/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">check out this article</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Notify the bank. You can do this by using the Death Notification Service. </span><a href="https://www.deathnotificationservice.co.uk/financial_institutions.ofml"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://www.deathnotificationservice.co.uk/financial_institutions.ofml</span></a>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The Death Notification Service doesn’t cover the following services: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Monzo</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Starling</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Co-op Bank</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Virgin Money</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Yorkshire Building Society</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Metro Bank</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="2"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Skipton Building Society</span></li>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">For information about how to close accounts from these services, please request via the direct support by emailing the Untangle team. </span>

<b>Useful Information</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Depending on your bank, you may be able to do this over the phone, online, by post or in-person at your local branch. As well as freezing the account, the bank will stop sending post addressed to the person who has died. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Even if you are waiting for a ‘grant of representation’ (the legal form that allows you to handle the deceased person’s finances), most banks will still allow you to use funds in the account of the person who has died to cover some immediate expenses related to settling their estate.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you can't find all the deceased's bank, building society or savings accounts, </span><a href="https://www.mylostaccount.org.uk/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">My Lost Account</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> can find out where they held an account, though it can take up to three months to trace.</span>

<h3><b>Notify the Landlord &amp; Other Tenants</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Tell the Landlord or local authority if your loved one rented a property. If the property is being rented under a joint contract, the contract becomes the responsibility of the other tenants and rent is still due so if the other tenants don’t already know it’s important to let them know.</span>
<h3></h3>
<h3><b>Notify Insurance: Home</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Contact your loved one’s home insurance provider with the following information:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your loved one’s name, last address and date of birth</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A certified copy of their death certificate (if you have one at this stage)</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The policy number</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your own proof of identity, for example, a valid driving license or passport</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The insurer should then guide you through the next steps and advise you of any further details or documentation needed.</span>
<h3><b>Notify Insurance: Car</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Contact your loved one’s car insurance provider with the following information:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your loved one’s name, last address and date of birth</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A certified copy of their death certificate (if you have one at this stage)</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The policy number</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The vehicle registration number</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your own proof of identity, for example, a valid driving license or passport</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re a named driver on the car insurance policy, check with the insurers whether you’re still covered. If you are not, you will need to get a new policy in place.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Watch out – most policies terminate on the death of the main policy holder and this will leave the car uninsured. Ideally, the car should be parked in private parking instead of on the road.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The provider should then guide you through the next steps and advise you of any further details or documentation needed.</span>
<h2>Money Management</h2>
<h3><b>Check for bereavement benefits</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you need to report the death to the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP), you can telephone the DWP Bereavement Service. They can deal with all the DWP benefits that were being paid to the person who died and check if you are entitled to any benefits. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">This is a helpful calculator for what benefits you're entitled to in the UK: </span><a href="https://www.moneysavingexpert.com/family/benefits-check/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://www.moneysavingexpert.com/family/benefits-check/</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You may also be able to claim a Bereavement Support Payment from the Government, if your husband, wife or civil partner died on or after 6 April 2017. You’re eligible for this if they paid National Insurance contributions for at least 25 weeks, but you must have been under State Pension age and living in the UK when they died. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">There are two types of bereavement benefit payments:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Bereavement Support Payment (this used to be called Bereavement allowance) which is an ongoing monthly payment</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A one-off Bereavement Payment which is £2,000 tax-free given once</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><b>If Your Partner has Died</b></h3>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You may be entitled to Income Support or Universal Credit from the Government if your earnings are now below a certain level.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If there’s now only one adult living in your property then you are entitled to a 25% discount on your council tax.</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><b>Claiming your loved one’s pension</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Accessing a State Pension should be done within the first 12 months after your loved one’s death. Often state pensions will stop being paid after the person dies, but in some cases a spouse or civil partner can inherit some of the pension.</span>
<ol>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Notify the Pensions Service that your loved one has died. This can be done via the </span><a href="https://www.gov.uk/after-a-death/organisations-you-need-to-contact-and-tell-us-once"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Tell Us Once</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> service that notifies all government organisations, or by calling the Pensions Service helpline on 0800 731 0469.</span></li>
</ol>
<ol>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Assess whether you can claim your loved one’s pension. This can </span><b>only</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> be done by a </span><b>spouse or civil partner</b><span style="font-weight: 400;">. You can contact Gov’s Pension Service to check what you can claim (you may be able to claim extra benefits if you meet the criteria): </span><a href="https://www.gov.uk/contact-pension-service"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://www.gov.uk/contact-pension-service</span></a></li>
</ol>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">What you get/how you claim depends on whether you reached State Pension age before or after 6 April 2016.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">For more on pensions, </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/claiming-pensions-after-a-loss/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">this guide is great</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>
<h3></h3>
<h3><b>Claim Life Insurance</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you don’t know if there is a life insurance policy, check the Will, ask their Solicitor or look at their bank statements. You can also visit </span><a href="https://www.uar.co.uk/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Unclaimed Asset Register</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, a database of thousands of life insurance policies, unclaimed pensions, shares, dividends, dormant savings accounts and lottery winnings. It costs £25 to run a search for a life policy.</span>
<h3><b>Pay Off Debts</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">When someone dies, the executor of the estate, or the administrator if no will has been left, is responsible for paying any outstanding debts from the estate.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If the money and/or assets in the estate won’t pay off all the debts, the debts will be paid in priority order until the money or assets run out. In most circumstances, any remaining debts will be written off. The only exception to this is if you acted as a guarantor or are a co-signatory of the debt.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you're having to deal with a complicated estate, we’d advise seeking the </span><a href="http://solicitors.lawsociety.org.uk/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">advice of a solicitor or probate specialist</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>

<b>Sorting out the debts of someone who has died</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The first step in paying off debts is working out what debts have been left. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You’ll need to check if there is a guarantor for any of these debts. If there is, the guarantor remains responsible for any debt covered by a guarantee if it is not payable by the estate (due to insufficient money/assets).</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Different forms of debt require different methods of payment. So we advise </span><a href="https://www.moneyhelper.org.uk/en/family-and-care/death-and-bereavement/dealing-with-the-debts-of-someone-who-has-died"><span style="font-weight: 400;">checking out this article</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> for a more in-depth look at the different forms of debt and how best to pay them off.</span>

<b>What do I do if I’m struggling to pay off debts after a death?</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re struggling to pay off your partner's debts after they’ve passed away, or if the sudden drop in income makes it difficult to keep up with your own debt payments, it can be hard to know where to turn.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">It’s important to know you don’t need to struggle alone with your debt worries. There are many ways to manage your debts and what will suit you best will depend on the specifics of your circumstances.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">It’s always best to </span><a href="https://www.moneyhelper.org.uk/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">talk things through with an experienced free debt adviser </span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">before you make a decision about what to do.</span>
<h2>Apply for Probate</h2>
<h3><b>What is Probate</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">When someone dies and leaves property, money and possessions (known as their ‘estate’) you need to sort out who gets what. To distribute the estate you need legal authority, which is granted by a document called a 'grant of representation'.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The person who distributes the estate will either be an Executor (if there is a Will) or an Administer (if there is no Will). Once they have applied for the ‘grant of representation’, the Executor will get a 'grant of probate' and the Administrator will get a 'grant of letters of administration’ - this means they are now legally able to sort out the Estate.</span>
<h3></h3>
<h3><b>Help with Probate</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The process of applying for the grant and the document you use to manage the estate is referred to as 'probate’.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">For step by step help </span><a href="https://www.gov.uk/applying-for-probate"><span style="font-weight: 400;">visit the Government website</span></a>

<a href="https://farewill.com/apply-for-probate"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Farewill</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> offer an over the phone probate application service. </span>
<h3><b> Useful things to note</b></h3>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If there's only jointly-owned property and money which passes to a spouse or civil partner you will not need probate. You can get advice from HM Revenue &amp; Customs (HMRC) on whether probate is necessary.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Application fees for probate are £155 if you apply through a solicitor and £215 if you're taking the DIY option. Estates worth less than £5,000 pay no fee.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Probate is the same for everyone in England, Wales and Northern Ireland, but if you live in Scotland it's called 'confirmation'.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">It usually takes between four and eight weeks to get a grant of probate after you've submitted the application</span></li>
</ul>
<h3></h3>
<h3><b>An overview of the Probate Process</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If your loved one had a will you’ll need to apply for a grant of probate.</span>

<strong>The probate process: how long does probate take, and who can do it?</strong>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Obtaining a grant of probate allows you to access your loved one’s assets and distribute them in accordance with their will. The executor of the will should apply for probate within a few months of your loved one’s death, as it may be necessary to access and close certain accounts that your loved one held. The probate process can vary in length, but on average, administration takes 6-9 months.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You don’t need it if:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The person had no assets outside the UK, and</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">All assets were jointly owned (eg. Mr &amp; Mrs Jones’s bank account), </span><b>or</b></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The value of the estate is less than £10,000 – but make sure you check with the financial providers!</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">You are likely to need probate if any of these apply to you:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If your loved one had any assets overseas – this includes property or financial accounts</span></li>
</ul>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If your loved one had financial assets valued at over £10,000 that were not jointly owned e.g stocks, shares, savings</span></li>
</ul>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If the value of your loved one’s estate (everything they owned) is more than £10,000 – this includes property, money and possessions. Each bank has its own threshold to determine whether you need probate to access your loved one’s account with them</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">To find out the thresholds for probate, contact the account provider(s). If you do need to apply for grant of probate, follow the steps in our guide below:</span>

<a href="https://untanglegrief.com/calculating-the-value-of-the-estate-probate/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Step 1 – Estimating the value of the estate</span></a>

<a href="https://untanglegrief.com/do-i-need-to-pay-inheritance-tax-probate/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Step 2 – Do I need to pay Inheritance Tax?</span></a>

<a href="https://untanglegrief.com/applying-for-grant-of-probate/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Step 3 – Applying for probate and next steps</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If your loved one didn’t have a will: You’ll need to apply for a letter of administration</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The probate process is quite complex, so for a more comprehensive guide, </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/wills-and-probate/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">be sure to check out our probate and wills article</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> where we cover each use case in detail. </span>
<h3><b>Estimating the value of the house</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">You need an estimate of the estate’s value to find out if there’s Inheritance Tax to pay.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The estate will not have to pay tax as long as one of the following applies:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">it all passes to the spouse or civil partner of the person who died</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">it all passes to a charity or a community amateur sports club</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">it has a value below the Inheritance Tax threshold of £325,000</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If the person who died was widowed or is giving away their home to their children, </span><a href="https://www.gov.uk/inheritance-tax"><span style="font-weight: 400;">the tax threshold can be higher</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>
<h3></h3>
<h3><b>Do You Need to Pay Inheritance Tax?</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you're the Executor or Administrator, you'll need to sort out any inheritance tax (IHT). If inheritance tax is due, you need to pay some of it before your ‘grant of probate’ can be issued, then in most cases, you've six months to pay it in full. Once you have paid some of the inheritance tax, you are said to have 'obtained probate’. In Scotland, this is known as 'confirmation' and the process is different.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You can find an estimate of your inheritance tax using the Government's free online calculator: </span>

<a href="https://www.gov.uk/inheritance-tax-reduced-rate-calculator"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://www.gov.uk/inheritance-tax-reduced-rate-calculator</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> </span>
<h3><b>Useful Things to Note</b></h3>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Inheritance tax is paid on the estate if it's worth more than £325,000 after debts are settled (and there aren't any other exemptions that need to be applied - see HMRC for more).</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anything above this is taxed at 40%, (which can be reduced to 36% if 10% or more of the post-IHT value of the estate was left to charity)</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">This normally needs to be paid within six months from the end of the month when the person died. You can defer tax and pay in instalments on some types of assets, including land, some shares and the value of any business owned (not the assets).If assets are being transferred to a surviving spouse or civil partner, no inheritance tax will normally be charged. The rules on this are complex, see HMRC for help. This Inheritance Tax guide also has useful info on how the system works.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Most big banks have arrangements to send cash from the deceased's bank account directly to HMRC to cover this.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">See the Scottish Government or NI Direct for more info.</span></li>
</ul>
<h2>Their Belongings</h2>
<h3><b>Handle their social media accounts</b></h3>
<b>Facebook</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A friend or family member connected with the deceased on Facebook</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">What is needed: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Death Certificate (scanned copy)</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Deceased full name on Facebook &amp; their profile url</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Next Step: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Complete this form </span><a href="https://www.facebook.com/help/contact/228813257197480"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://www.facebook.com/help/contact/228813257197480</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">*You can choose to have the account memorialised or deleted</span>

<b>Twitter</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A person authorized to act of behalf of the estate or a verified immediate family member</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">What is needed: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Deceased person's full name on Twitter &amp; Twitter handle</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A copy of your ID</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A copy of the deceased’s death certificate.</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Step 1: </b>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Complete this form </span><a href="https://help.twitter.com/forms/privacy"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://help.twitter.com/forms/privacy</span></a></li>
</ul>
<b>Step 2: </b>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Twitter will email you with the next instructions for providing more details</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Step 3: </b>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You will need to email Twitter with information about the deceased, a copy of your ID, and a copy of the deceased’s death certificate.</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Instagram</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A friend or family member connected with the deceased on Instagram to memorialise the account; or an immediate family member to delete the account</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">What is needed: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Decide whether you want the account to be memorialised or deleted</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The deceased's full name, Instagram username</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Proof of death (e.g. an obituary or news article)</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The date they passed away</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you decide  to delete account you will also need: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Verification that you're an immediate family member e.g. The deceased person's birth certificate, The deceased person's death certificate or Proof of authority under local law that you are the lawful representative of the deceased person, or his/her estate.</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Next Steps: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Complete this form to memorialise the account: </span><a href="https://help.instagram.com/contact/452224988254813"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://help.instagram.com/contact/452224988254813</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Complete this form to request a removal of the deceased person's account: </span><a href="https://help.instagram.com/contact/1474899482730688"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://help.instagram.com/contact/1474899482730688</span></a>

<b>WhatsApp</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anyone with access to their phone</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Next Steps: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anyone with access to their account details</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Next Steps: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">*The account will then be deactivated for 30 days, after which it will be permanently deleted</span>

<b>YouTube</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>

 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">An immediate family member or their legal representative</span></li>
</ul>

<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Death certificate (scanned copy)</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Deceased name, email address</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your details</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Scan of your ID</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Date of death</span></li>
</ul>

<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Visit this link on the Google Support page: </span><a href="https://support.google.com/accounts/troubleshooter/6357590?hl=en"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://support.google.com/accounts/troubleshooter/6357590?hl=en</span></a></li>
</ul>
<b>Step 2: </b>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Select 'close the account of a deceased user'</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Step 3: </b>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Enter their name, email address, details of a relative or legal representative, their date of death and a scan of your ID and their death certificate</span></li>
</ul>
