<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A close friend or family member</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">What is needed: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The deceased member name</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The URL to their LinkedIn profile</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your relationship to them</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Their email address</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The date they passed away</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Their last place of employment </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Link to their obituary or a relevant news article if possible</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Death certificate (scanned copy) - if there is no obituary or a relevant news article</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Note: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">LinkedIn allows a feature in which a person can nominate someone to close their account if they pass away. If you know this is the case, that nominated person will need to get in touch with LinkedIn. If not, a close friend or family member can do so.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Next Step: </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Complete this form to delete the account: </span><a href="https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/ask/ts-rdmlp"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://www.linkedin.com/help/linkedin/ask/ts-rdmlp</span></a>
<h2>What to do with Their Belongings</h2>
<h3><b>Sharing possessions with family</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">You are likely to come across many items that have sentimental value rather than monetary value, and you can discuss who will keep which items with your family members. This process can be a lovely way to hear about each other’s memories with the person who has died, and you’ll often find that items have a different meaning for each person.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you need help deciding how to share out items, everyone in the family can have a pack of stickers and can stick them onto the items they’d like to keep as they go round the house. You can then discuss any overlaps and come to a decision.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">When sharing out items with monetary value, some families allocate an equal ‘allowance’ to each person and place a price or value on each item, which they then ‘bid’ on. This works best when family members get on well and can keep it lighthearted.</span>
<h3></h3>
<h3><b>Donating items to charity</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">After sorting through your loved one’s belongings, you’ll probably have plenty of things you could donate to charity. Choosing a charity that meant something to your loved one can be a nice way to </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/remembering-a-loved-one/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">honour their memory</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Or, you might want to support organisations that helped care for your family member in some way, such as a local hospice or Age UK.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Before taking your donations to the charity shop, find out which items they will or won’t accept. For safety reasons, many charity shops won’t accept electrical goods and will only accept furniture with fire safety labels still attached (If you do have electrical goods, Cancer Research UK is one of the few charities that will take them, but they don’t accept white goods).</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Charities say that they appreciate clothing, accessories, homeware, linen and books, as they sell particularly well. Some charities will come to collect larger items, such as wardrobes and beds.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Another option is to sell items, then donate the money you raise to the charity as a cash donation (they can also claim gift aid if you’re a taxpayer).</span>
<h3></h3>
<h3><b>Tips to Selling Belongings</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">You may have items that are in a good, saleable condition that you decide to sell; this could be anything from large furniture, like wardrobes and dressers, to smaller items like clothing or crockery. eBay and local social media selling sites can be good places to list items for sale. For smaller, less valuable items, you might decide to hold a car boot sale.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Once you have sorted through their possessions, you need to decide what to do with their house. You need to check whether they owned the house outright or if there is an outstanding mortgage to pay to the bank. After this, you might decide to keep their house, to either live in, rent out or sell. We’d recommend taking advice from a solicitor. before making a decision, particularly if family members disagree on the best option.</span>
<h2>Their digital accounts</h2>
<h3><b>Access their email address</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Gaining access to your loved one’s account when they pass can help you identify tasks that might otherwise remain unknown such as accounts to close or subscriptions to end. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Access to their email account will also allow you to reset passwords for accounts so that you can gain access and close them.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Many email account providers only allow you to close a deceased user’s account; submit a request for funds from a deceased person’s account; or obtain data from their account. This means gaining access to an email account is usually prohibited by providers and the laws surrounding access after death are murky. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re happy to follow standard protocol, for gmail accounts </span><a href="https://support.google.com/accounts/troubleshooter/6357590?hl=en"><span style="font-weight: 400;">you’ll need to fill in this form</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">; and for </span><a href="https://uk.help.yahoo.com/kb/options-yahoo-account-owner-passes-sln26120.html"><span style="font-weight: 400;">yahoo accounts head here</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Our recommendation is to contact the provider directly and let them know your circumstances and why you need access to the account. </span>

<b>Yahoo</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Executor of the will</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">What is needed: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Death certificate (copy/scan)</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Yahoo ID of the deceased</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A copy of a document appointing the requesting party as the personal representative or executor of the estate of the deceased</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Copy of the ID of the requesting party</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Next Step: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You can send this information via email or post. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">For contact details, follow this link here where you will need to enter the Yahoo ID of the deceased: </span><a href="https://io.help.yahoo.com/contact/index?page=home&amp;locale=en_GB&amp;y=PROD_ACCT"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://io.help.yahoo.com/contact/index?page=home&amp;locale=en_GB&amp;y=PROD_ACCT</span></a>

<b>Microsoft</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Immediate family member</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">What is needed: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Death certificate (copy/scan)</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Full name, Email address(es), Date of birth</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Country the deceased gave as their home address when signing up</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Estimated year the deceased opened their account</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Estimated time that the account was last accessed – this includes if you think there might have been suspicious activity on the account by another user, or if you have checked the account</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">An email address you’re happy to be contacted on</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Proof of your identification, if you aren’t named in the will – e.g. marriage or birth certificate,</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your shipping address – so that Microsoft can post the DVD to you</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The type of computer you use, if you’d like to request a copy of the account’s contents, i.e. PC or Mac</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Next Step: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Email this information to </span><a href="mailto:msrecord@microsoft.com"><span style="font-weight: 400;">msrecord@microsoft.com</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">*If this is not possible, the account will be deleted a year after inactivity</span>

<b>Gmail</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">An immediate family member or their legal representative</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">What is needed: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Death certificate (copy/scan)</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The deceased name, email address</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Details of a relative or legal representative</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Date of death</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Scan of your ID </span></li>
</ul>
<b>Next Step: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Visit this link on the Google Support page: </span><a href="https://support.google.com/accounts/troubleshooter/6357590?hl=en"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://support.google.com/accounts/troubleshooter/6357590?hl=en</span></a>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Select 'close the account of a deceased user’</span>
<h3><b>Accessing cloud/online storage</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Physical possessions made it fairly easy to know who owns what when someone passes away. However, with so much of our lives now taking place online, more and more of our assets are moving online too.  And this causes quite a bit of complexity in terms of identifying who owns what (you or the company that sold the asset).</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">For example, if your loved one purchased a song through iTunes, what they purchased was the temporary rights to the song. In other words, they don’t actually own it and so it can’t be passed on to you or anyone else. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">On the other hand, stored photos, videos and documents, are owned by the deceased and therefore can be passed on. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The process of gaining access to your loved one’s cloud/online storage requires you to contact the storage provider, usually with at least the following documentation: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Full name of the deceased</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The email address of the deceased</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Full name of the relative or legal representative</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Email of the relative or legal representative</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Address of the deceased</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Date of death</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A copy of a document appointing the requesting party as the personal representative or executor of the estate of the deceased; and</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A copy of the death certificate of the account holder</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><b>Cancelling monthly on-demand subscriptions</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Cancelling online subscriptions following the death of a loved one will avoid any unnecessary charges or fees. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you have access to their email address, cancelling a subscription is as easy as resetting the relevant account password (the company will send a generic password to your loved one’s email address and you can use that to log in). </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you don’t have access to their email address, the quickest way to cancel a subscription is to search for the company’s customer support number and call them up. </span><a href="https://www.cpjfield.co.uk/planning-a-funeral/after-the-funeral/cancelling-leisure-entertainment-accounts-after-death"><span style="font-weight: 400;">This article provides a helpful list of the most popular leisure and shopping accounts</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> (Amazon, PayPal, Ebay, Spotify, Netflix etc.) and the relevant links and/or numbers that’ll get you access the accounts. </span>

<b>Netflix</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anyone</span></li>
</ul>
<b>If you have access to the account: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Go to </span><a href="https://www.netflix.com/CancelPlan"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://www.netflix.com/CancelPlan</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and click cancel, then sign out of all devices</span>

<b>If you don't have access to the account: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Gather the following: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Email address and/or phone number associated with the Netflix account</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Full payment information currently used to pay for the Netflix service.</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Contact:</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Call 0800 096 6379 or use the live chat service </span><a href="https://help.netflix.com/en/contactus"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://help.netflix.com/en/contactus</span></a>

<b>Amazon Prime</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anyone with the executor's details</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">What is needed: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The customer's name, address, email address and login details if known</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Death certificate (copy)</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Next Step: </b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Email </span><a href="mailto:bereavement-support@amazon.co.uk"><span style="font-weight: 400;">bereavement-support@amazon.co.uk</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and attach the copy of the death certificate</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;"> </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">*If you have an Amazon.co.uk account and would like any gift certificates to be transferred to your account, please provide the email address and last purchase associated with your Amazon.co.uk account. We may need to verify that you are entitled to the gift certificates, so if you are not mentioned in the death certificate please provide some proof of your relationship with your lost loved one.</span>

<b>Spotify</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anyone </span></li>
</ul>
<b>Contact: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Customer services </span><a href="https://support.spotify.com/uk/contact-spotify-support/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://support.spotify.com/uk/contact-spotify-support/</span></a>

<b>Now TV</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anyone with the executor's details</span></li>
</ul>
<b>Contact: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">0333 2020 912</span>

<b>Apple Music</b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Who can do this?</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anyone </span></li>
</ul>
<b>Next Step: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The best way to stop subscriptions is to contact your bank and remove any direct debits</span>

<b>Account disable: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">The account can be disabled if you have access to their password, if so you can do this via account settings or via webchat with Apple support </span>

<a href="https://getsupport.apple.com/?locale=en_GB&amp;PGF=PGF63005"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://getsupport.apple.com/?locale=en_GB&amp;PGF=PGF63005</span></a>

<b>To request access to their information e.g. photos: </b>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Follow these steps -</span>

<a href="https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT208510"><span style="font-weight: 400;">https://support.apple.com/en-us/HT208510</span></a>
<h2></h2>
<h2>Conclusion  <span style="font-weight: 400;">   </span></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Figuring out what to do when someone dies is complicated and for most of us, a new and overwhelming experience. Having to get through all the practical tasks while processing all these new and challenging emotions can be extremely challenging. Untangle Grief provides free grief support, an understanding community, and access to expert advice so that navigating grief is a bit more manageable and a whole lot less lonely. <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/sign-up/">Sign up here for access to all our free support.</a></span>

		How To Face The New Year When You’re Grieving
		https://untanglegrief.com/how-to-face-the-new-year-when-youre-grieving/
		Fri, 24 Dec 2021 11:26:47 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=2436
		
		<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you lost someone you loved in 2021, our condolences. We at Untangle know how hard this is. Feelings, especially in that first year, can prove very mixed: Sad that they’re gone, lonely in your grief, angry at the world for carrying on and sometimes, relieved that they’re no longer suffering. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Whilst grief isn’t linear and whilst these feelings don’t necessarily lessen, you will adjust and learn to live alongside them. </span>
<h2></h2>
<h2>Changing times</h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The New Year can bring to grievers a sense of trepidation. For the first time, you won’t be able to say that you lost someone this year. Suddenly, you lost them ‘last year’ and you become acutely aware that they won’t ever know 2022. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">“It’s okay to lean into that feeling and to recognise that you have lost something significant within these last 12 months,” says Clinical Psychologist Dr Marianne Trent of </span><a href="https://www.goodthinkingpsychology.co.uk/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Good Thinking Psychological Services</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. “It’s totally normal that it might feel hard to fathom a year that your loved one will never know.”</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You may also worry that friends and family might not check in as often, and in the team’s experience, many of them won’t. People, especially those lucky enough not to have experienced close loss, won’t know how important that is. But some will keep checking in, and they will prove a Godsend. Take the matter into your own hands and ask people to check in. Your loved ones will want to do what’s right by you, so find a time to air these anxieties with them. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">“If you can, open up to other people you know who have been through similar experiences to you,” says Behavioural Psychologist Jo Hemmings. “According to research by Recognised, 48% of us feel less alone when we hear people share the same struggles we face. But if you’re the first of your friends going through this, don’t be afraid to speak to them as well.”</span>

&nbsp;
<h2>Don't suffer alone</h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The same research showed that 47% of Brits said that they suffered in silence (with an issue of their feelings) in the last 18 months because they didn’t want to burden others but 41% believe that the pandemic has made them more able to empathise and put themselves in other people’s shoes. “So you might be surprised at how much they understand or can recognise how you’re feeling,” Hemmings says. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">And don’t </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/the-myth-of-stages-of-grief/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">concern yourself with ‘timelines</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">’ either. Grief doesn’t have an expiry date. “It’s okay to still be moved by your grief and not to be too concerned whether people think you should be ‘over it by now’ because it happened last year,” Dr Trent explains. Grief comes in waves, sometimes you will feel fine, and sometimes you won’t. </span>

&nbsp;
<h2>Complicated feelings</h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Guilt can also be a common feeling at this time of year. “It’s really common that people report that they feel guilty about getting to carry on,” Dr Trent continues, but it’s okay to feel okay right now. “We don’t deserve to suffer and it is absolutely fine for you to turn your face towards the sun again and enjoy the warmth it has to offer.”</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">You can go further than that too. Why not use this time of year to take extra good care of yourself? It’s a lovely way to honour your loved one and what they would have wanted. “</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Make sure you’re making time for self care and exercise,” says Jo Hemmings. “Maybe go for a cycle, brisk walk or have a workout? Or go online and offer your empathy and support to others who may be grieving and alone.” The </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/news-feed/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Untangle Forum</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/chats"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Chats</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> spaces are the perfect place to start. </span>

&nbsp;
<h2>Marking time mindfully</h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">And if you’re feeling ready to end a year in which you’ve known such pain and face the new year head on, </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/remembering-a-loved-one/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">acknowledging this time in a mindful way</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> can prove healing. “Some people find it helpful to mark the passing of someone they loved with something which will continue to grow, such as a plant or tree,” says Dr Trent. “It can give a mindful focus for loving and tending and allow us to assimilate the time since loss with growth.”</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Or, make 2022 the year when you learn to live with your loss. Finding the perfect therapist can take time, but therapy can help you to understand and process your feelings. Untangle can match you with the perfect grief therapist </span><a href="https://untangleonline.typeform.com/to/mU2OH38O"><span style="font-weight: 400;">using one quick questionnaire</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">However, if you’re in crisis right now, get help straight away. Dr Trent says: “If you are concerned about your wellbeing, ability to function, the number of mounting problems and your risk level it’s really important that you reach out for support via your Doctor, mental health team or an accredited therapy service.”</span>

&nbsp;
<h2>Here for others</h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">And finally, if you’re here because you’re trying to help someone who is grieving, firstly kudos for signing up to Untangle. You’re already trying to educate yourself on grief and are working hard to make them feel a little less alone. But it can be a lot simpler than that. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">“It’s easy to get swept up in the business of our everyday lives but if you have friends of family members you know are going through a hard time, take a moment to check in with them,” Jo Hemmings says. “According to research by Recognised, what makes Brits feel the most valued and appreciated is the simple act of someone checking in to see if they are okay. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">“Small gestures of kindness or compassion, like sending a quick text or giving someone a call, can often have a more positive impact on our well-being, than grand or expensive gestures. It shows us that people are considering our feelings as well as understanding them, which in turn immediately boosts our levels of oxytocin and serotonin - hormones which can help us feel calmer and happier - while reducing our stress hormone, cortisol.“</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">However you choose to see in the New Year, we hope the above advice helps you to realise that you’re not alone in facing a new chapter of your life. </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/sign-up/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Join our free community</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to speak to others in the same position and know you’re not alone on New Year’s Eve.</span>

<b> </b>

<b>Dr Marianne Trent is a Clinical Psychologist with Good Thinking Psychological Services and author of The Grief Collective. </b>

<b>Jo Hemmings has been working with social impact jewellery brand, Recognised. Together they have released a report on how the nation is feeling in the run up to Christmas and how recognition could be the key to our mental wellbeing. Find out more at </b><a href="https://recognisedstore.com/pages/recognition"><b>www.recognisedstore.com/recognition</b></a><b> </b>

		The 35 Greatest Grief Quotes: Healing Through Wisdom
		https://untanglegrief.com/the-35-greatest-grief-quotes/
		Mon, 17 Jan 2022 16:49:18 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=2684
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946">To meet others who share a similar experience of loss, including access to over 25+ support spaces, <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">download the Untangle app</a>. <br>We’re all in this terrible club together.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The late bell hooks knew that where there is grief, there is powerful, enduring love. “In its deepest sense,” she wrote, “grief is a burning of the heart, an intense heat that gives us solace and release.” Whether you have lost someone yourself or are comforting another who has lost a loved one, it can feel like there is nothing that can be said to make it better. But as exemplified by bell hooks, the greatest grief quotes provide comfort by sharing an experience of this pain. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Collected from the work of historic writers, poets, and songwriters, the following quotes incorporate a number of perspectives to guide through feelings of grief and loss. They stand apart from the rest— offering wisdom about living with their memory, absence, and the grieving process itself.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Find the words you need in our collection of the greatest quotes about grief and healing below. </span></p>
<h3><b>Quotes about grief and memories:</b></h3>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">1. “Everyone must leave something behind when he dies, my grandfather said. A child or a book or a painting or a house or a wall built </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">or</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> a pair of shoes made. Or a garden planted. Something your hand touches some way so your soul has somewhere to go when you die, and when people look at that tree or that flower you planted, you’re there.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Ray Bradbury, </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Fahrenheit 451</span></i></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">2. “If there ever comes a day where we can’t be together, keep me in your heart. I’ll stay there forever.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— A.A. Milne, </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Winnie the Pooh</span></i></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">3. “I’ll be seeing you</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In all the old familiar places</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">That this heart of mine embraces</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">All day through.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Billie Holiday, “I’ll Be Seeing You”</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">4. “So when you need her touch</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">And loving gaze</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Gone but not forgotten</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Is the perfect phrase</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Smiling from a star</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">That she makes glow</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Trust she’s always there</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Watching as you grow</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Find her in the place</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Where the lost things go.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Mary Poppin Returns. “The Place Where Lost Things Go”</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">5. “The song is ended, but the melody lingers on.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Irving Berlin</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">6. "We do not have to rely on memories to recapture the spirit of those we have loved and lost – they live within our souls in some perfect sanctuary which even death cannot destroy."</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Nan Witcomb</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">7. “Simply touching a difficult memory with some slight willingness to heal begins to soften the holding and tension around it.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">― Stephen Levine</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">8. “A great soul serves everyone all the time. A great soul never dies. It brings us together again and again.” </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Maya Angelou</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">9. “You will lose someone you can’t live without, and your heart will be badly broken, and the bad news is that you never completely get over the loss of your beloved. But this is also the good news. They live forever in your broken heart that doesn’t seal back up. And you come through. It’s like having a broken leg that never heals perfectly—that still hurts when the weather gets cold, but you learn to dance with the limp.” </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Anne Lamott</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">10. “Your memory feels like home to me. So whenever my mind wanders, it always finds its way back to you.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Ranata Suzuki</span></p>
</blockquote>
<h3><b>Quotes about loss:</b></h3>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">11. “One more day</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">One more time</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">One more sunset, maybe I’d be satisfied</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">But then again</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">I know what it would do</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Leave me wishing still, for one more day with you.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Diamond Rio</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">12. “Sometimes, only one person is missing, and the whole world seems depopulated.” </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Alphonse de Lamartine, Méditations Poétiques</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">13. "When someone you love dies, and you're not expecting it, you don't lose her all at once; you lose her in pieces over a long time - the way the mail stops coming, and her scent fades from the pillows and even from the clothes in her closet and drawers. Gradually, you accumulate the parts of her that are gone. Just when the day comes - when there's a particular missing part that overwhelms you with the feeling that she's gone, forever - there comes another day, and another specifically missing part."</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— John Irving</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">14. “The bird is gone, and in what meadow does it now sing?”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">― Philip K. Dick</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">15. "The melody that the loved one played upon the piano of your life will never be played quite that way again, but we must not close the keyboard and allow the instrument to gather dust. We must seek out other artists of the spirit, new friends who gradually will help us to find the road to life again, who will walk the road with us."</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Joshua Loth Liebman</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">16. “Never. We never lose our loved ones. They accompany us; they don’t disappear from our lives. We are merely in different rooms.” </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Paulo Coelho</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">17. “I should know enough about loss to realize that you never really stop missing someone-you just learn to live around the huge gaping hole of their absence.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Alyson Noel</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">18. “For as long as the world spins and the earth is green with new wood, she will lie in this box and not in my arms.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">― Lurlene McDaniel</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">19. “When I saw your strand of hair I knew that grief is love turned into an eternal missing.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">― Rosamund Lupton</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">20. “Without you in my arms, I feel an emptiness in my soul. I find myself searching the crowds for your face—I know it’s an impossibility, but I cannot help myself.” </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">– Nicholas Sparks</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">21. “What they never tell you about grief is that missing someone is the simple part.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">― Gail Caldwell</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">22. “Absence is a house so vast that inside you will pass through its walls and hang pictures on the air.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Pablo Neruda</span></p>
</blockquote>
<h3><b>Quotes about grief:</b></h3>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">23. “The deeper that sorrow carves into your being, the more joy you can contain.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Khalil Gibran</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">24. “Look closely and you will see almost everyone carrying bags of cement on their shoulders. That’s why it takes courage to get out of bed in the morning and climb into the day.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Edward Hirsch</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">25. “No one ever told me that grief felt so like fear. I am not afraid, but the sensation is like being afraid. The same fluttering in the stomach, the same restlessness, the yawning. I keep on swallowing.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">At other times it feels like being mildly drunk, or concussed. There is a sort of invisible blanket between the world and me. I find it hard to take in what anyone says. Or perhaps, hard to want to take it in. It is so uninteresting. Yet I want the others to be about me. I dread the moments when the house is empty. If only they would talk to one another and not to me.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">― C.S. Lewis,</span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> A Grief Observed</span></i></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">26. "The risk of love is loss, and the price of loss is grief - But the pain of grief is only a shadow when compared with the pain of never risking love."</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Hillary Stanton Zunin</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">27. “And once the storm is over you won’t remember you how made it through, how you managed to survive. You won’t even be sure, in fact, whether the storm is really over. But one thing is certain. When you come out of the storm you won’t be the same person who walked in. That’s what the storm’s all about.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Haruki Murakami, </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Kafka on the Shore</span></i></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">28. “The whole world can become the enemy when you lose what you love.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Kristina McMorris, </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Bridge of Scarlett Leaves</span></i></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">29. “But there was no need to be ashamed of tears, for tears bore witness that a man had the greatest of courage, the courage to suffer.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Viktor E. Frankl, </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">Man’s Search for Meaning</span></i></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">30. “Your grief path is yours alone, and no one else can walk it, and no one else can understand it.” </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Terri Irwin</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">31. "There is a sacredness in tears. They are not the mark of weakness, but of power. They speak more eloquently than ten thousand tongues. They are the messengers of overwhelming grief, of deep contrition, and of unspeakable love." </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Washington Irving</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">32. “Grief is like the ocean; it comes on waves ebbing and flowing. Sometimes the water is calm, and sometimes it is overwhelming. All we can do is learn to swim.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Vicki Harrison</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">33. “And when great souls die, after a period peace blooms, slowly and always irregularly. Spaces fill with a kind of soothing electric vibration. Our senses, restored, never to be the same, whisper to us. They existed. They existed. We can be. Be and be better. For they existed.” </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Maya Angelou</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">34. “Deep grief sometimes is almost like a specific location, a coordinate on a map of time. When you are standing in that forest of sorrow, you cannot imagine that you could ever find your way to a better place. But if someone can assure you that they themselves have stood in that same place, and now have moved on, sometimes this will bring hope.” </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Elizabeth Gilbert</span></p>
</blockquote>
<blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">35. “Grief can be the garden of compassion. If you keep your heart open through everything, your pain can become your greatest ally in your life’s search for love and wisdom.”</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">— Rumi</span></p>
</blockquote>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">That rounds out our collection of 35 quotes about grief and healing. We hope that some of the quotes on this list can provide comfort or clarity for you and yours, or to send to anyone grieving. Whose words have you resonated with when processing a loss? And for free grief support,<a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa"> click here</a>.</span></p>

			Bereavement Cards | Untangle Grief
			
			https://untanglegrief.com/bereavement-cards/

		Losing both your parents in adulthood: What it actually means to become an ‘adult orphan’
		https://untanglegrief.com/losing-both-your-parents-in-adulthood-adult-orphan/
		Thu, 03 Feb 2022 17:02:36 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=2868
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946">To meet others who share a similar experience of loss, as well as access to our parent loss support group, <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">join the Untangle app</a>. <br>We’re all in this terrible club together.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Losing both of your parents,</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> no matter what age you are, can be painful and scary. You may find that your family structure has suddenly changed and the people you’ve depended on for years aren't there any more to support you. It can be exposing, vulnerable and lonely.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’ve heard terms like </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">‘adult orphan’</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">‘double parental bereavement’</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> or</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> ‘double parental loss</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">’ being used to describe your situation, you may be wondering what this all actually means. ‘</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">Adult orphan’ </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">is not a term we usually like to use at Untangle, but we understand that you may have some questions around it. So we’ve put together a guide to help make things a little easier and less confusing. In this guide we’ll look into answering important questions like:</span></p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Can an adult be an orphan?</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">What does</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> orphan syndrome in adults</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> look like?</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">What does becoming an orphan in your 20s, 40s, 50s and beyond feel like?</span></li>
</ul>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our work at Untangle means that we’ve seen up close how there’s no universal way to experience grief. Going through something as defining and unique as losing both of your parents can be a very lonely thing to experience. You may have a partner, children or you may be surrounded by friends and family, but when both of your parents die, it’s very normal to feel a sudden and strong sense of loneliness.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Don’t forget, you’re not alone. In this guide we’ve added in a few ways to help you manage your grief and get through the hardest days, but if you’re looking to talk to people who are going through similar experiences, <a href="https://join.untanglegrief.com/">join our community here</a>.</span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Can an adult be an orphan?</span></h3>
<p><b>Y</b><b>es. An adult can be an orphan.</b></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">When you think of an orphan, you’ll probably be thinking of someone under the age of 18 who has </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">lost both of their parents</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">. An adult, with real-life responsibilities like paying bills or having a full-time job or even having kids of their own, may not be the first image that comes to mind. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">In Emily Dean’s article</span><a href="https://graziadaily.co.uk/life/real-life/adult-orphan-1/"><span style="font-weight: 400;"> ‘Things you only know if you’re an adult orphan’ </span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">she talks about how the word ‘orphan’  just feels strange when it’s used by an adult. As she says, “Orphans have tight, red 1970s perms and kindly wealthy benefactors. They don’t have mortgages and powerful anti-ageing creams”.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">While the textbook definition of an orphan is a child who has</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> lost both parents</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">, adults can be considered orphans too. The word orphan has expanded broadly over time, so it can be used to describe anyone who has lost their biological parents.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">The term </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">‘adult orphan’</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> is commonly used to describe someone who has </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">lost both parents in adulthood</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">What is </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">orphan syndrome</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">?</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Orphan syndrome </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">is a psychological condition that can come from losing one or both parents. It’s not always caused by something physical, like your mum or dad (or both parents) dying, it can also be caused by an emotional loss of parents that comes through neglect or abandonment.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Orphan syndrome</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> is sometimes known as ‘abandoned child syndrome’ when it’s seen in children. </span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">What does </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">orphan syndrome</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> in adults look like?</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Orphan syndrome</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> in adults is a type of anxiety. It can look different for everyone and it comes in many shapes and sizes. There’s no one-size-fits-all way to experience grief; grief can turn your world upside down, and it can impact our lives in very different ways.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Here are a few common signs of </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">orphan syndrome</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> in both adults and children:</span></p>
<ul>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">A fear of being abandoned</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anxiety or panic when a friend or family member leaves for a period of time</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Fear of being alone</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Low self-esteem</span></li>
</ul>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">People experiencing grief that’s caused by </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">double parental loss</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">, sometimes talk about something called ‘grief brain’. ‘Grief brain’ is what happens to your brain when you’re overloaded with feelings like sadness, loneliness and grief. It can affect your memory and concentration and lead to sleeping difficulties, anxiety and even migraines.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">It’s normal to feel overwhelmed and lonely after losing both of your parents. If you’re looking for support to help you through it, or to connect with people experiencing something similar, you can <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">join our wonderful and supportive community here</a>. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> </span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">What does </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">becoming an orphan in your 20s</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">40s</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">50s</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and beyond feel like?</span></h3>
<p><b>It can make you question your identity</b></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Experiencing the loss of one parent is incredibly painful no matter what age you are, but going through </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">double parental loss</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> as an adult can bring on entirely new feelings of grief. Some people say that it causes a sudden questioning of your identity and your own mortality.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Caron Kemp lost both of her parents by the time she was 36. In </span><a href="https://www.cosmopolitan.com/uk/reports/a33623630/losing-parents/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">an article written for Cosmopolitan</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, Caron describes the impact that losing both parents and becoming an </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">‘adult orphan’ </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">had on her sense of identity. </span></p>
<p><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">“I lost my identity as someone’s daughter, I lost the family and friends only connected to me through them, and I lost anything standing in the pecking order between me and my own demise”.</span></i></p>
<p><b>It can bring up old, buried feelings of grief</b></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Losing both parents as an adult</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> can also trigger feelings of grief you thought were behind you, and this can sometimes be latent grief for the first parent you lost. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">It’s a very human reaction to keep yourself busy after experiencing a significant loss, like the</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> death of a parent</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">. People often find that there’s so much going on and plenty of welcome distractions at first. <a href="/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/">Organising the funeral</a>, notifying friends and family, sorting out their estate and will. The list goes on.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">But once the dust settles, you may find you have more time to think about what’s happened, and that’s when we often see the grief start to sink in. It’s at this point that we see </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">the loss of a second parent</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> uncover feelings of grief for the</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> loss of the first parent</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">. These are often feelings that people may have thought they’d put behind them.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re grieving the loss of one or both parents, you can chat to our team of experts for advice and grief support by <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">joining our community here</a>. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> </span></p>
<p><b>It can make you feel lonely and that’s very normal</b></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our work at Untangle has shown us how people who have lost one parent often find support in others who have been through something similar. But people who have </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">lost both parents</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> can often feel very lonely and isolated.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Double parental loss </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">changes your familial status, and this can be particularly isolating if you find yourself as an</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> ‘adult orphan</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">’ early in your adult life. </span></p>
<p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2019/feb/02/you-will-behave-weirdly-what-i-learned-from-becoming-an-orphan-at-25"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Joel Golby</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> wrote for the Guardian of his experience</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> becoming an orphaned adult in his 20s</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">, saying </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">“instances of grief, I have found, are unique, two never coming in the same shape. There is no one single catch-all solution.”</span></i></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">There’s often an assumption that once you've dealt with grief once, you'll know how it feels and understand how it works. You'll have a list of tools and strategies and a support system to rely on. But each time you experience grief can actually feel very different from the other experiences you have. </span></p>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">How to cope with the </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">loss of both parents</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">?</span></h3>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Coping with the </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">loss of both parents</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> is an incredibly difficult thing to go through. There’s no magic fix to help get rid of the pain and sadness that can come from being </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">an orphaned adult. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">For some people, the grief of </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">losing both parents</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> comes as a shock. For others, it’s a slow and overwhelming realisation that things have changed.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">“The loss of a second parent can mean the loss of the home you grew up in. It could mean the loss of rituals that have lasted a lifetime, the loss of habits and practises that have lasted for decades,” said Bella DePaulo, a social science researcher at the University of California at Santa Barbara who has written about the resulting loss when parents die.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We’ve put together a few ways to help you cope with </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">double parental loss</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> - it won’t take away the grief, but it’ll hopefully make things a bit easier.</span></p>
<p><b>Make time for your grief - your grief matters</b></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Try not to dismiss your feelings or minimise your loss by telling yourself that your parents ‘had a good run’ or ‘it was their time to go’. These are often things we tell ourselves (or others) to help make death seem like a natural part of life. And while it may be true, sometimes saying things like this can undermine our very real feelings. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Make time for your grief, </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">whether you’ve lost your parents in your 20s or 60s</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">. There’s a lot to take in and it’ll take some time for you to adapt.</span></p>
<p><b>Find ways to stay connected to your parents and to celebrate their lives</b></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">We’ve seen members of our community stay bonded to their parents through doing small things like supporting their parent’s favourite charity, making their favourite meal once a week, or visiting their favourite restaurant. </span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Take time to listen to the music they loved, put up photographs of your parents around your house, bake a cake to celebrate their birthday and don’t be afraid to talk to family and friends about what they were like. Don’t forget, your loved ones want to support you through this grief, and you won’t be burdening them by opening up.</span></p>
<p><b>Be kind to yourself</b></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Grief can manifest itself in physical and emotional ways; taking time to connect with both your body and what’s going on in your mind, is important. Try to move every day - whether it’s a walk, yoga, a run or even dancing in your room with the curtains closed. Practise self-compassion and kindness and celebrate the small wins in life.</span></p>
<p><b>Find a community that understands what you’re going through</b></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">No matter how hard your friends and family try to support you, </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">becoming an orphan in adulthood</span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> is something that’s incredibly hard to explain to people who haven’t experienced it themselves. Find a community of people who have gone through this too, so you can turn to them for support when you need it. Reach out to people you know from your friendship group or work who have recently </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">lost a second parent</span><span style="font-weight: 400;">, meet them for coffee and talk to them about how you feel.</span></p>
<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">There are also safe spaces on Instagram, like </span><a href="https://www.instagram.com/orphan_ish/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Orphan_ish</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and <a href="https://www.instagram.com/untanglegrief/">our own page</a>, which both aim to normalise conversations around grief and loss. </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">And of course, there’s our wonderful and supportive <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Untangle community where you can chat with people going through similar experiences and reach out for expert help. </a></span><span style="font-weight: 400;"> </span></p>

		Bereavement cards
		https://untanglegrief.com/bereavement-cards/
		Wed, 23 Feb 2022 11:01:53 +0000
		emma.harvey
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=3070
		
		<span style="font-weight: 400;">Bereavement cards, also known as sympathy cards, can mark the death of a family member, friend or pet. A bereavement card is a nice way to show someone you’re thinking about them after a loss.</span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Bereavement cards are typically sent immediately following a loss, but you could also send one to mark a poignant occasion. For example, you might wish to acknowledge an anniversary or send a special first Christmas card after bereavement. You could even make a note in your diary to remind you every year.</span>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">What makes a good bereavement card?</span></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">A good bereavement card comes from the heart and is written with the recipient in mind. </span>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our tips:</span></h2>
<b>Be authentic.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Speak from the heart to reflect your relationship with the person receiving the card and their loved one who has died.</span>

<b>Acknowledge their pain.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> It’s ok to acknowledge the pain of loss and let the bereaved person express their pain. Don’t encourage them to ‘keep their chin up’ or ‘stay positive’.</span>

<b>Don’t compare your own loss.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> In most instances, it’s unhelpful to focus on yourself by talking about your own loss when someone is recently bereaved. However, there might be an exception if it's highly relevant, for example, if you’ve both had a loss under the same unusual circumstances.</span>

<b>Be specific with offers for help.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Although you might mean it when you say, “Let me know if I can help”, it leaves the responsibility on the bereaved person to reach out. Instead, try offering something specific, for example, “I can get your groceries and leave them on the doorstep”.</span>

&nbsp;
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">What should you write in a bereavement card?</span></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">It can be hard to know what to write in a bereavement card, and many people worry about saying the wrong thing. Remember that the person for whom you’re buying the card is likely to simply appreciate the kind gesture. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">There is no right or wrong way to send a message of condolence, and nothing anyone can write in a card will take away the pain of loss. However, some thoughtful, kind words can go a long way in helping someone find comfort in their grief.</span>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">Examples</span></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Here are a few examples of good sympathy messages you could include in your bereavement card.</span>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">A short, simple message to acknowledge their grief.</span></h3>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">I’m sorry for your loss.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Sending love at this difficult time.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Our sincere condolences for your loss.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">I’m sorry to hear about the passing of your loved one.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">My heart goes out to you.</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Offering practical or emotional support can help a recently bereaved person feel less alone.</span></h3>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">I’m here for you.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">I know nothing I can say will take away your pain, but I’m here if you need a shoulder to cry on.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">We’d love to contribute to the funeral arrangements; please let us know what needs organising.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you need help with the children, we’d love to have them, to give you some space.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you feel up to visitors, I’d love to come round and help with anything you need, even if just to talk and cry together.</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Religious messages</span></h3>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">I’m so sorry for your loss; you will meet again in Heaven one day.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">My prayers are with you at this difficult time.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">“Blessed are those who mourn, for they will be comforted”. Matthew 5:4.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">“And he said to him, “Truly, I say to you, today you will be with me in Paradise.” Luke 23:43.</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">For more tips and suggestions on observing religious and cultural norms around death and dying, see our article: </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/grieving-across-different-cultures/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">What to say to people grieving across different cultures</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">.</span>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Personalised message</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Don’t be afraid to talk about special memories you have with the person who has died. It can be very comforting for the people left behind to hear stories about their loved one’s life.</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">I am saddened to hear the news of X’s passing. I remember the day we first met when he told one of his corny jokes, and I knew we’d be firm friends! He’ll be greatly missed.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Please accept our condolences at X’s passing. She talked about you and the children all the time at band practice. Do you remember when she made the band learn your wedding song so we could play it at your anniversary party? She wanted that day to be so special. </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You might find a meaningful quote that would resonate with the recipient. See </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/the-35-greatest-grief-quotes/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">The 35 Greatest Grief Quotes</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> for ideas.</span></li>
</ul>
<h2><span style="font-weight: 400;">Where to find bereavement cards</span></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">There are plenty of great places to find bereavement cards in the UK. Before you start looking, think about the style of the card that might suit that person. Perhaps they have a strong faith and would get comfort from a religious card, or would appreciate you acknowledging the passing of their beloved pet with a dog bereavement card.</span>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">On the high street</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Some people like to see and feel bereavement cards before making a choice. Many well established high street chains specialise in greetings cards, including </span><a href="https://www.hallmark.co.uk/l/sympathy-cards/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Hallmark</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://www.clintonsretail.com/cards/other-greetings/sympathy-and-loss"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Clinton Cards</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><a href="https://www.cardfactory.co.uk/cards/occasion-cards/sympathy-cards/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Card Factory</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Many of these stores can be found in your local town or city and feature a range of bereavement cards at different prices.</span>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Supermarkets and convenience stores </span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Most supermarkets and convenience stores carry a line of greetings cards, although the selection of bereavement cards may be limited in smaller shops.</span>
<h3><span style="font-weight: 400;">Online greetings cards suppliers</span></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Online greetings cards stores include </span><a href="https://www.moonpig.com/uk/personalised-cards/sympathy/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Moonpig</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, </span><a href="https://www.thortful.com/cards/sympathy"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Thortful</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> and </span><a href="https://www.funkypigeon.com/cards/sympathy-cards"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Funky Pigeon</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. There are a few notable benefits to choosing and buying a bereavement card online. </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Many online greetings cards stores will print a short condolence message of your choice and post the card directly to the recipient.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Online stores often have a more extensive range of bereavements cards than high street shops.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">You can personalise your card, perhaps with a treasured photograph or meaningful quote to make it extra special.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Some online stores also sell condolence gifts to purchase alongside your bereavement card, for example, keepsakes, flowers or a book (see our </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/the-30-best-books-on-grief/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">30 Best Books on Grief</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> for ideas).</span></li>
</ul>
