		How long does grief last?
		https://untanglegrief.com/how-long-does-grief-last/
		Wed, 23 Feb 2022 11:49:25 +0000
		emma.harvey
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=3073
		
		<span style="font-weight: 400;">‘How long does grief last?’ It’s a question we often hear in the early days of a bereavement, when the future feels uncertain and you’re not sure what to expect from the journey ahead. Here, we talk about the importance of not setting timelines as you go through your grief, and why everyone’s experience is unique.  </span>
<h2><b>So, how long does grief last?</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The truth is, it’s different for everyone. There is no timeline for grief and, unfortunately, it doesn’t have an expiry date. It simply takes as long as it takes. What’s important is that you give yourself time to experience loss in your own way, without setting expectations or timelines, or feeling frustrated that it’s taking longer than you hoped. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Every loss is different, and how you process your grief is unique to you. That’s why, while some may start to feel better within weeks, others could find it takes months or years. Many of us at Untangle have come to realise that our grief will never fully go away, but that our day-to-day lives have become more manageable as time has gone on. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">It reminds us of Lois Tonkin’s theory that grief stays with us, but our life grows around that loss. It’s always there and it’s always the same size, but slowly you rebuild your world around it. How that grief presents itself can change, too. While, in the early days, it might be a very physical experience, later on it might be more emotional, but without the brain fog or exhaustion you felt at first. Usually, these feelings come in waves that hit stronger on some days, and gentler on others. Roll with them, knowing that a calmer tide </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">is</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> on the horizon, even if it doesn’t feel like it right now. </span>
<h2><b>What are the seven stages of grief after death?</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Some believe we go through seven </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/the-stages-of-grief-myth/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">stages of grief</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> after a loss. These are: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Shock and denial</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Pain and guilt</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Anger and bargaining</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Depression, loneliness and reflection</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Upward turn</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Reconstruction</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Acceptance and hope</span></li>
</ul>
<h3><b>How long does each stage of grief last?</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The idea was first introduced as five stages of grief by Elisabeth Kübler-Ross, before ‘shock and denial’ and ‘acceptance’ were later added on. But we’ll be honest: at Untangle, we see these stages as something of a myth. While you might experience all of the symptoms above, the idea of a ‘checklist’ or a ‘correct’ way to grieve ignores how unique the grieving process is. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">However, if you do go through these stages, know that the timing is different for everyone. Some of them may be fleeting, some may come and go, and some you may never feel at all. While these stages have often been interpreted as being in a set order, Kübler-Ross made it clear in her writing that they are not linear.</span>
<h2><b>What does grief do to your body?</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Grieving isn’t just an emotional process. It can be surprisingly physical too, leaving you exhausted, achy, restless and even with cold or flu-like symptoms. Your mind and body are run down and burnt out, and you might feel that way for weeks or even months. It’s one of many reasons why taking a break is needed in those early stages of a bereavement. </span>
<h3><b>How long does grief fatigue last?</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">We wish we could tell you that it’s ending soon, but like all stages of grief, it takes as long as it takes to get over grief fatigue. Not only is your mind in overdrive and your body coping with a trauma, but you might also be suffering from insomnia, which adds to the exhaustion. Our advice is always patience, but if you feel that grief fatigue is lasting too long for </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">you</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> (not for someone else), you can speak to a doctor about ways to improve your sleep or energy levels. They might be able to offer suggestions on establishing a new sleep pattern, or vitamins to take that will support your body during this difficult time. </span>
<h3><b>How long does grief brain fog last?</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Brain fog is an all too common (and often frustrating) symptom of grief, but try not to be hard on yourself if you find you’re more forgetful in the first weeks or months after a loved one dies. There’s a lot of new information for your brain to process, both in terms of the actual loss and shock, and in terms of any difficult ‘death admin’ you may have to do. Where possible, lean on the help of others for the admin side of things. (Reading our ‘</span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/what-to-do-when-someone-dies/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">What to do when someone dies</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">’ complete guide may help also.) The brain fog should start to clear with time, as you overcome the shock. </span>
<h2><b>How long does pet grief last?</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Pets are family, so when they pass away, the loss is heartbreaking – whether it’s a dog, a cat or another beloved animal. You haven’t just lost a loved one, but often a sense of routine that was built around caring for your pet. And, to make it harder, not everyone will always understand this kind of grief if they’ve not been through it. </span>

<a href="https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/why-we-need-to-take-pet-loss-seriously/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Scientific American</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> says that, after the loss of a pet, acute grief can last two months, with symptoms of grief persisting up to a full year (on average). But, again, we recommend you never put a timeline on your feelings. We at Untangle have experienced this kind of grief, and know how hard it is to adjust to life without your pet. This is your reminder to not bottle up your feelings, and to find people who understand what you’re going through. One day you’ll be able to reflect on all your pet’s funny, unique quirks with a smile. </span>
<h2><b>Does grief last forever?</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">It can – and that’s okay. Grief may stay with you forever, but it won’t always feel as hard or all-consuming as it does right now. In the future, you might find that it’s triggered by a birthday or an anniversary – or just an unexpected memory. But the days in between will start to feel normal again, and missing your loved one will be more manageable. Some things that can help you on this journey include:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Learning about grief, so you can understand why you might be feeling what you’re feeling, and what to expect along the way. </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Finding your support, whether it’s a </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/events/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">bereavement group</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, a good friend or a family member. Opening up, and also hearing others’ stories, can help you process your grief.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Listening to your needs and not pushing yourself to do things before you’re ready. You </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">can</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;"> say ‘no’ when you want to.</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Speaking to HR or a trusted manager at work. </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/bereavement-guides/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Returning to work after a bereavement</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> can be difficult, so it’s important you get the support you need.</span>
<h2><b>A note on complicated grief</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Feelings of deep sadness and hopelessness are common when grieving. However, you may be dealing with complicated grief if you:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Find your feelings don’t become more manageable over time and/or worsen.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Focus on little else but your loved one’s death for a prolonged period of time. </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Feel persistently numb, detached, and that life has no meaning or purpose.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Experience depression, self-blame and/or guilt.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Isolate yourself from others for an extended time. </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Wish you had died with your loved one.</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Complicated grief is an ongoing state of mourning that will often be debilitating, but there are ways to find happiness in your life again. It’s important that you speak to a loved one or a doctor, who will be able to help you access the support you need, </span><span style="font-weight: 400;">whether that’s </span><a href="https://untangleonline.typeform.com/to/mU2OH38O"><span style="font-weight: 400;">individual therapy</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> or medicine. You don’t have to struggle alone. </span>

		How to get grief counselling and what to expect
		https://untanglegrief.com/grief-counselling-advice/
		Fri, 11 Mar 2022 15:31:59 +0000
		emma.harvey
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=3323
		
		<span style="font-weight: 400;">After losing someone you love, it’s not unusual to feel lonely or like nobody else understands. All grief is relative, and how you process your grief is something that’s completely unique to you. However, for many of us, bottling up our emotions is a common ‘coping’ mechanism; one that often leads to even deeper feelings of loneliness and a sense of isolation. This is one of many reasons grief counselling is recommended after a bereavement, but we know that seeking help can feel a little bit scary at first. To help you take that step, we’ve rounded up what you need to know about grief counselling; from why it’s so useful to the different types that are available to you. We hope it helps. </span>
<h2><b>How do I know if I need grief counselling?</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Technically, there is no wrong or right time to consider grief counselling, and you don’t have to fit a certain criteria in order to seek help. However, many counsellors will tell you to wait a few months until after your loss, so you have had some time to process all that has happened and how it has changed your life. It’s never too late to get started, even if the bereavement first took place years ago, and there are no ‘rules’ on how difficult you must be finding your grief. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">Grief counselling isn’t only for those mourning the death of a friend, family member or pet, either; there are other types of loss it can help you process, such as a divorce, losing a job or an estrangement. The fact that you’re grieving is reason enough for you to look into grief counselling, and there are certain signs that help may be essential. Here’s what to be aware of:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you feel like the sadness of a bereavement is taking over your life, counselling is designed to help you manage and live alongside your grief. It’s not necessarily about ‘moving on’ (for many of us, that’s not possible), but it’s about making space in your life for joy to reenter. </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re bottling up emotions and trying to cope on your own, please know you don’t have to. Sometimes, talking your feelings through with a stranger (and a professional) can be easier than talking to those closest to you.  </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you’re supporting others and putting your own feelings on the backburner, grief counselling means you have someone looking out for </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">you</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">. We all need and deserve that level of support. </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">If you have symptoms of depression, seeking help becomes all the more important. A prolonged sense of hopelessness or feeling like you don’t want to be alive anymore is your sign that it’s time to reach out today. </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/contact/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Let us know</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> if there is any way we can help you take that first step.  </span></li>
</ul>
<h2></h2>
<h2><b>What type of therapy is used for grief?</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">There are many different types of bereavement counselling available, and some you may find are more useful than others, depending on how you are currently dealing with your grief. Below are four of the most common, but if you’re not sure where to start, you can also get advice through our </span><a href="https://untangleonline.typeform.com/to/mU2OH38O?typeform-source=untanglegrief.com"><span style="font-weight: 400;">therapy booking service</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. </span>
<h3><b>1. Talking therapy</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">This is what many of us think of when we hear the words ‘grief counselling’. The clue is in the name with this type of therapy; it involves simply talking to your counsellor about how you’re feeling and what has led you to seeking their help. Sometimes, just speaking your truth can help you better process what has happened to you, and understand a way forward that makes the loss more bearable. This is often the ‘starting point’ for people looking into grief counselling, and some go on to explore other types of therapy (such as the ones you’ll see below).  </span>
<h3><b>2. Cognitive behavioural therapy (CBT)</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">CBT is actually a type of talking therapy, which is used to help you and your counsellor identify negative thought patterns so you can work to gradually change them. Studies show that it can have a big impact on the quality of your life, as it helps you reframe troubling thoughts, behaviours or habits and turn them into something that helps you. You may even find it changes the narrative surrounding your loss, and allows you to dwell less on the things that hurt you. </span>
<h3><b>3. Eye movement desensitisation and reprocessing therapy (EMDR)</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The trauma of a loss can impact you both physically and mentally, resulting in a fight, flight or freeze response that makes your grief feel too overwhelming to process. If this sounds familiar, and you find certain triggers put you back in your trauma (such as seeing someone who resembles the person who died or smelling their perfume), EMDR therapy could help you ‘unlock’ that trauma and work through it. This won’t take the memories away, but it will make them more manageable, and help you break cycles of self-blame or guilt. </span>
<h3><b>4. Acceptance and commitment therapy (ACT)</b></h3>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">ACT works on your ability to accept what has happened and the events surrounding your loss, rather than running away from it or trying to avoid it altogether. This type of therapy is sometimes helpful if you’re dealing with prolonged or complicated grief, as it’s designed to help you come to terms with your emotions, and develop techniques to overcome times when it hurts the most.  </span>
<h2></h2>
<h2><b>What do you talk about in grief counselling?</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">No matter what type of grief counselling you choose, expect to talk about the loved one you have lost, what they mean to you, and how you have been coping with your bereavement. It’s important you feel comfortable speaking with your counsellor, so they will work to establish a relationship with you before discussing anything that might be upsetting. From there, the way the conversation progresses depends on both you and your counsellor. Remember, their aim is to help you, and you can pause at any time if you want to. </span>

&nbsp;
<h2><b>How do I get grief counselling?</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">There are various ways you can go about seeking help to manage your grief. To get started, we recommend one of these simple routes:</span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><a href="https://untangleonline.typeform.com/to/mU2OH38O?typeform-source=untanglegrief.com"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Find help right here at Untangle</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. After asking you a few questions about you and your needs, we will partner you with a trusted and vetted therapist.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Contact your GP, tell them about how you are feeling, and ask for a referral to a recommended grief counsellor.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><a href="https://www.nhs.uk/service-search/mental-health/find-a-psychological-therapies-service/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Fill out the NHS form</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> to find grief counselling and psychological help in your local area.</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">And don’t forget, urgent help is always available with the </span><a href="https://www.samaritans.org"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Samaritans</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">. Do not suffer in silence; you can call 116 123 for free at any time, day or night. </span>

		7 ways to say goodbye to a home
		https://untanglegrief.com/ways-to-say-goodbye-to-a-home/
		Mon, 21 Mar 2022 17:24:50 +0000
		emma.harvey
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=3397
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946">To connect with others who share a similar experience of loss, as well as access to coping tips and resources, <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">download the Untangle app</a>. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<p><span style="font-weight: 400;">Parting with a home is never easy, and it’s undoubtedly harder when you’re parting with a house that’s filled with memories and after a bereavement. Here’s the Untangle guide to making this process just that little bit easier.&nbsp;</span></p>
<ol>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><b>Take your time.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> If you can afford to, don’t rush into selling. Making big decisions in the immediate aftermath of loss isn’t advised, because it’s tricky to think logically in a time of such upheaval. You may sell a property that you later decide you wanted to keep. Remember, selling doesn’t always have to be the only option - renting the property out can sometimes cover mortgage and/or maintenance costs. However, if selling the house is right for you, read on to make parting a little less painful.&nbsp;</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><b>Capture everything.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Take photos of every room, ideally both furnished and unfurnished. Consider hiring a photographer to take professional photos of both the interior and exterior.&nbsp; Many artists can be commissioned to paint houses from photographs, and a framed painting of the house you’re saying goodbye to can make a lovely keepsake.&nbsp;</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><b>Host an informal memorial service.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Invite close friends and family around to the house over a day or weekend to enjoy the property with you one more time. It can be a great way to make one more set of memories in the space, and share further memories of the deceased and their life there one more time.</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><b>Take something with you. </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">Some find it comforting to take a little piece of the house with them. Provided you’re not going to damage the property, taking a little light pull or finial and installing it in your own home can be a wonderful way to honour that property and keep it close.&nbsp;</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><b>Leave something behind.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Even more people like to leave something behind. You could write something small in a cupboard or in a window frame, carve your family name into a brick or tree outside, or bury a time capsule in the garden.&nbsp;</span></li>
<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><b>Create a memory book. </b><span style="font-weight: 400;">Whether you choose a scrapbook or a photobook, creating a physical space to memorialise the building is a lovely keepsake. Knowing you have a document within arm’s reach that reminds you of the home, and that you can show to future generations, can be a really comforting thing to own.&nbsp;</span></li>
</ol>
<p><b>Know that your home is the people who are important to you.</b><span style="font-weight: 400;"> Ultimately, it’s important to remember that this home is simply a collection of bricks, tiles, wood and glass. The memories which you associate with it are really stored in your head, and the protection the building once afforded you, truly resides in the people you love and care about. Selling that building changes nothing - you take the memories and love with you wherever you go, forever. </span></p>

		How to prepare for a death: a practical checklist
		https://untanglegrief.com/end-of-life-planning-checklist/
		Mon, 09 May 2022 16:02:16 +0000
		emma.harvey
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=3656
		
		<span style="font-weight: 400;">One day, we’re all going to die. It’s an unavoidable fact of life, and something that many of us would prefer not to think too hard about. However, the truth is that preparing for death can make things easier for both yourself and those who love you. By getting your affairs in order, you can save them from added stress, while also making sure your wishes are heard. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">If this is something you are currently thinking about, firstly, we hope you’re doing okay. Our </span><a href="https://untangleonline.typeform.com/to/mU2OH38O?typeform-source=untanglegrief.com"><span style="font-weight: 400;">therapy booking service</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> is always there if you are going through a difficult time and need someone to talk to. We want to try and make end of life planning that little bit simpler for you or your loved one, which is why we’ve created this ‘getting your affairs in order’ checklist of practical tasks. </span>

<span style="font-weight: 400;">A lot of these steps you can take on your own, but don’t be afraid to ask for help if you need it. This may actually be wise, as it will mean someone knows exactly what preparations you’ve made. The list might look long and daunting, but many of these things you’ll already have lying around </span><i><span style="font-weight: 400;">somewhere</span></i><span style="font-weight: 400;">. It’s just a case of finding them, getting them together, and sharing them with the right people.  </span>
<h2><b>1. Write your last will and testament</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">The first practical thing many of us think about when preparing for a death is the will. This sets out what will happen to your estate and belongings when you die, who will carry out your wishes and, if you have children, who will look after them. You can write a simple will on your own or find templates on Google that you can fill in. Make sure, when you choose an executor, it is someone you trust to act fairly and do exactly as you ask. We then recommend contacting a solicitor to read over your will, provide any feedback, and ensure the final document is legally binding. This is something we at Untangle may be able to help you with, so do </span><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/contact/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">reach out</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> if you’re looking for the right solicitor for you.  </span>

&nbsp;
<h2><b>2. Communicate your funeral wishes</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you know there is a certain song you want played or ritual carried out at your funeral, tell the person or people who would be responsible for planning the day. Maybe you want everyone to wear a certain colour, or there’s a reading you’d like them to listen to. Whatever your funeral wishes are, write them down and pass them on to someone you trust. This isn’t just for your own peace of mind; it’s helpful for your loved ones too. They won’t have to guess or wonder (or argue over!) what you might have wanted when the time comes. Dying Matters and the National Association of Funeral Directors have created a </span><a href="https://digitallegacyassociation.org/funeral-wishes-leaflet/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">‘My Funeral Wishes’ leaflet</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, which you can print out and fill in if you need some help with ideas.</span>

&nbsp;
<h2><b>3. Document all of your passwords</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">So much of our lives is stored on phones and computers these days, which means that, chances are, your loved ones will need access to your devices at some point. Note down all of your passwords – including any for online banking, bill paying, emails, etc. – or better yet, use a password managing service to store them all in one place. </span><a href="https://1password.com/"><span style="font-weight: 400;">1Password</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;"> keeps them all together, and lets you share with friends and family in a few taps. It’s completely safe (with plenty of security measures in place), but makes it easy to give people the access they need. </span>

&nbsp;
<h2><b>4. Share locations for important paperwork</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Two of the most important documents you can share with your loved ones are your life insurance policy and your pension details – but these can often be overlooked while people focus on the will. So, make sure you gather them up and place them in one location in your home, then tell your loved ones where they can find all the paperwork they need. Other documents and financial details to add in are: </span>
<ul>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Debts you might owe, including mortgage statements, utility bills in your name, leases, educational loan statements and other unpaid bills.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">An outline of all bank accounts and credit cards you own.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Your birth certificate and (if you have one) marriage certificate.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Life insurance documents, including mortgage cover.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Any paperwork related to your property, including mortgage agreements and property deeds or leases.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Relevant statements from Jobs &amp; Benefits Offices (for benefits) and/or the Pension Service.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Existing valuations of expensive items, such as jewellery or artwork. </span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">PAYE form P60 if you are employed or recent tax calculations and returns if you are self-employed.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Organ donor card.</span></li>
 	<li style="font-weight: 400;" aria-level="1"><span style="font-weight: 400;">Passport, driving licence and any relevant membership cards.</span></li>
</ul>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Place them all in a clearly labelled folder to make things even simpler for the person looking for them.</span>

&nbsp;
<h2><b>5. Make a list of who needs to be told</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Those closest to you will probably know who to contact after you’ve passed away, but if you have some old friends you think they might forget, make sure to write their names and numbers down. This can go in the same folder as your important documents – just make sure someone knows it’s there. </span>

&nbsp;
<h2><b>6. Consider your social media accounts</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">There’s no denying that social media has become a big part of our lives, so you may want to have an end of life plan in place for your Instagram, Facebook and Twitter accounts. Perhaps you just want them removed entirely, or maybe you want someone to create a post for you. Whatever the case, this is another thing to share with those closest to you. In your Facebook settings, you can even choose a ‘legacy contact’ to look after your account after you pass away or request that your account is removed once someone confirms your death.  </span>

&nbsp;
<h2><b>7. Make sure your car isn’t parked on the road</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">Your car insurance policy becomes invalid as soon as you have passed away, so if your car is parked on a road, nobody will be legally able to move it. Start making sure it’s parked up properly so it can’t become a problem later on. </span>

&nbsp;
<h2><b>8. Ensure the executor has enough money</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">It will be up to the executor of your will to gather money from your estate and pay off any debts and home bills that come through. However, they can only get money out of the estate when the grant of probate has been issued, which means they may need some funds up front to cover essential costs. Try to come to an arrangement that will ensure they have enough money to pay off those bills, as even the most straightforward estates can take months to process. Alternatively, the executor may be able to get help from a solicitor, who can contact creditors on their behalf and advise on how and when payment will be made. </span>

&nbsp;
<h2><b>9. Arrange a home for your pet(s)</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">If you live with just your pet(s), you’ll want them to go to a loving home; somewhere you know they’ll be taken care of and given all the care and attention they deserve. Think carefully about who you would want to look after them after you have gone. Someone they already have a relationship with would be perfect, as they’re likely to settle in much quicker. You could also register for the </span><a href="https://www.rspca.org.uk/whatwedo/care/homeforlife/howitworks"><span style="font-weight: 400;">RSPCA’s Home for Life</span></a><span style="font-weight: 400;">, and they will arrange a home for your pet on your behalf. There’s paperwork involved here so, again, make sure your pet’s plan is kept with all your other documents. </span>

&nbsp;
<h2><b>10. Check if there’s anything you want to get rid of</b></h2>
<span style="font-weight: 400;">As well as things you’ll want to gather, there might be things you want to get rid of, too. That slightly embarrassing teenage journal comes to mind! This is just a friendly reminder to go through your belongings and check there’s nothing that makes you cringe too hard. (But don’t worry too much; the people who love you won’t judge those old ‘Dear Diary’ entries.)</span>

		Funeral songs - what and how to choose?
		https://untanglegrief.com/funeral-songs/
		Thu, 09 Jun 2022 11:51:10 +0000
		ryan.stafford
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=3720
		
		It’s not uncommon for us to use songs like bookmarks for the landmarks of life. We hear a song at a wedding or a funeral and then the next time we hear it, it transports us back.

That’s why music is such an important <a href="/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/">consideration for a funeral</a>. Pick funeral songs that embody your loved one - you'll forever associate your choices with them.

<strong>Now, every guide under the sun lists the same songs again and again - and whilst that's because they are genuinely the most popular songs for funerals, we decided to put it to our <a href="/">bereavement support</a> community. The result? A combination of the most chosen funeral songs across the UK with those that have a beautiful member story behind them.</strong>
<h2>Things to consider when choosing a funeral song</h2>
Given the gravity of your funeral song choices, it’s easy to get stuck deciding between a thousand different artists and songs. In these instances, <strong>we recommend choosing those that most closely match the preferences of your loved one,</strong> rather than random songs you hear on the radio (or those that you / your family like).
<blockquote>“I really struggled to pick funeral songs. <strong>I realise, looking back, that I was trying to please my family, rather than choosing based on my dad.</strong> I wanted everyone to feel like they had a connection to dad via the songs, rather than just something he loved to listen to. <strong>My advice? Don’t think of how the songs will be perceived.</strong> Don't strive to appease. Pick based on the person you lost - <strong>choose something that embodies them.</strong>” Ryan, Untangle member</blockquote>
<h2>Songs and stories from our community</h2>
The thing about a grief community is that everyone can relate - every member has been 'there'.

<strong>Whilst almost any person can curate a list of songs, the following have real stories behind them:</strong>

<img class="alignnone wp-image-3771 size-full" src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/Funeral-song-sharon-story.webp" alt="Sharon's funeral songs story" width="1920" height="1080" />

<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3768" src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/Funeral-songs-Saneeta-story.webp" alt="Saneeta's funeral song story" width="1920" height="1080" />

Some other songs to have come out of the Untangle community include:
<ul>
 	<li><strong>These Dreams</strong> - Heart
<em>"Mum and I used to sing this together." Eleanor</em></li>
 	<li><strong>The sound of Silence</strong> - Disturbed
<em>"I remember hearing him sing it it for the first time. Then when he passed, the lyrics had so much more meaning." Jaye</em></li>
 	<li><strong>Brothers in Arms</strong> - Dire Straits
<em>"My husband was in the army for 22 years and the police for 20 years." Mandy</em></li>
 	<li><strong>This Must Be Love</strong> - Phil Collins
<em>"My partner said this is how he felt about me and our relationship." Jules</em></li>
 	<li><strong>Wind Beneath My Wings</strong> - Better Middler
<em>"Mum used to sing this song whenever we had family karaoke." Eleanor</em></li>
 	<li><strong>Mockin' Bird</strong> - Dusty Springfield
<em>"My wife's favourite female singer." Colin</em></li>
 	<li><strong>Last Time</strong> - Yavid
<em>"Our favourite artist released it after he passed." Kay</em></li>
</ul>
<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3772" src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/Funeral-songs-lynn.webp" alt="Lynn's funeral song story" width="1920" height="1080" />
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Somebody</strong> - Depeche Mode
<em>"My husband chose it a couple of weeks before he died. It makes me so tearful as the words are so poignant as he use to sing it to me " Jenny</em></li>
 	<li><strong>Behold the Light</strong> - White Sun
<em>"Every morning my son would listen as I would hold him and dance in our living room to greet the day." Claire</em></li>
 	<li><b>Will You Know My Name? </b>- Eric Clapton
<em>"A year before her death they appeared all together with this song in a school concert." Yulia</em></li>
 	<li><b>Perfect Duet </b>- Ed Sheeran &amp; Beyoncé
<em>"My dad's favourite song in the whole world." Vanessa</em></li>
</ul>
<h2>The most popular funeral songs</h2>
By popular, we mean those that are frequently chosen across the UK - the list derives from surveys and our community members.
<ul>
 	<li><strong>You’ll Never Walk Alone</strong> - Gerry and the Pacemakers
<em>Note: this overtook Frank Sinatra’s My Way as the most popular funeral song to be played in the UK.</em></li>
 	<li><strong>My Way</strong> - Frank Sinatra</li>
 	<li><strong>The Long and Winding Road</strong> - The Beatles
<em>Written in 1970, this was famously performed by George Michael at Linda McCartney’s tribute concert.</em></li>
 	<li><strong>Imagine</strong> - John Lennon</li>
 	<li><strong>The Chain</strong> - Fleetwood Mac</li>
 	<li><strong>Bridge Over Troubled Water</strong> - Simon &amp; Garfunkel</li>
 	<li><strong>We'll Meet Again</strong> - Vera Lynn
<em>A song that captured the heart of the nation during the Second World War and forever after.</em></li>
 	<li><strong>The Best</strong> - Tina Turner</li>
 	<li><strong>Somewhere Over the Rainbow</strong> - Eva Cassidy</li>
</ul>
<iframe style="border-radius: 12px;" src="https://open.spotify.com/embed/playlist/1VCLa363F1cX5CBYPel8ld?utm_source=generator&amp;theme=0" width="100%" height="270" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>
<h2>Funeral songs for dad</h2>
For some, it’s an easy choice - perhaps there’s a song that encapsulated him; maybe he had said which song he had always wanted to go out to. For others, it’s not so easy - it certainly wasn’t for me. <strong>There wasn’t one song that typified my dad. I had to go searching for inspiration</strong>.

With that in mind, here’s a collection of songs that have proven themselves to be both touching and popular songs for dad:
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Dance with My Father</strong> - Luther Vandross</li>
 	<li><strong>Tears in Heaven</strong> - Eric Clapton</li>
 	<li><strong>Old Man</strong> - Neil Young</li>
 	<li><strong>Go The Distance</strong> - Michael Bolton
<em>"He always said it made him feel like he could do anything. And ge deserved a series welcome at the pearly gates." Keisha</em></li>
 	<li><strong>Wake Me Up When September Ends</strong> - Green Day</li>
 	<li><strong>Comfortably Numb</strong> - Pink Floyd</li>
 	<li><strong>Life On Mars</strong> - David Bowie</li>
 	<li><strong>A Case Of You</strong> - Joni Mitchell</li>
 	<li><strong>My Father’s Eyes</strong> - Eric Clapton</li>
 	<li><strong>Sailing -</strong> Rod Stewart
<em>"Dad had it at his mum’s funeral and dad requested it at his. It utterly destroyed me." Clare</em></li>
</ul>
<iframe style="border-radius: 12px;" src="https://open.spotify.com/embed/playlist/3twWqtxJwfovdkmc0B8AHn?utm_source=generator&amp;theme=0" width="100%" height="270" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start">﻿</span></iframe>
<h2>Funeral songs for mum</h2>
Choosing a song to say goodbye; it’s one of the hardest things you’ll ever have to go through. But, before you even think of a song, sit back, think of your mum - what were her best qualities? What are some of your favourite memories together? Now, is there a song that encapsulates those times? If so, choose it. If not, see if any of the songs below capture her spirit. Even if they don’t, hopefully they give you a steer in the right direction.
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Your Song</strong> - Elton John</li>
 	<li><strong>Angel</strong> - Sarah McLachlan</li>
 	<li><strong>Supermarket Flowers</strong> - Ed Sheeran</li>
 	<li><strong>In My Life</strong> - The Beatles</li>
 	<li><strong>You are the Sunshine of My Life</strong> - Stevie Wonder</li>
 	<li><strong>Mama</strong> - Spice Girls</li>
 	<li><strong>Dear Mama</strong> - 2Pac</li>
 	<li><strong>Sweetest Devotion</strong> - Adele</li>
 	<li><strong>The Rose</strong> - Westlife</li>
</ul>
<img class="alignnone size-full wp-image-3779" src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/05/Funeral-song-sue-story.webp" alt="Sue's funeral song for mum story" width="1920" height="1080" />

<iframe style="border-radius: 12px;" src="https://open.spotify.com/embed/playlist/1sLPkO7iUZXPfkyJodV8Bl?utm_source=generator&amp;theme=0" width="100%" height="270" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"></iframe>
<h2>Funeral songs for the older generation</h2>
The beauty of music lies in nostalgia - <strong>hearing a song that an older relative loved can evoke powerful images of them in their heyday, and there’s so much beauty in that.</strong> For me, the process of picking funeral songs for grandma was incredibly powerful experience - her spirit was in the room; it was palpable. That came through playing some of the records that she ALWAYS listened to. I have a picture of her from when she was in her late twenties - that's the person I always picture dancing to them.

<strong>Here are some of the most popular funeral songs for the older generation:</strong>
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Wind Beneath My Wings</strong> - Bette Midler</li>
 	<li><strong>We'll Meet Again</strong> - Vera Lynn</li>
 	<li><strong>Time To Say Goodbye</strong> - Andrea Bocelli and Sarah Brightman</li>
 	<li><strong>How Great Thou Art</strong> - Elvis Presley</li>
 	<li><strong>Valley of Tears</strong> - Buddy Holly</li>
 	<li><strong>I’ll Be Seeing You</strong> - Bing Crosby</li>
 	<li><strong>Make You Feel My Love</strong> - Bob Dylan</li>
 	<li><strong>Ave Maria</strong> - Franz Schubert</li>
 	<li><strong>Nimrod</strong> - Edward Elgar</li>
</ul>
<iframe style="border-radius: 12px;" src="https://open.spotify.com/embed/playlist/3uplt2dHdUcxyVYhCVxhMN?utm_source=generator&amp;theme=0" width="100%" height="270" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start">﻿</span></iframe>
<h2>Modern funeral songs</h2>
This is very much a fluid category, in that the top 40 of the time will equate to 'modern' - whatever that means. When we asked our community, there were plenty of classic songs, but they certainly didn't dominate. In fact, there was a perfect blend of 'modern' vs 'classic'.

<strong>A selection of popular modern funeral songs, as chosen by the Untangle community:</strong>
<ul>
 	<li><strong>All of Me</strong> - John Legend</li>
 	<li><strong>Just the Way You Are</strong> - Bruno Mars</li>
 	<li><strong>Shut up and Dance</strong> - Walk the Moon</li>
 	<li><strong>Visiting Hours</strong> - Ed Sheeran</li>
 	<li><strong>Lost Without You</strong> - Freya Ridings</li>
 	<li><strong>A Sky Full of Stars</strong> - Coldplay</li>
 	<li><strong>Thinkin Bout You</strong> - Frank Ocean</li>
 	<li><strong>Free Fallin'</strong> - John Mayer</li>
 	<li><strong>Halo</strong> - Beyonce</li>
</ul>
<iframe style="border-radius: 12px;" src="https://open.spotify.com/embed/playlist/21kX4kam1D14w9Nv0Mxw0V?utm_source=generator&amp;theme=0" width="100%" height="270" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start">﻿</span></iframe>
<h2>Uplifting funeral songs</h2>
Funerals are always going to be one of the toughest things you'll ever have to go through - there's no denying that, but they're also a celebration of life and the impact our lost one had on all of our lives.
<blockquote>My dad always wanted people to smile - he sure cracked enough jokes to try to make that the case. Whilst it was one of the saddest days of my life, I’m glad I chose happy, uplifting songs that reflected him.</blockquote>
<strong>With this in mind, a selection of uplifting funeral songs as chosen by the Untangle community:</strong>
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Always Look on the Bright Side of Life</strong> - Monty Python</li>
 	<li><strong>Bring Me Sunshine</strong> - Morecambe and Wise</li>
 	<li><strong>Three Little Birds</strong> - Bob Marley</li>
 	<li><strong>What a Wonderful World</strong> - Louis Armstrong</li>
 	<li><strong>Live Forever</strong> - Oasis</li>
 	<li><strong>Hero</strong> - Mariah Carey</li>
 	<li><strong>You’re My Best Friend</strong> - Queen</li>
 	<li><strong>Fly Me To The Moon</strong> - Frank Sinatra</li>
 	<li><strong>Easy</strong> - The Commodores</li>
</ul>
<iframe style="border-radius: 12px;" src="https://open.spotify.com/embed/playlist/5QR0zwodkJcANgkck3jM0W?utm_source=generator&amp;theme=0" width="100%" height="270" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start">﻿</span></iframe>
<h2>Funny funeral songs</h2>
The theme of this post is very much choose something that embodies your loved one. Always one to crack a joke? Forever finding the funny in things? These might inspire you to find the one to prick everyone's ears.

<strong>Funeral songs to sure raise a smile:</strong>
<ul>
 	<li><strong>Another One Bites The Dust</strong> - Queen</li>
 	<li><strong>Highway to Hell</strong> - ACDC</li>
 	<li><strong>Ding Dong! The Witch Is Dead</strong> - The Munchkins</li>
 	<li><strong>Ha Ha You’re Dead</strong> - Green Day</li>
 	<li><strong>Blaze Of Glory</strong> - Bon Jovi</li>
 	<li><strong>Going Underground</strong> - The Jam</li>
 	<li><strong>Monkey Gone to Heaven</strong> - The Pixies</li>
 	<li><strong>Should I Stay or Should I Go?</strong> - The Clash</li>
</ul>
<iframe style="border-radius: 12px;" src="https://open.spotify.com/embed/playlist/0Mb1ZUz5LBq9DOfWnLcbqf?utm_source=generator&amp;theme=0" width="100%" height="270" frameborder="0" allowfullscreen="allowfullscreen"><span data-mce-type="bookmark" style="display: inline-block; width: 0px; overflow: hidden; line-height: 0;" class="mce_SELRES_start">﻿</span></iframe>
<h2><em>Do I need to obtain copyright for music played at a funeral?</em></h2>
<em>No. PRS for Music and PPL consider funerals to be private functions, requiring no copyright licence to play the songs of your choosing. If, however, the service is going to be recorded and/or live streamed, then a licence may well be required.</em>

&nbsp;

<b> We really hope this helps you on your way to finding the right funeral song. We've also got some related posts on songs about losing a friend and songs about missing someone who died. </b>

And, as always, if you want to share how you're feeling or perhaps ask questions to others who have lost, do not hesitate one bit - it's exactly why our free grief community exists. <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Download the Untangle Grief app.</a>

<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><a href="#personal">My own battle with death anniversaries</a></li><li><a href="#tania">Tania's story</a></li><li><a href="#ideas"><strong>Death anniversary ideas</strong></a></li><li><a href="#tips">Tips for coping on a death anniversary</a></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The Death Anniversary. It’s such a weird and confusing term. Anniversaries are, for the most part, a celebration of milestones. But when you juxtapose it with a terrible moment - scratch that, the worst moment - in our lives, it becomes oh-so confusing.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>With this in mind, we reached out to our community to gather some stories on loss itself and their thoughts on death anniversaries.<strong> After all, whilst every article under the sun can advise on ‘death anniversary ideas’, nothing compares to hearing from those who truly understand what you’re going through. </strong>You’ll also find some ideas to honour your loved one, together with ways in which our members have managed to cope on the day itself.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946">If you want to share your story, how you’re feeling, anything - however small you think it might be - <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">come over to Untangle</a>. We’re all in this terrible club together.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="personal">My own battle with death anniversaries</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I lost my loved one in 2017. Unsurprisingly, it ripped my world apart. <strong>For the first year, I went into survival mode - for me, that meant suppression.</strong> It seemed logical to ignore the things that made me feel bad, and this was unlike anything else. <strong>After all, if you stick your head in the sand for long enough, maybe one’s troubles will dissolve into sweet nothingness? Of course, it never quite works out that way.</strong> My <a href="/therapy/">bereavement counsellor</a> didn’t think so. And it certainly didn’t for me. Suppression has long been known to extend the lifespan of unwanted feelings.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:group -->
<div class="wp-block-group"><!-- wp:media-text {"mediaId":3943,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/death-anniversary-story/","mediaType":"image","imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide is-stacked-on-mobile"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Death-anniversary-story.webp" alt="Picture of loved one for death anniversary" class="wp-image-3943 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So, as you might've guessed, <strong>I didn’t do anything on the first anniversary of his death</strong>. It took me until year 3 to begin celebrating his life on that ominous date, January 6th. <strong>Now, I kind of look forward to it - I treat it as celebrating his life up until that point.</strong> To remember the amazing times we shared and use it as an opportunity to thank him for the impact he had on my life. And I regret not doing it in the first year.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text --></div>
<!-- /wp:group -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In short, when you <a href="/what-to-do-when-someone-dies/" data-type="post">lose someone</a>, the anniversary of that loss is scary, but it can be marked in a way that honours them. That’s not to say it's easy to do or that the grief goes away - there will forever be a ping of sadness resting on my shoulder. But it can be, with will, a day for reflection and gratitude. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join our free grief community</a></strong> - </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:cover {"customOverlayColor":"#fff2e5","focalPoint":{"x":"0.53","y":"0.27"},"minHeight":320,"minHeightUnit":"px","contentPosition":"center center","isDark":false,"align":"center"} -->
<div class="wp-block-cover aligncenter is-light" style="min-height:320px"><span aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-cover__background has-background-dim-100 has-background-dim" style="background-color:#fff2e5"></span><div class="wp-block-cover__inner-container"><!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"center","width":"100%"} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-center" style="flex-basis:100%"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"large"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-large-font-size" id="tania" style="color:#003946">Tania's story:</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946"><strong>It's about the two of you</strong>...</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"16px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:16px">"I lost my husband in 2020. I didn’t see it coming. The wave of pain that hit me was intense. I can't really describe it. I just didn’t know I could feel that way. Every second I ached for him. I went on throughout the year with little regard to much - and by that I mean I didn’t care for anything: my health, friendships, like I said, anything. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"16px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:16px"><strong>As the anniversary of his death approached, I had no idea what to do. Truth be told, I was dreading it.</strong> I started looking through our texts, when I stumbled upon this, “don’t worry about being late - enjoy yourself. It’s so good knowing you’re letting loose and having fun. That’s what life’s about.”  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"16px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:16px">That’s when I thought, “right, we’re going to celebrate life together on that dreaded day”. So, I called up my mum, his friends and family members, then booked a restaurant and bar for post-dinner drinks. We went out, told stories of him - good and bad! We each went round the table speaking of the impact he had on us individually. It was so tough, but it made my heart smile, if that’s even possible. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"19px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:19px"><strong>My advice to anyone is that death anniversaries are about you and your loved one. Don’t put on some extravagant event or act if it’s not what you want to do. It should reflect the mantra that was the glue in your relationship.</strong>"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:cover -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="ideas">Ideas for a death anniversary</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>We reached out to our community for this one.</strong> After all, anyone can write a bunch of death anniversary ideas, but only those who have experienced it can understand the nuance of the occasion.<strong>Here's what they had to say:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Take the day off and just give yourself the time and space to grieve.</strong></li><li><strong>Light a candle in their memory or visit their final resting place</strong>.</li><li><strong>Write letters and put them inside balloons</strong>.</li><li><strong>Paint, draw, write a poem, or play a song to celebrate your loved one.</strong></li><li><strong>Buy a cake to lift the mood</strong> - think of it as celebrating their life up until that point.</li><li><strong>Get together as a family, play their favourite songs</strong>.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaPosition":"right","mediaId":3942,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/death-anniversary-skyline/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":32,"verticalAlignment":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fffdea"}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile is-vertically-aligned-center has-background" style="background-color:#fffdea;grid-template-columns:auto 32%"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Death-anniversary-skyline.webp" alt="London skyline for death anniversary idea" class="wp-image-3942 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:group {"style":{"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-group" style="padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"lineHeight":"1.2","fontSize":"26px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:26px;line-height:1.2"><strong>"Go for a drive at night. If you have one near you, find a view of the skyline, pull up and soak it in. Then reflect.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"extra-small"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-extra-small-font-size" style="color:#003946">– Charat, Untangle member</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:group --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul id="block-b6b7f0f7-4577-4cf5-a5cb-878092c2eadc"><li><strong>Make a memory bear from their clothing</strong>.</li><li><strong>Go to their favourite place - be it a park, beach or, in my case, festival!</strong></li><li><strong>“We had a family meal and told stories of dad. We then let off balloons and put on his favourite song.”</strong></li><li><strong>Scatter some of their ashes somewhere meaningful</strong>: on a favourite walk or at the top of a mountain you used to climb together, as an example.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaId":3944,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/death-anniversary-ideas-plant/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":32,"verticalAlignment":"center","imageFill":false,"style":{"color":{"background":"#fffdea"}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide is-stacked-on-mobile is-vertically-aligned-center has-background" style="background-color:#fffdea;grid-template-columns:32% auto"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Death-anniversary-ideas-plant.webp" alt="Plant as a death anniversary idea" class="wp-image-3944 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:group {"style":{"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-group" style="padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"lineHeight":"1.2","fontSize":"28px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:28px;line-height:1.2"><strong>"Plant something in their memory. It can be extremely comforting to watch it grow over time." </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"extra-small"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-extra-small-font-size" style="color:#003946">– Lisa, Untangle member</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:group --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Go for a long walk. Take a friend or two and talk out your feelings, or walk alone and have some quiet time to think.</strong></li><li><strong>Call up or visit someone who knew your loved one well and have a long chat. </strong>They may also be struggling.</li><li><em><strong>Write a letter to your loved one:</strong> you can explore a range of things: things you miss; things you resent; traumas; things you’re grateful for; things that were left unsaid; regrets; funny things you wish they’d been there to see; things they’d be proud of; gossip; questions; things you’ve let go of or forgiven; things that still make you laugh.</em></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaPosition":"right","mediaId":3948,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/death-anniversary-ideas-fortune-cookie/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":32,"verticalAlignment":"center","imageFill":false,"style":{"color":{"background":"#fffdea"}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile is-vertically-aligned-center has-background" style="background-color:#fffdea;grid-template-columns:auto 32%"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/06/Death-anniversary-ideas-fortune-cookie.webp" alt="Fortune cookie for death anniversary" class="wp-image-3948 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:group {"style":{"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-group" style="padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"lineHeight":"1.2","fontSize":"24px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:24px;line-height:1.2"><strong>“I ordered Chinese fortune cookies and put sentences from her diary in them, as her gift to all her friends and relatives who came to share the pain with us on that day.”</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"extra-small"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-extra-small-font-size" style="color:#003946">– Yulia, Untangle member</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:group --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Travel somewhere that’s been on your bucket list for a while.</strong></li><li><strong>Throw a dinner party </strong>with people that knew your loved one well.<strong> Share stories. Laugh. Cry. Console. Connect.</strong></li><li><strong>Make it a potluck with your family</strong>, with everyone bringing your loved one’s favourite foods.</li><li><strong>Have a duvet day</strong> and watch their favourite films or TV shows.</li><li><strong>Take a class to learn to do something your loved one enjoyed </strong>– this can be a great mechanism for connection.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaId":4046,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/?attachment_id=4046","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":32,"verticalAlignment":"center","imageFill":false,"style":{"color":{"background":"#fffdea"}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide is-stacked-on-mobile is-vertically-aligned-center has-background" style="background-color:#fffdea;grid-template-columns:32% auto"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/07/Death-anniversary-ideas-scrapbook.webp" alt="Death anniversary idea: photo scrapbook" class="wp-image-4046 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:group {"style":{"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-group" style="padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"lineHeight":"1.2","fontSize":"24px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:24px;line-height:1.2"><strong>“Look at their photos, videos, letters, journals, clothes, jewellery, books, and anything else they left behind. Maybe add some of these things to a scrapbook or create a photo memory book.”</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"extra-small"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-extra-small-font-size" style="color:#003946">– Charlie, Untangle member</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:group --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Go somewhere that was special to the two of you. Leave them flowers and a note.</strong></li><li><strong>Spend the day helping others:</strong> do a charity run, or organise a fundraiser for a cause that mattered to the person you’ve lost.</li><li>If you are religious, <strong>go to a service, spend the day with your community</strong> or take part in a memorial ritual.</li><li>Make a <strong>mixtape or Spotify playlist of tracks that they loved</strong> and listen to them.</li><li>Go see one of their <strong>favourite bands play live.</strong></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join our free grief community</a></strong> -</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:cover {"customOverlayColor":"#fff2e5","focalPoint":{"x":"0.53","y":"0.27"},"minHeight":320,"minHeightUnit":"px","contentPosition":"center center","isDark":false,"align":"center"} -->
<div class="wp-block-cover aligncenter is-light" style="min-height:320px"><span aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-cover__background has-background-dim-100 has-background-dim" style="background-color:#fff2e5"></span><div class="wp-block-cover__inner-container"><!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"center","width":"100%"} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-center" style="flex-basis:100%"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"large"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-large-font-size" id="tom" style="color:#003946">Tom's story:</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946"><strong>There's no right or wrong</strong>...  </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"16px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:16px">“It’s a tough one - I know others who do the same thing each and every year. I get that - they’ve told me they feel more connected to their lost person. <strong>For me, it depends how I’m feeling.</strong> And, to be fair, whenever we did stuff together, it would be based on how we were feeling at the time. So, in a way, it very much reflects that. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"16px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:16px">On the first anniversary of her death, I hid away. I took the day off work knowing that I wasn’t going to be much fun to be around - I put her favourite box set on, ordered her favourite takeaway and didn’t move for the rest of the day. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"16px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:16px">The second year, I wanted to do some sort of activity - truth be told, I didn’t want to be stuck in the same spot like the first time. Instead, I took to the beach and went stand up paddleboarding. We did it on holiday once and she loved it. At that moment, I realised what others had been saying - I felt so connected to her.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"19px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:19px"><strong>My advice to others is to listen to your body. If it’s riddled with grief and you can’t move, chances are you’re not going to feel that connection if you do some sort of activity. There’s no right or wrong. Do you.”</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:cover -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="tips">Tips for coping on a death anniversary</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As Tom mentioned, sometimes, you just need to switch off from the world; to shut yourself away and get through the day.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>We asked the community and Untangle team for some quick tips for coping on death anniversaries. Here’s what came up:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>If you’re going to be around people, let them know that the date is approaching:</strong> <em>“you may not want to bring it up - why would you? - but letting friends and family know means they can be there to support you - or, in my instance, let me be.”</em></li><li>There may be others who are also affected by the loss (family or close friends of your lost person). <em>"<strong>I’ve found doing something together incredibly powerful</strong>.</em> <em>I find that others bring up amazing memories that I had almost forgotten."</em></li><li><strong>Plan ahead: </strong><em>“When I haven’t planned anything, I withdraw. It’s an anniversary of a death after all, why wouldn’t I? Planning enables me / forces me to put myself into a more positive mindset. Looking back, that definitely helps.”</em></li><li><strong>Don’t put yourself under pressure to do anything:</strong> <em>"It’s a tough day; you don't have to treat it as a celebration of life. Not doing anything is doing something in itself."</em></li><li><strong>Share your story and how you’re feeling on a grief community</strong>: <em>"There’s comfort in talking to people you don’t know who understand the precise agony of loss." </em></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946">If you want to share how you're feeling, ask questions to others who have lost or simply read their stories, head on over to the Untangle community via the <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Untangle Grief app</a>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We hope this article helps you navigate a death anniversary. Please get in touch if you have any questions or are seeking support. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		The stages of grief: can they be trusted?
		https://untanglegrief.com/stages-of-grief/
		Tue, 13 Sep 2022 14:57:30 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4125
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left"><strong>Whilst the sad truth is that death and loss are universal experiences, responses to loss are not: </strong>they’re unique, individual and personal, characterised by the circumstances and meaning of that loss, not to mention the resources available to a person.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left">Some will cry, feel distress, withdraw, others will become fixated on purpose or a task at hand - the list is endless and each reaction is normal. <strong>There is no right or wrong. Everyone grieves differently.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center","id":4132,"width":425,"height":292,"sizeSlug":"full","linkDestination":"custom"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full is-resized"><a href="https://urlgeni.us/stages-grief-image"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/Stages-of-grief-poll.webp" alt="Untangle's poll: do you believe in the 5 stages of grief" class="wp-image-4132" width="425" height="292"/></a><figcaption><em>A divided opinion on the five stages of grief</em></figcaption></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>This is why stages of grief theories can cause problems.</strong> Culture has made it seem that grief is linear and that there is an expectation to feel a certain way, but for anyone coping with grief, these ideas <em>can</em> be harmful.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>With this in mind, we spoke to Untangle members about their experience of loss and the grieving stages, as well <a href="https://www.nottingham.ac.uk/medicine/about/divisions-and-units/psychiatry-and-applied-psychology/people/elizabeth.paddock" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Dr Lizzie Paddock</a>, Psychologist and Assistant Professor in Forensic Psychology at the University of Nottingham.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e4e4e4"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e4e4e4;color:#e4e4e4"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->

Q&amp;A</a></li><li><a href="#tonkins">Tonkins model of grief</a></li><li><a href="#trusted">Can the stages be trusted? </a></li><li><a href="#tips">How to care for yourself</a> </li><li><a href="#support">Where to find support</a></li></ul>
