<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="grief-feel">What can grief feel like? </h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Grief can manifest itself in many different ways.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>From physical symptoms through to behavioural changes, you may experience a number of reactions or none at all.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><em>The below is a non-exhaustive list of possible reactions to loss:</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:table {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"16px"}},"backgroundColor":"white","className":"is-style-stripes, is-style-stripes"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-table is-style-stripes, is-style-stripes" style="font-size:16px"><table class="has-white-background-color has-text-color has-background" style="color:#003946"><thead><tr><th class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left">Reaction type </th><th class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left">How grief might present itself</th></tr></thead><tbody><tr><td class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left"><strong>Physical</strong></td><td class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left"><ul class="has-normal-font-size"><li>Nausea</li><li>Headaches</li><li>Insomnia</li><li>Noise sensitivity</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left"><strong>Emotional</strong></td><td class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left"><ul class="has-normal-font-size"><li>Sadness</li><li>Anger*</li><li>Hopelessness</li><li>Anxiousness</li><li>Loneliness</li></ul><em>* this doesn't exclusively mean blind range, it also encompasses things like bitterness, resentment, etc.</em></td></tr><tr><td class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left"><strong>Cognitive</strong></td><td class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left"><ul class="has-normal-font-size"><li>Unable to concentrate</li><li>Unable to return back to work</li><li>Confusion and emptiness</li><li>Replaying the loss in your head</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left"><strong>Behavioural</strong></td><td class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left"><ul class="has-normal-font-size"><li>Obsessive and compulsive behaviour</li><li>Distracting from the loss via alcohol use, etc.</li><li>Social withdrawal</li><li>Changes in activity level</li><li>Avoidance of places or reminders of your loved one</li></ul></td></tr><tr><td class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left"><strong>Spiritual</strong></td><td class="has-text-align-left" data-align="left"><ul class="has-normal-font-size"><li>Searching for meaning in life</li><li>Examining faith in a deeper way</li><li>Changing religious or spiritual beliefs/following</li></ul></td></tr></tbody></table></figure>
<!-- /wp:table -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <em>See our <a href="/symptoms-of-grief">symptoms of grief</a> article for further insight -</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e4e4e4"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e4e4e4;color:#e4e4e4"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="stages">The stages of grief: what are they?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The 5 stages of grief theory was developed in 1969 by psychiatrist, <a href="https://www.ekrfoundation.org/elisabeth-kubler-ross/">Dr Kübler-Ross</a>, as a way of describing the emotional process experienced by those facing their own death.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The theory quickly gained traction and embedded itself into the public psyche as <em>the</em> model for dealing with bereavement and, in turn, became synonymous with the grieving process.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3 id="5stages">What are the 5 stages of grief?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:spacer {"height":"17px"} -->
<div style="height:17px" aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-spacer"></div>
<!-- /wp:spacer -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"background":"#fffdea","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fffdea;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Denial</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"normal"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-normal-font-size" style="color:#003946">Denial is largely considered the stage that holds back your feelings of grief. <strong>Common thoughts are simply not believing that the loss has happened or imagining another, nicer state of reality.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"normal"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-normal-font-size" style="color:#003946"><em><em>“I was convinced for months that my loved one was going to enter the room at any moment.”</em></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#f5d3d4","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f5d3d4;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Anger</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"normal"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-normal-font-size" style="color:#003946">Anger can present itself in different ways, from bitterness to blind fury. It can be directed at the person we've lost or anyone that enters our mind at that moment in time. <strong>It is often seen as a masking effect</strong>, in that other emotions may not be immediately obvious when anger’s at play.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column -->

<!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8f5ee","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#e8f5ee;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-color" id="family" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Bargaining</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-css-opacity is-style-wide"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"normal"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-normal-font-size" style="color:#003946">Bargaining has been described as <strong>a way to regain some level of control by wanting to affect the situation at hand</strong>. This usually surfaces in the form of 'what if' and 'if only' statements.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"normal"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-normal-font-size" style="color:#003946">“If only I told them…”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#f9f5f2","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f9f5f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Depression</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"normal"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-normal-font-size" style="color:#003946"><strong>A sense of isolation, sadness and a longing for previous times are typically associated with this phase.</strong> As is the theme of this article, depression can present itself in various forms, such as fatigue, despair, anxiety, not wanting to eat, eating too much, an inability or want to do anything, plus much more.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column -->

<!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#fbe0c3"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-color" id="family" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Acceptance</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"normal"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-normal-font-size" style="color:#003946"><strong>This isn't getting over your loss, but rather acknowledging it</strong> and recognising that there are better days ahead.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3 id="7stages">What are the 7 stages of grief?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Over the years, other stages have been added to Kübler-Ross’s model. <strong>You might have heard of the 7 stages of grief, which adds ‘shock and disbelief’, ‘pain and guilt’ and ‘reconstruction’ into the mix.</strong> Just as with the 5 stages, this presents itself as a linear process that is often untrue to life.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>The seven stages of grief are:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>Shock and disbelief</li><li>Pain and guilt</li><li>Anger and bargaining</li><li>Depression</li><li>The upward turn</li><li>Reconstruction</li><li>Acceptance</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:cover {"customOverlayColor":"#fff2e5","focalPoint":{"x":"0.53","y":"0.27"},"minHeight":1122,"minHeightUnit":"px","contentPosition":"center center","isDark":false,"align":"center"} -->
<div class="wp-block-cover aligncenter is-light" style="min-height:1122px"><span aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-cover__background has-background-dim-100 has-background-dim" style="background-color:#fff2e5"></span><div class="wp-block-cover__inner-container"><!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"width":""} -->
<div class="wp-block-column"></div>
<!-- /wp:column -->

<!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"center","width":"95%"} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-center" style="flex-basis:95%"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"26px"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="qa" style="color:#003946;font-size:26px"><strong>Is what I'm feeling normal? </strong><br><strong>A stages of grief Q&amp;A</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Question:</strong><br>"I’ve looked through both the 5 stages of grief and 7 stages of grief models, but I’m not experiencing that journey at all. I used to be sociable, now I keep myself to myself. I lack confidence and I cannot accept that my husband has gone.<strong> </strong><br><br><strong>It’s been over 3 years - surely I should be onto another, more acceptable stage by now? Is what I’m feeling even normal? The stages of grief suggest not.</strong>"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center","id":4170,"width":93,"height":98,"sizeSlug":"full","linkDestination":"none"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full is-resized"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/Stages-of-grief-profile.webp" alt="Profile icon" class="wp-image-4170" width="93" height="98"/></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"small"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-small-font-size" style="color:#003946">Sue, Untangle member</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Answer:</strong><br>"Stages theories of grief are present throughout popular culture. However, evidence has shown that the grieving process is ‘neither a linear nor a fixed progression of stages’.<strong> The truth is, people may never experience some of these stages. Everyone’s grief is unique to them. And most people will not experience them in that order</strong> – instead, jumping back and forth between stages. Some researchers prefer to talk about the ‘components’ of grief.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>The most important way to help yourself while grieving is to take care of yourself and your needs</strong> - being aware of how you are feeling. <br><br><strong>For many of us, talking about loss is an incredibly painful and difficult thing.</strong> It takes strength and courage to describe how you are feeling after a bereavement, and all too often, we avoid the conversation because we can’t find the right words. Do you feel this may be contributing to why you are not wanting to be around others?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"19px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:19px"><strong>Grief is a huge trauma, and you are reeling from the shock of your loss. Be patient with yourself. There is no timeline for how long grief lasts, or how you should feel after a particular time.</strong>"</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center","id":4171,"width":93,"height":98,"sizeSlug":"full","linkDestination":"none"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full is-resized"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/08/Stages-of-grief-lizzie-profile.webp" alt="Profile picture of Dr Lizzie Paddock" class="wp-image-4171" width="93" height="98"/></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"small"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-small-font-size" style="color:#003946">Dr Lizzie Paddock, Psychologist and Assistant Professor in Forensic Psychology </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join our grief community</a></strong> -</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column -->

<!-- wp:column {"width":""} -->
<div class="wp-block-column"></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e4e4e4"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e4e4e4;color:#e4e4e4"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="tonkins">Growing around your grief: Tonkins model</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Lois Tonkin is a grief counsellor who coined the term ‘growing around grief’ after counselling clients who had experienced loss.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaId":4303,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/?attachment_id=4303","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":41,"imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:41% auto"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/grief-stages-tonkins-model.webp" alt="Stages of grief: Tonkins model" class="wp-image-4303 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>She describes that rather than grief disappearing over time, it stays roughly the same, and the life of a bereaved person grows around it as they have new experiences and begin to look forward.</strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At times, that grief can feel just as painful as it did at the beginning, and at other times, it’s in the background.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>How can Tonkins model of grief help?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This frame of thinking means you can both be growing and grieving at the same time. <strong>Whilst there may always be a pang of sadness resting on your shoulder, you can make progress.</strong> Grief doesn’t go away, nor should you expect it to, but you can grow around it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Many of our members have explained that they prefer this way of thinking as it steers away from grief having an endpoint, and instead explains grief as something that forms part of our identity, ever-present throughout the good and bad moments in our lives.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e4e4e4"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e4e4e4;color:#e4e4e4"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="trusted">The stages of grief: so, can they be trusted?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you take one thing from this article, let it be that the components of the models listed are things that you <em>may</em> experience - ‘may’ being the key word.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaPosition":"right","mediaId":4317,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/?attachment_id=4317","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":41,"imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:auto 41%"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/stages-of-grief-linear.webp" alt="" class="wp-image-4317 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>In fact, Kubler-Ross herself later said that she regretted the way her model was viewed.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>This is something that David Kessler, co-author of <em>On Grief &amp; Grieving, also said, “</em></strong><em>the stages have evolved since their introduction and have been very misunderstood... <strong>They were never meant to help tuck messy emotions into neat packages.</strong> They are responses to loss that many people have, but <strong>there is no typical loss.</strong>”</em><strong><em> </em></strong><a href="https://grief.com/the-five-stages-of-grief/"><strong><em>Source</em></strong></a></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>So, in short, don’t hold yourself to these models.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>They can provide a level of comfort by showing that you’re not alone in feeling the way you do, but grief is inherently a unique experience; everyone will grieve in different ways.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946">This is where we thoroughly recommend using a <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa" data-type="URL" data-id="https://onelink.to/zka2sa" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">peer-to-peer support service</a>, offering the chance to connect with others over shared experiences means you can discuss loss instead of trying to compare yourself to a psychological theory or model.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e4e4e4"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e4e4e4;color:#e4e4e4"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="tips">How to care for yourself when grieving</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>The basics</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Listen to your body</strong>:<ul><li>If you need to rest or sleep, then do. Trauma is hard for the body to process and is tiring.</li></ul></li><li><strong>Look after yourself</strong>: <ul><li>Try to eat healthy food and get outside in nature. It won’t take the pain away but looking after your basic health will ensure you don’t make things worse for yourself.</li></ul></li><li><strong>Avoid numbing substances:</strong> <ul><li>Whilst it might feel like these take the pain away, they don’t. Instead, they delay those feelings from surfacing and extend the amount of time you spend in the ‘acute grief’ phase.</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Your behaviour</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Accept change</strong>:<ul><li>You might notice your sleeping patterns or eating patterns change in the wake of a loss. These will return to normal so don’t fret. Do what</li></ul></li><li><strong>You’re exactly where you need to be</strong>:<ul><li>Don’t feel any pressure to be or act in a certain way. Some people like to keep busy and go out lots, others stay in bed and watch TV. Do what feels right for you.</li></ul></li><li><strong>Feel your feelings</strong>:<ul><li>If you need to cry, cry. If you want to laugh, laugh. Grief is not all sadness - sometimes it’s guilt, anger, joy and even relief. Try to embrace and lean into your feelings, rather than avoiding or pushing them down.</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Your friends</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Ask for and accept help</strong>:<ul><li>If people offer to drop food round or take the kids for a few hours, take them up on it. Remember, you would do the same for them.</li></ul></li><li><strong>Try to be understanding</strong>:<ul><li>Some of your closest friends may avoid you in your grief, whilst others will surprise you with their kindness. Try not to be too angry with those who avoid you - their silence is usually because of their own discomfort around grief and death, not because they don’t love or care about you.</li></ul></li><li><strong>Be honest</strong>:<ul><li>You may feel some pressure to return to ‘normal’ because you worry your feelings may make others uncomfortable, but that will only make you feel more isolated. Open up and talk about your grief, even if it’s years from the loss. True friends will want to be there for you.</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="support">Where to find support</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Peer bereavement support</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Untangle’s app</a> can help you to meet others who have also experienced a loss and help you to feel less alone.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Education</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Read advice</strong>: <ul><li>The Untangle website has lots of free articles on grief and bereavement. Books can also be really helpful and we’ve <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/the-30-best-books-on-grief/">rounded up our 30 favourite books on grief here</a>.</li></ul></li><li><strong>Follow social media accounts</strong>:<ul><li>There are lots of brilliant Instagram accounts, subReddits and private Facebook groups on the subject of grief which can help you to understand that what you’re feeling is normal.</li></ul></li><li><strong>Listen to podcasts</strong>:<ul><li>Cariad Lloyd’s <a href="https://cariadlloyd.com/griefcast" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Griefcast</a> features interviews with famous people who have experienced grief, which can help you to realise that you’re not the first person to walk this path.</li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Therapy</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>Consider 1-2-1 therapy</strong>:<ul><li>Many people find bereavement counselling or therapy helpful to navigate the choppy waters of loss. Untangle can match you to the perfect affordable bereavement therapist. <a href="https://untangleonline.typeform.com/to/mU2OH38O">Take our quiz here to get started.</a></li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Support as a carer</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><strong>If you’re caring for an elderly parent:</strong><ul><li>Finding care homes: <a href="https://lottie.org/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Lottie</a> </li><li>At-home care: <a href="https://www.belleviecare.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Bellevie</a></li></ul></li><li><strong>Information and advice: </strong><ul><li><a href="https://www.agespace.org/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Age Space</a></li></ul></li><li><strong>If you’ve now become an unpaid carer as the result of a death:</strong> <ul><li><a href="https://www.mobiliseonline.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Mobilise</a> </li></ul></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3>Urgent support</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li>If you feel you’re in crisis, don’t delay. Call The Samaritans on UK 116 123.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946">If you want to share how you're feeling, ask questions to others who have lost or simply read their stories, head on over to the Untangle community via the <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Untangle Grief app</a>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		The symptoms of grief: what are they and how to cope?
		https://untanglegrief.com/symptoms-of-grief/
		Tue, 27 Sep 2022 17:11:32 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4410
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>To anyone who hasn’t been through a <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/what-to-do-when-someone-dies/">bereavement</a>, the symptoms of grief might seem obvious. But those of us who have experienced loss know that the symptoms go far beyond feeling sad (although there’s lots of that too) – grief affects your whole body and mind in ways that can take you by surprise.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center","id":4413,"width":413,"height":292,"sizeSlug":"full","linkDestination":"custom"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full is-resized"><a href="https://urlgeni.us/symptoms-grief-article"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/symptoms-of-grief-poll.webp" alt="Symptoms of grief poll" class="wp-image-4413" width="413" height="292"/></a></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We talk a lot about our grief symptoms at Untangle, and if we’ve learnt one thing from a recent poll on our community, it’s that everyone’s journey is unique. We're also acutely aware of the stigma surrounding death and grief, and that finding good advice can be hard - so, here, we’re listing some of the most common symptoms our community has experienced, along with tips on how to best manage those symptoms…</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e4e4e4"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e4e4e4;color:#e4e4e4"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Jump to section:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><a href="#emotional">Emotional symptoms</a></li><li><a href="#physical">Physical symptoms</a></li><li><a href="#cognitive">Cognitive symptoms</a></li><li><a href="#faqs">FAQs</a></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e4e4e4"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e4e4e4;color:#e4e4e4"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="emotional">The emotional symptoms of grief </h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>What does grief feel like?</strong> There are <em>so many</em> emotional symptoms of grief and they tend to come in waves. One day you might be feeling terribly lonely, and the next you could be overcome with anger at the unfairness of it all. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>These are just some of the emotions you may experience…</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#f5d3d4","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f5d3d4;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Anger</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>It’s completely normal to feel angry about no longer having your loved one around. </strong><br><br>It can feel so unfair that the world is still turning, yet the person you miss is no longer here. This can surface as blaming someone or something - it’s a way of trying to release some of the pain trapped inside of you.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column -->

<!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8f5ee","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#e8f5ee;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" id="family" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Depression</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-css-opacity is-style-wide"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">"<em><em>The fatigue and overwhelming sadness are all-encompassing.”</em></em> Viki, Untangle member</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Sadness, despair and depression are the overriding emotions </strong>we feel when grieving, and they take on a whole new meaning when you’re missing someone you love.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"background":"#fffdea","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fffdea;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Guilt</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Guilt is a powerful emotion. It can isolate us and alter how we look at the world. <strong>When linked to bereavement, guilt is often a burden we put on ourselves rather than something that others make us feel.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Realistic guilt exists when we have done something we knew was wrong, but we may also unrealistically blame ourselves for things over which we have no control. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Guilt causes us to punish ourselves and keeps us focused on the past. <strong>You may find it helpful to look at Lois Tonkin’s ‘<a href="/stages-of-grief/">Growing around Grief</a>’ metaphor.</strong> This is a helpful way of thinking about moving forwards with your grief. Although it doesn’t ever completely go away, the painful feelings come less often. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>And remember, just because you feel guilty doesn’t mean you are guilty.  </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#f9f5f2","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f9f5f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Numbness</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Months - heck, even years after losing a loved one - shock can take over. <strong>This can lead to numbness; as if all of your emotions have been dulled or tuned out.</strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"normal"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-normal-font-size" style="color:#003946">This in some way acts as an emotional shield, enabling you to carry on with the stresses of life after loss. That said, numbness can be an incredibly frustrating experience, in that it can make you question your own view of relationships (as was my experience). </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column -->

<!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#fbe0c3"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" id="family" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Loneliness</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Grief can be very isolating. Not only have you lost a loved one, but it can feel as though those around you don’t understand what you’re going through, particularly if your close circle hasn’t experienced loss before.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}},"fontSize":"normal"} -->
<p class="has-text-color has-normal-font-size" style="color:#003946"><strong>Loneliness, sadly, is all too common after the death of a loved one.</strong> Even if others rally around to offer support, it's easy to feel alone in your crowd. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"background":"#cee6f2","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#cee6f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Relief</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Feeling relieved after someone has passed doesn’t mean you didn’t care or that you loved them any less. Some Untangle members have stated that they felt a sense of relief, having cared for a loved one for such a long time; others have stated that it was time for their loved one to go after battling an illness. Put simply, every relationship is different; every loss is unique.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em><strong>“I felt a great sense of relief after she passed- I loved her so much, but towards the end, I felt tied to a person I didn't recognise as her. It’s such a bittersweet feeling.”</strong></em><br>Jamie, Untangle member</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","level":3} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-center" id="stages"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">How to cope with the emotional symptoms of grief</span></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Whether it’s anger, guilt or depression you’re feeling after a bereavement, it may be a good idea to explore grief counselling to help you work through difficult emotions. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>We suggest taking a look at <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/grief-counselling-advice/">the different types of bereavement therapy available</a>, and then using our <a href="https://untangleonline.typeform.com/to/mU2OH38O" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">free therapist matching service</a> to find the right style of counselling for your needs.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaId":4433,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/grief-symptoms-support/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":47,"imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:47% auto"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/grief-symptoms-support.webp" alt="Support group having coffee" class="wp-image-4433 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>As well as getting professional advice, it’s helpful to have a support network you can talk to</strong>. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Turn to friends and family members you can trust, and be honest and open about how you’re feeling. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Sometimes, after a bereavement, the people who are there for us might be the ones we least expect.</strong> That’s okay; embrace these friendships. You deserve kindness and compassion right now.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center"><strong>Look to support groups and communities that can relate.</strong> Untangle was built entirely to help you – and others who are grieving – feel less alone at the most difficult times in your life. Our community is there for you 24 hours a day, 7 days a week.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <a href="http://onelink.to/zka2sa" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><strong>Download the Untangle app to get started</strong></a> -</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e4e4e4"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e4e4e4;color:#e4e4e4"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2 id="physical">The physical symptoms of grief</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>With how intense losing someone can be, it’s not surprising that, alongside emotional symptoms, there are many physical symptoms of grief. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>From aches, and tiredness, to digestive issues, these are some of the side effects you may be experiencing...</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#cee6f2","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#cee6f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Aches &amp; pains</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">There are many reasons aches and pains can crop up or worsen when you’re grieving. It’s a mixture of tiredness; lack of routine; tensions that tighten up your muscles; and deep sadness that feels all-consuming. <br><br><strong>You might get more headaches than usual, or a recurring bad back problem could heighten (more so than it has before).</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column -->

<!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8f5ee","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#e8f5ee;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" id="family" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Fatigue</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-css-opacity is-style-wide"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Fatigue is common with intense grief, as both shock and sadness can exhaust your body.When you become so run down, it’s easier to pick up more illnesses (your immune system isn’t as reactive as it was before). If you notice you get sick more often now, grief fatigue <em>could</em> be one of the reasons.<br><br><strong><em>“When my husband first died in November I couldn’t eat for months, had water infections, vomiting and slept around the clock."</em></strong> @ericagh21.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"background":"#f5d3d4","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f5d3d4;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Panic attacks</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Think of all that you’re going through; it’s no wonder that your ‘fight or flight’ response might kick in. <br><br><strong>You may notice there are certain triggers for these attacks</strong>, such as if you go somewhere that meant something to your loved one or when <a href="https://community.untanglegrief.com/articles/40">dealing with someone’s belongings after they’ve died</a>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#f9f5f2","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f9f5f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"32px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:32px"><strong>Insomnia</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Even if you feel exhausted, it's still possible to experience insomnia.</strong> Sure, you’re tired, but sleep is seemingly impossible whilst processing a whole new reality. <br><br>When you’re left alone with your thoughts, it’s not uncommon to go over and over (and over) them, trying to make sense of a world without your loved one.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column -->

<!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#fbe0c3"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"32px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" id="family" style="color:#003946;font-size:32px"><strong>Digestive issues</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">If your eating habits have changed as a result of grief, or your body just feels extremely run down, you might experience vomiting, nausea and digestive issues. <br><br><strong><em>“The first two weeks I had a lot of digestive problems,” explains @amberranae0974. “I also had panic attacks. My doctor gave me meds and they helped.”</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","level":3} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-center"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">How to cope with the physical symptoms of grief</span></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>While medicines can help with pain relief and insomnia (and are worth talking to your doctor about), <strong>it’s also important to keep nurturing your body with food, exercise and routine.</strong> We’re creatures of habit, after all. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This can be easier said than done – all sense of schedule can go out of the window when after loss – but try reintroducing a routine with small steps. <strong>Take it day by day.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>You could begin by deciding that, for a whole week, you’re going to get out in nature for a 20-minute walk each day. Exercise not only boosts serotonin, but exposure to daylight can also regulate your body clock, so you may sleep better at night.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaId":4440,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/symptoms-grief-walk/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":47,"imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:47% auto"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/symptoms-grief-walk.webp" alt="Man walking in a park" class="wp-image-4440 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>One of our members mentioned that going on daily walks wasn’t just time for exercise, but also for connection:<strong> </strong><br><br></strong><em>“A friend who had lost her daughter told me to start running or walking. </em><em>I initially thought this was ridiculous as the last thing I wanted to do was get fit but realised this was my time with her. I would listen to her videos and her favourite songs.”</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>For the next week, decide whether you’re ready to make another routine improvement. If you are, put the focus on food and giving your body the vitamins it needs to handle grief.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Keeping yourself well nourished can help with sleeping issues, aches and pains, as well as digestive issues. </strong>We know how difficult it can be to take care of yourself when your world has turned upside down, that’s why we asked Nutritional Therapist, Joanne Crovini, to offer <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/event/eating-well-after-a-loss/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">advice on how to eat well after a loss</a>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e4e4e4"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e4e4e4;color:#e4e4e4"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-left" id="cognitive">The cognitive symptoms of grief</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left"><strong>‘Grief brain’ or ‘grief fog’ is a real thing.</strong> When you’re coping with grief, trying to concentrate on anything else can feel almost impossible. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left">Here are some of the signs that grief is affecting your day-to-day cognitive function…</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaPosition":"right","mediaId":4471,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/grief-symptoms-confused/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":47,"imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:auto 47%"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/grief-symptoms-confused.webp" alt="Confused woman on phone" class="wp-image-4471 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>Confusion</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Suddenly, everything feels so confusing. <strong>Even if you’re usually good at understanding documents, the sheer amount of ‘grief admin’ you have to go through can leave you completely overwhelmed.</strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Companies don’t always make this easy either (see <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/what-to-do-when-someone-dies/">what to do when someone dies</a>), which is why seeking support can be an important first step when it feels like your brain is more scattered than usual.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#003946"}},"className":"is-style-dots"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-dots" style="background-color:#003946;color:#003946"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaId":4472,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/grief-symptoms-concentration/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":47,"imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:47% auto"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/grief-symptoms-concentration.webp" alt="Woman struggling to concentrate" class="wp-image-4472 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>Lack of concentration</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Don’t be hard on yourself if you’re finding it difficult to pay attention to… well, anything.</strong> It’s a natural response to grief, and your mind has a lot to process right now.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>“Mentally I'm a mess, I forget things, I don't concentrate, I cry every day, my anxiety is terrible, I'm not me anymore,” says @jay.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:spacer {"height":"12px"} -->
<div style="height:12px" aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-spacer"></div>
<!-- /wp:spacer -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#003946"}},"className":"is-style-dots"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-dots" style="background-color:#003946;color:#003946"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaPosition":"right","mediaId":4474,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/grief-symptoms-forgetful/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":47,"imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:auto 47%"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/09/grief-symptoms-forgetful.webp" alt="Woman holding head in hands" class="wp-image-4474 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>Forgetfulness</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Just as you might be finding it hard to concentrate, <strong>you may catch yourself forgetting things more often too.</strong> Again, this is because your brain is overwhelmed with the many thoughts and emotions you’re coping with.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>“I had to take leave from my job for several months because I was making mistakes and forgetting, and I was afraid of being fired,” @birrrdegg says.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","level":3} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-center"><span style="text-decoration: underline;">How to deal with the cognitive symptoms of grief</span></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>The cognitive symptoms of grief can have the biggest effect on your work, so don’t be afraid to have some honest conversations with your employers and colleagues if you’re struggling.</strong> Take a look at our <a href="/bereavement-guides/">Bereavement &amp; Work guides</a> for more advice on this, including <a href="/returning-to-work-after-a-bereavement/">returning to work after a loss</a>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>These cognitive symptoms can also be frustrating when you’ve got lots of ‘grief admin’ to tackle, so take a look at our guide on <a href="/what-to-do-when-someone-dies/">what to do when someone dies</a> for step-by-step advice. Think of it like a checklist that you can tick off as and when you feel ready. Take it at your own pace, and don’t hesitate to ask for help along the way.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This frame of thinking means you can both be growing and grieving at the same time. <strong>Whilst there may always be a ping of sadness resting on your shoulder, you can make progress.</strong> Grief doesn’t go away, nor should you expect it to, but you can grow around it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e4e4e4"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e4e4e4;color:#e4e4e4"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946">If you want to share how you're feeling, ask questions to others who have lost or simply read their stories, head on over to the Untangle community via the <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Untangle Grief app</a>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e4e4e4"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e4e4e4;color:#e4e4e4"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center" id="faqs">FAQs</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:group {"layout":{"type":"default"}} -->

<div class="wp-block-accordion-toggle-accordion-toggle"><div class="eb-parent-wrapper eb-parent-eb-accordion-hcmjt8d "><div class="eb-accordion-container eb-accordion-hcmjt8d" data-accordion-type="accordion" data-tab-icon="fas fa-angle-right" data-expanded-icon="fas fa-angle-down"><div class="eb-accordion-inner"><div class="eb-accordion-wrapper" data-clickable="false"><div class="eb-accordion-title-wrapper"><span class="eb-accordion-icon-wrapper"><span class="fas fa-angle-right eb-accordion-icon"></span></span><h3 class="eb-accordion-title">How long do the physical symptoms of grief last?</h3></div><div class="eb-accordion-content-wrapper"><p class="eb-accordion-content">The truth is, there is no one-size-fits-all answer. Everyone’s experience of grief is different. For some, it never truly ends but becomes more manageable over time as they learn to live alongside grief. This is true for the physical, emotional <em>and</em> cognitive symptoms.<br><br>See our ‘<a href="https://untanglegrief.com/how-long-does-grief-last">How long does grief last?</a>’ article for further insight.</p></div></div><div class="eb-accordion-wrapper" data-clickable="false"><div class="eb-accordion-title-wrapper"><span class="eb-accordion-icon-wrapper"><span class="fas fa-angle-right eb-accordion-icon"></span></span><h3 class="eb-accordion-title">What does grief do to your body?</h3></div><div class="eb-accordion-content-wrapper"><p class="eb-accordion-content">Grief is physically exhausting, and an exhausted body doesn’t function at its best. This is why you might experience headaches, muscle aches, extreme tiredness, insomnia and even digestive issues. When you’re run down, your immune system is also affected, so you may catch colds or infections more easily. This is why being kind to yourself through grief is so important.</p></div></div><div class="eb-accordion-wrapper" data-clickable="false"><div class="eb-accordion-title-wrapper"><span class="eb-accordion-icon-wrapper"><span class="fas fa-angle-right eb-accordion-icon"></span></span><h3 class="eb-accordion-title">Can grief make you physically unwell? </h3></div><div class="eb-accordion-content-wrapper"><p class="eb-accordion-content">Yes. A lot of Untangle members have talked about feeling sick and nauseous when going through the stages of grief, and it’s no surprise – stress and trauma are a lot for your body to handle. Be kind to yourself when you’re struggling, and speak to a doctor if you feel like your symptoms are unmanageable.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
