		What to say to someone grieving: the dos and don'ts
		https://untanglegrief.com/what-to-say-someone-grieving/
		Wed, 12 Oct 2022 11:41:39 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4520
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Unless you’ve experienced grief, it can be hard to know what to say when someone dies.</strong> In fact, even if you’re grieving yourself, words of comfort don’t always come easily. Ultimately, it’s a sensitive and challenging time, and the pressure to say ‘just the right thing’ can be overwhelming. So here’s our guide on what to say when someone dies. We hope it helps…</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Jump to section:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><a href="#recent">Upon hearing the news of a recent loss</a></li><li><a href="#after">After time has passed</a></li><li><a href="#not">What not to say when someone dies</a></li><li><a href="#grief">A note on grief</a></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","fontSize":"large"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-large-font-size"><strong>What to say to someone who is grieving</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>First things first: it’s better to say <em>something</em> than say nothing at all, so don’t go silent on someone coping with grief.</strong> Radio silence can often be more hurtful than saying the ‘wrong’ words. You’re not always going to get it exactly right, but checking in just after a loss, and in the time that follows, can help your friend or family member feel a little less alone.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"background":"#fffdea","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fffdea;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="recent"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Upon hearing the news of a recent loss</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Say things like:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“I’m so sorry for your loss/I’m so sad to hear about your loss.”</strong> - This is a simple yet meaningful way to start sympathy messages or conversations with someone who’s grieving.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“Can I do anything to help?”</strong> - The person who has recently lost will be struggling right now, so help from friends and family is more important than ever. If you can, make specific offers, such as “I’m going to the shops, can I get you anything?” or “would you like me to look after the kids today?”</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“I remember when…”</strong> - If you know them, talk about the person who has died. Share a favourite memory of them with their loved ones. It could be a funny joke they once told you or a time they helped you when you needed it most.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“I’m thinking of you.”</strong> - Like “I’m sorry for your loss”, this is a simple line you can include in a text message, as it lets your friend or family member know you’re there for them when they need you.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“How are you?”</strong> - You already know the answer to this one – of course, they’re feeling terrible. However, by asking them, you’re creating an opportunity for them to open up.&nbsp;<br>Sending a card? Take a look at our advice on <a href="/bereavement-cards/">how to write a bereavement card</a>, which has plenty of ideas and inspiration for writing a meaningful message.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join Untangle's grief community</a></strong> - </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#cee6f2"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#cee6f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="after"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>After time has passed</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">It might feel like the early stages of grief are when your words and actions are needed the most, but <a href="/stages-of-grief/">grief isn’t linear</a>, and the months and years that follow are just as important.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>This is something we hear a lot in the Untangle community: although grief doesn’t disappear once the funeral is over; often, well wishes do.</strong> This lack of acknowledgement can make those grieving feel isolated and like they can’t talk honestly about how they’re feeling.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:spacer {"height":"30px"} -->
<div style="height:30px" aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-spacer"></div>
<!-- /wp:spacer -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaId":4549,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/instagram-what-to-say-when-someone-dies/","linkDestination":"custom","mediaType":"image","imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide is-stacked-on-mobile"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><a href="instagram.com/p/ChHskJasqAZ/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/instagram-what-to-say-when-someone-dies.webp" alt="Untangle Grief instagram post" class="wp-image-4549 size-full"/></a></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"16px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:16px"><em>"They left the grief train after the first stop: the funeral. If I'm being truly honest, I'll never forgive them for that. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"16px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:16px"><em>I actually raised the fact nobody reached out over the last 4 years to a close friend. His response? 'How are we supposed to know?...'</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"16px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:16px"><em>I personally think that's a load of sh**."</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"16px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:16px"><em><a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/ChHskJasqAZ/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Ryan, Untangle's Grief Stories, vol 1</a></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:spacer {"height":"21px"} -->
<div style="height:21px" aria-hidden="true" class="wp-block-spacer"></div>
<!-- /wp:spacer -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>What can you do?</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Show up for them.</strong> Remember wedding and death anniversaries, birthdays and other dates of note (such as Mother’s Day or Father’s Day). It will mean so much to them. You could reach out with a card and flowers, or just a simple message on the day. Or <strong>how about offering to take them somewhere to commemorate their loved one(s)?&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">It’s not just special dates that matter, either. <strong>It’s easy to feel apprehensive about mentioning someone who has died - after all, are you reminding people that they’re gone? The answer to this is no</strong>: they don’t need reminding; their loved one is always on their mind. By giving them the space to talk about them, you can help them to process grief.&nbsp;&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Say things like:&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“How are you?”</strong> - This one is so important both straight after a loss as well as in the time that follows. Those who are grieving don’t always feel comfortable bringing up their sadness, so invite them to express their feelings as time goes on. Then, when they answer, really listen to what they have to say. <strong>Don’t offer solutions</strong> (unless they ask you to); instead, acknowledge their emotions and the fact that it’s hard for them.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“I just wanted to let you know that I’m thinking of you on their birthday/your anniversary/this Mother’s or Father’s Day.”</strong> - This message can apply to any important date, including a <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/death-anniversary/">death anniversary</a>. You may want to send a card at this time. Remain consistent with this too; don’t simply mark the many ‘firsts’, but reach out each year so they know their loved one isn’t forgotten.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“I just saw X and it made me think of the time Y…”</strong> - A message like this, any time, can mean so much to someone who is grieving. <strong>If you see a reminder of their loved one, let them know.</strong> Stories, memories and jokes are treasures to them.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join Untangle's grief community</a></strong> - </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:group -->
<div class="wp-block-group"><!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#f9f5f2"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f9f5f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="not"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>What not to say when someone dies</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">We asked the Untangle community to <a href="https://urlgeni.us/what-to-say-poll" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">vote on the worst things people say to those who are grieving</a>, and most agreed that “you’ll get over it” is the hardest to hear, closely followed by “time’s a good healer”, then “don’t be sad”.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center","id":4581,"width":397,"height":280,"sizeSlug":"full","linkDestination":"custom"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full is-resized"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/poll-what-to-say-to-someone-grieving.webp" alt="What to say to someone who is grieving poll" class="wp-image-4581" width="397" height="280"/></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Our members also shared a few extra ‘no-nos’. </strong><strong>So here are the things you shouldn’t say to someone who is grieving…</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“At least…” </strong>- There is no ‘at least’ when someone is grieving. Their person is gone and it’s heartbreaking, so no ‘silver linings’ are going to suddenly make that feel okay.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“I know how you feel.” </strong>- Even if you’ve experienced loss, don’t try to compare your grief with someone else’s. Every experience is unique, and comparing situations can make them feel somewhat trivial.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“Don’t be sad.”</strong> - Or anything similar. Even if years have passed since the loss, telling someone that they shouldn’t be sad doesn’t achieve anything - it only makes them feel shamed or misunderstood. You might find that they talk to you less about their grief because they’re worried about being judged.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center","id":4590,"width":389,"height":389,"sizeSlug":"full","linkDestination":"custom"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full is-resized"><a href="https://www.instagram.com/untanglegrief/" target="_blank" rel="noopener"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/10/what-to-say-when-someone-dies-bingo.webp" alt="Grief bingo: what to say when someone dies" class="wp-image-4590" width="389" height="389"/></a></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“Everything happens for a reason.”</strong> - If you’re wondering what to say when someone dies unexpectedly, avoid this line. In fact, avoid it regardless. It can be hurtful to hear, as it implies the death of a loved one was ‘meant to happen’.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“I don’t know how you’re doing this.”</strong> - Some say this can make their grief feel bigger and unmanageable. It can also make them feel isolated, unable to vocalise their true feelings, due to both perception and a knowing that others are unable to empathise.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“Time’s a good healer.”</strong> - this is predicated on grief getting easier over time. It also adds an element of pressure to feel okay with the passing of time. This is wrong. Every relationship is different; every loss is unique. Grief doesn’t just get easier because another year has passed. For more info on this, check out our stages of grief article.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>“They’re in a better place now.”</strong> - While this may comfort some, depending on their religious beliefs, many say this is one of the hardest things to hear. <a href="/grieving-different-religions/">Grieving is different across cultures</a>, so be sure to know people’s beliefs before you make a statement like this. In other words, the use of this is not advised.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns --></div>
<!-- /wp:group -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center" id="grief">An important note on grief...</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Everyone’s experience of grief is unique</strong>, so while these tips are meant to help you comfort your loved one, you may find the support they need looks different to the words on this page. That’s okay – <strong>keep the lines of communication open and accept that, sometimes, you might just say the wrong thing.</strong> As long as your intentions are good and you really listen to your loved one, you can help them through their most difficult times.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>And, if you’re really unsure, keep your words simple, <strong>don’t try to hurry them through the <a href="/stages-of-grief/" data-type="post">stages of grief</a></strong>, and don’t try to fix things. Showing up and letting them know you care is the most important thing of all.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Lastly, do recommend a grief community - we have dedicated support spaces that aim to connect people over shared experiences of loss. </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946">For more advice and to connect with others who share a similar experience of loss, download the <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Untangle Grief app</a>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left"><em>Do let us know if there’s anything you feel should be added to this 'what to say to someone who is grieving' guide</em> - the more useful advice, the better.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		The marking of time: life after caring
		https://untanglegrief.com/life-after-caring/
		Tue, 15 Nov 2022 15:21:56 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4674
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center"><em>By Annabel James, founder of <a href="https://www.agespace.org/" data-type="URL" data-id="https://www.agespace.org/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Age Space</a></em>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The weekend after Mum’s funeral my 83-year-old Dad and I went out and bought new saucepans. Not what Dad would have had on his to-do list, but we didn’t really know what to do with ourselves, how to fill the time, and it would have been an outing Mum would have enjoyed.&nbsp; The start of some strange times, and the end of some strange times too. &nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Married for 60 years, their last decade together saw Mum’s health decline following a stroke.&nbsp; During that time Dad moved seamlessly from husband to that of super hero (my words not his) - <strong>general factotum</strong> with multiple roles including <strong>full-time carer</strong>. Also, <strong>personal assistant</strong> making appointments, sorting medication, doing paperwork; <strong>chief entertainment officer</strong> in charge of daily laughter, often after some medical mishap; <strong>head of logistics</strong> organising outings to friends, the hairdresser or just an afternoon drive on quiet days, usually with an ice-cream stop; <strong>quartermaster</strong> doing the shopping, paying the bills and running the hoover round;&nbsp; as <strong>constant companion</strong> to help with the fiddly business of socks and shoes, and <strong>transport manager</strong> helping her on and off the stairlift. He embraced them all with gusto and 100% enthusiasm for the task, whatever it was.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>After Mum died his grief was not only for the loss of his beloved wife, but for the loss of all those roles his life had become. &nbsp;Initially the routine was perhaps quite similar as he threw himself into the administration and paperwork of death of which - thank goodness - there is a mountain. Her <a href="/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/">funeral</a> was a labour of love with no detail left to chance.&nbsp; He spent weeks writing letters to everyone who called or wrote or delivered meals and flowers.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Over weeks and months, Dad sorted through Mum’s <a href="/belongings-after-a-death/">clothes and possessions</a>. He called her friends and family regularly, picking up where she had left off.&nbsp; The house adaptations and mobility aids were eventually returned from whence they came.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>He started lunches with a fellow widower in the village. He went to a bereavement coffee morning at the local hospice which much to his surprise he found a great comfort.&nbsp; He visited Mum’s grave and came to enjoy spending time choosing flowers for her. &nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaId":4678,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/?attachment_id=4678","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":47,"imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:47% auto"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Annabel-James-agespace-with-dad.webp" alt="Annabel James, founder of Agespace, with her dad" class="wp-image-4678 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Slowly, life took on a new shape. He resumed old hobbies and adopted new projects that he’d not had time to do while he was juggling all those roles. He went on holiday and visited friends and family. His role of chief mourner slowly morphed into that of widower, and whilst it wasn’t overly merry, life did perk up.&nbsp; </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If he was to give any advice or words of wisdom about life after caring for a spouse, partner, relative or friend, I think he would say three things: firstly, that time really became his enemy.&nbsp; Having had a decade of too little of it, after Mum died there was just far too much of it – so retaining a little bit more time for himself while she was alive may have been a good thing.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Secondly, he’d say that grief is a labour of love and a testament to the person who has died and your relationship with them.&nbsp; As such, the process of death, the funeral, the sorting, the memories, are memorials to that person.&nbsp; Embrace the rituals of death and grief for the person you loved.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Thirdly he’d say that shopping for saucepans probably won’t help with anything except the cooking, but whatever gets you through the day.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946"><strong>Annabel James is the founder of <a href="http://www.agespace.org/care">Agespace.org</a> - <em>the one-stop online resource for anyone caring about elderly parents and relatives.</em></strong><em>  The website is packed with useful information, resources and signposting to the best services and products for every stage of elderly care</em><strong><em>.</em></strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:image {"align":"center","id":4681,"width":251,"height":145,"sizeSlug":"full","linkDestination":"custom"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image aligncenter size-full is-resized"><a href="https://agespace.org"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Agespace-logo.webp" alt="" class="wp-image-4681" width="251" height="145"/></a></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->

		https://untanglegrief.com/funeral-wake/
		Tue, 15 Nov 2022 17:51:29 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4691
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Are you planning a funeral wake, or attending one? No matter your role at this difficult time, we’ve got advice to help you navigate a wake and celebrate your loved one’s life in the most meaningful way…</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Jump to section:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><a href="#info">Some important info: costs, do you need one, how much?</a></li><li><a href="#organise">How to organise a wake</a></li><li><a href="#behave">How to behave at a wake</a></li><li><a href="#being-there">A note on being there for someone</a></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#f9f5f2"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f9f5f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="info"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Some important info</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">What is a wake?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">A wake is a gathering that can take place before or after a <a href="/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/">funeral</a>. At a traditional wake, you would visit the body of the person who has died before the funeral service begins. However, <strong>it’s now common for a wake to be more of a reception after the funeral</strong>; a chance to talk with loved ones, share memories, and support one another. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">Do you have to have a wake?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">No, you don’t have to host a wake. Like the funeral itself, it’s completely optional, but some prefer to organise one in order to get friends and family together before or after the funeral service. That said, if you don’t feel you want to, that’s completely fine as well. If you’re just unsure, weigh up the pros and cons, and don’t be pressured into doing anything you’re uncomfortable with.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">How much does a wake cost?</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">The cost of a wake will vary depending on the venue you choose, the food and drink you serve, the decor you put up, and the number of people you decide to invite. <strong>To give you an idea, that the average ‘send-off cost’ in the UK in 2021 was £2,484</strong>. This includes the wake/memorial service and other ‘non-essential’ add-ons, such as catering and flowers.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join Untangle's grief community</a></strong> - </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#cee6f2"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#cee6f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="organise"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>How to organise a wake or funeral reception</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">Decide who you're going to invite:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>First of all, ask yourself, do you want the wake to be public or private? </strong>If you prefer, you can keep it small and intimate by only asking your closest family and friends to attend a get-together in your home or at a restaurant. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">You can also make it a bigger event by inviting everyone who attends the funeral, or perhaps keep the funeral small and ask people to come to the wake instead. Make a list of everyone you’d like to have there before you do anything else. <strong>Often, you can combine the funeral and wake guest lists into one. </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">Consider which wake venues suit your needs:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Next, decide how formal or informal you want your loved one’s wake to be, then <strong>choose a venue to fit the mood, as well as the expected headcount</strong>. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Some of the places you could consider include:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li><strong>The funeral home</strong>: a convenient choice that means you won’t have to make extra travel arrangements. This is especially appropriate if there will be a viewing at the wake.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>A house</strong>: your own, a relative’s, a friend’s, or the home of the person who has passed away.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>A pub, hotel or restaurant</strong>: ideal for a wake reception that takes place after the funeral. Some of these venues will allow you to hire out a room for privacy.</li><li><strong>A town hall, sports centre or community centre:</strong> these spaces are often available for last-minute bookings, and they’re ideal for a larger post-funeral wake.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">Share details with friends and family:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Let friends and family know when and where the wake will take place. If it’s a large group, we recommend providing details with an invitation, via email, or using Facebook Events. This will save you the time and effort of reaching out to people individually, which can be an overwhelming task if the guestlist is particularly long. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">However, if you’re hosting a small, intimate gathering, a quick, informal text message or phone call will do. <strong>Loved ones can also help you spread the word if you’re finding it difficult to speak to people.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">Arrange for food and drinks to be served:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Food is optional at a wake, but it tends to be served more often than not, so think about the kinds of things your friends and family might enjoy. <strong>It doesn’t need to be a meal</strong> – just snacks/canapés and drinks are usually enough. You could cook yourself, but to save yourself the stress, we recommend asking a friend to help or hiring a caterer. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Many venues will already have catering options available</strong> – especially if you choose to have the wake at a restaurant, hotel or pub<span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, &quot;Segoe UI&quot;, Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, &quot;Helvetica Neue&quot;, sans-serif;">.</span></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">Add personal touches to commemorate them:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">You may want to add personal touches to the venue decor. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Here are just some of the ways you can pay tribute to your loved one at a wake:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li><strong>Decorate the room with their favourite flowers or something that feels distinctly ‘them’.</strong> For example, you could put up memorabilia from their all-time best-loved sports team.</li><li><strong>Compile a playlist of your loved one’s favourite songs or <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/funeral-songs/">funeral songs</a> for background music.</strong> You could even arrange for live music if your budget and the venue allow.&nbsp;&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Place photos around the room of your loved one.</strong> If possible, you could include snaps of them with people who you know are attending the wake.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Arrange a memory jar with pen and paper so guests can write down stories for you to keep.</strong> It might feel too difficult to read them right away, but one day you may be glad of all the memories.&nbsp;</li><li><strong>Create a slideshow or video</strong> that you could present at some point during the wake, or ask a creative friend to put something special together.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join Untangle's grief community</a></strong> - </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:group -->
<div class="wp-block-group"><!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#fff2e5"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fff2e5;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="behave"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>How to behave at a wake</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Maybe you’re not planning a wake, but instead attending your first one. If that's the case, here’s some advice to help you get through the day…</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">Let loved ones know if you’re attending:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>If you’re wondering whether you should attend the wake after a funeral, the simple answer is: it’s up to you. </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">It’s not compulsory, so if you have other commitments, you can politely excuse yourself. It’s respectful to let the person arranging the wake know whether or not you can attend – especially if they’re arranging food and drink.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">Politely introduce yourself if needed:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">If you don’t know many people at the wake, consider introducing yourself. This is common if the person who has died was, for example, a work friend whose family you never got to meet. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">When the time feels right, say ‘hi’ to family and close friends and tell them how you know their loved one. It’s nice to offer your condolences, and you could even share a (tasteful!) memory or story.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">If you're really unsure what to say, check out our guide on <a href="/what-to-say-someone-grieving/" data-type="post">what to say to someone grieving</a>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">Come with a card and a small, meaningful gift:</h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Bringing a gift to a wake is not required, but it’s a kind and appreciated gesture</strong>. It doesn’t need to be big; a <a href="/bereavement-cards/">sympathy card</a>, flowers, food or photos are thoughtful ways to <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/remembering-a-loved-one/">commemorate the person who has died</a>. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Donating to a charity they cared about is another touching tribute, or you could contribute to the funeral fund to show your support to the family.&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px">Keep showing up after the funeral and wake:</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Grief doesn’t end when the funeral is over.</strong> In fact, often, grief never ends. That’s why, if you feel able, it’s important to keep showing up for loved ones long after the last glass of wine has been served at the wake. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join Untangle's grief community</a></strong> - </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#f2f7ff"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f2f7ff;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="being-there"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>A note on being there for others</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Everyone’s experience of grief is unique</strong>, but one thing that we hear often is that many people disappear after the funeral. If you can, show your support to those grieving. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Here are some actions that have stayed with Untangle's members: </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>“I have one very good friend who will just show up with coffee, or snacks, packed lunches, small little gifts, and say “I know you’re busy with school (first-semester nursing), but I wanted to drop this off for you.” And then she leaves bc she knows I need time alone. I thank God for her.”</em> – Christine</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#003946"}},"className":"is-style-dots"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-dots" style="background-color:#003946;color:#003946"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>“My friend and her now fiancé helped me tremendously with my yearly car inspection. I couldn't do it without them.”</em> – Najti</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#003946"}},"className":"is-style-dots"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-dots" style="background-color:#003946;color:#003946"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>“Listened. My team at work helped carry the load for a year. They made me laugh yet listened to my stories of her. They also bought me a plant and a tree in her name. They let me be what I was when I was.”</em> – Charity</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#003946"}},"className":"is-style-dots"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-dots" style="background-color:#003946;color:#003946"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>“Cried with me, unashamedly. Made sure I ate something. Let me sleep in and took mum's dog out for a walk for me. Listened and told me that everything I was feeling was normal and ok. FaceTimed me from out of the country to just tell me they’re here for me.”</em> – Lissa</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" style="color:#003946"><strong>- <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join Untangle's grief community</a> - </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns --></div>

		Channeling grief into good
		https://untanglegrief.com/channeling-grief-into-good/
		Tue, 22 Nov 2022 23:40:41 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4729
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When I was 15, my Mum was diagnosed with an aggressive form of stomach cancer. Turns out, the doctors had been ignoring her symptoms for a couple of years because she didn’t have the typical risk factors for someone with cancer. She wasn’t overweight, didn’t smoke or drink, and this particular form of cancer doesn’t run in the family - so they weren’t looking for it.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I remember her sitting down to tell us one day in February after school. “I’ve got cancer” she told us, “but don’t worry. I’m going to have treatment and surgery and everything will be fine”.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I believed her. I didn’t know any differently and had never had any experiences with cancer before. I wasn’t prepared for what happened over the coming weeks and months.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Mum started chemo and swiftly started to lose her hair, and as the weight fell off of her it became obvious that this was really serious. We didn’t know just how serious until just three months later our Dad sat us down to tell us “Mum won’t make it through the week”.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This was the first time I realised I was going to have to face life without my Mum. That I would have to go through all my teenage milestones - like having my first boyfriend, doing my A levels and applying to University - without her by my side.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>She died just three days later, at home with her four children and surrounded by family.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:quote {"style":{"color":{"background":"#cbe9da"}},"className":"is-style-default","fontSize":"medium"} -->
<blockquote class="wp-block-quote is-style-default has-background has-medium-font-size" style="background-color:#cbe9da"><p>This was the first time I realised I was going to have to face life without my Mum. That I would have to go through all my teenage milestones - like having my first boyfriend, doing my A levels and applying to University - without her by my side.</p></blockquote>
<!-- /wp:quote -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There's never a good time to lose your Mum, let alone when you’re a teenager going through your GCSE exams. I was pulled out of my Maths exam to be at home with Mum when she died, and I went back into school the next day to take another exam.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As the eldest of four children, with my younger sister being just 9 years old at the time, I ended up taking on a lot of adult responsibility very early on. Not only was I having to contend with the loss of my main attachment figure, I also had to focus on my education and taking the next steps to get through exams and into Sixth Form to do my A levels whilst also picking up a lot of slack at home while my Dad was struggling with his own grief. I’d be responsible for cooking, cleaning and looking after my siblings. There wasn’t a lot of room for my grief.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>So I struggled through those late teenage milestones, barely scraping through my A Levels (with multiple threats of being kicked out of Sixth Form) and I made it into University to study Business Administration.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I didn’t really want to be at University, but I didn’t know what else to do. I felt completely lost and was still reeling from the trauma of losing my Mum.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I hadn’t realised until recently just how badly my world had spun off course at age 15. The future that I assumed was planned out for me, one that I’d dreamed about and was excited for, was now just a faint image in the distance. I wasn’t sure of anything anymore except that I wanted my Mum so desperately and I was sorely missing that safe, secure relationship that I didn’t have with anyone else.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Having not had the space to grieve properly I found myself struggling with bad anxiety and depression all through my late teens and early twenties. At about age 23, it got to a point where it was so bad I had no other option but to get some support.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I reached out to a local counselling organisation to speak with someone about the challenges I’d been facing. It was the first time I’d had an open and non judgemental space to talk about everything that had happened over the last eight years. For the first time I was able to create the smallest window of space to air those really difficult feelings I’d kept bottled up inside. The ones I’d kept under lock and key for fear that if they came out they’d overwhelm me and I’d not be able to recover, like I’d never make it out from under the weight of them.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:group {"layout":{"type":"flex","flexWrap":"nowrap","justifyContent":"center"}} -->
<div class="wp-block-group"><!-- wp:gallery {"imageCrop":false,"linkTo":"none"} -->
<figure class="wp-block-gallery has-nested-images columns-default"><!-- wp:image {"id":4808} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/sophia-mum.webp" alt="Treasure Time founder, Sophia, and her mum" class="wp-image-4808"/></figure>
<!-- /wp:image -->

<!-- wp:image {"id":4806} -->
<figure class="wp-block-image"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/sophia-and-mum.webp" alt="Treasure Time founder, Sophia, with her mum" class="wp-image-4806"/></figure>
<!-- /wp:image --></figure>
<!-- /wp:gallery --></div>
<!-- /wp:group -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Over time I started to feel like I could breathe again, like my lungs had just a bit more space to expand. I knew I was ready to find some inspiration to ‘start’ my life, but I didn’t know where to begin. I looked at people in my circle to see what they were doing with their lives and if there was anything that might spark some creative joy within me.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>At the time, my cousin was training to be a Play Therapist. I’d never heard of Play Therapy before but it sounded intriguing. She explained to me that it’s like counselling for children, but rather than using words to describe how they’re feeling or what they’ve been through they use toys and play. “Play is the natural language of children”, she told me.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>In that moment I realised that something major had been lacking for me and my younger siblings when we were dealing with the trauma and grief of losing our Mum. We hadn’t had anyone we could talk to, or anywhere we could go to blow off steam and be children, with someone who understood how we might be feeling. All of the adults in our lives were also grieving and it made it hard for them to really give us what we needed at the time. No one at school was well equipped enough to support us either - we really were left alone in our separate grief processes.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>As soon as my cousin explained Play Therapy to me, I knew I’d found something special - something inspiring. I wanted to provide Play Therapy to children and young people who’d faced trauma so they didn’t have to go through the same isolating and frightening experiences that I had. I set my mind to providing a service to local children through their schools, and started raising money.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Over the next decade I worked hard to build up a Play Therapy charity in Oxfordshire, one that would go on to win awards and support hundreds of children and families. <a href="http://www.clear-sky.org.uk">Clear Sky Children’s Charity</a> was born from my desire to make sure other children and young people didn’t feel so alone when they were facing really difficult things in life. I went on to do a Masters in Play Therapy and learn about ways that parents play a crucial role in children’s mental health, and how strong relationships (with remaining parents / carers) can provide protection for the developing minds of children and young people.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>From my Masters research I devised a 6 step programme for parents and carers, called <a href="http://www.treasuretime.co.uk">Treasure Time</a>, to develop the strong foundations of good mental health, with strong communication and secure attachment between their children and themselves.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I didn’t realise it at the time, but all of the work I was doing in the charity and with Treasure Time was part of me processing my loss. I found I could fill in missing pieces of my puzzle by learning about the way children experience and process trauma. I understood why I’d struggled so much with the loss of my Mum and that I really lacked age appropriate support when I needed it the most.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>I realise now that seeing a child in pain, especially your own child, can be extremely triggering for parents. If you’re also grieving it might feel like an impossible situation to overcome. My best advice for parents is that your child really needs you to bring them in closer to you during this time. It’s easy for families to fracture after the loss of a parent in particular. Everyone has their own grief journey and you might not be on the same path at the same time. Everyone’s experience is valid.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Where you can, normalise grieving. Normalise having conversations about the person you’ve lost. Acknowledge there will be days when you cry, and days that you laugh and everything in between. But you need to do parts of the journey together. It’s easy for children to feel isolated and scared when they’ve lost someone close to them, and this can make them vulnerable. To best protect your children and to preserve their mental health you need to make sure the relationship you have with them is strong and secure so that they know they can turn to you and count on you when they need your help.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:group -->
<div class="wp-block-group"><!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:group -->
<div class="wp-block-group"><!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center","style":{"color":{"background":"#fbe0c3","text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontStyle":"normal","fontWeight":"400"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center has-text-color has-background" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#003946;font-style:normal;font-weight:400"><strong>Sophia is a Play Therapist and Founder of Clear Sky Children's Charity &amp; <a href="https://www.treasuretime.co.uk/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Treasure Time</a> an organisation that supports children impacted by trauma through Play and Creative Arts Therapy, which she founded because of the experience of losing her Mum as a teenager.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:group --></div>
