		9 ideas for scattering your loved one’s ashes
		https://untanglegrief.com/scattering-ashes/
		Mon, 21 Nov 2022 17:02:13 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4731
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>The weeks, months and years after a loss can take us through so many challenging moments.</strong> <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/">Planning the funeral</a>, <a href="http://untanglegrief.com/funeral-wake/">arranging the wake</a>, <a href="/calculating-the-value-of-the-estate-probate/">managing the estate</a> – and, of course, grieving in the midst of it all. If your loved one has been cremated, the question of scattering ashes is yet another hard decision. Should you do it, and if so, where? When? How? With whom? The answers aren’t always straightforward.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>So, to help you with scattering ashes (or not), we’ve compiled some of the guidelines to keep in mind, as well as a few ideas to make the moment even more meaningful…</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Jump to section:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><a href="#spread">Do ashes have to be spread?</a></li><li><a href="#anywhere">Can you scatter ashes anywhere?</a></li><li><a href="#ideas">9 ideas for scattering ashes</a></li><li><a href="#stories">Your stories</a></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8f5ee","text":"#003946"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#e8f5ee;color:#003946;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="spread"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Do ashes have to be spread?</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaPosition":"right","mediaId":4793,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/urn-scattering-ashes/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":47,"imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:auto 47%"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/urn-scattering-ashes.webp" alt="An urn on table" class="wp-image-4793 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>You don’t have to spread your loved one’s ashes.</strong> Some prefer to keep the ashes in an urn or another safe container, so do whatever feels right to you – <strong>there’s no wrong or right decision.</strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">If you’re truly torn, you could even spread half of the ashes and keep the other half with you. <strong>It’s a big and difficult decision, so take as much time as you need.</strong> The answer will come.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#fff2e5","text":"#003946"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fff2e5;color:#003946;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Prepare for what the ashes will look like</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">It can be deeply upsetting to see your loved one’s ashes, not least because they might not look as you’d expect. <strong>What people don’t always tell you is there will likely be pieces of bone inside the container. That’s why we recommend you have someone with you when you open them for the first time. </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">You might also want to do this a few days before spreading the ashes, so you know what to expect. We also suggest you don’t touch the ashes with your bare hands, if possible. They can stick to your skin, so gloves are best if they need to be moved from one container to another.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <a href="http://onelink.to/zka2sa" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener"><strong>Join Untangle to access over 25 dedicated support spaces</strong></a> -</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#cee6f2","text":"#003946"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#cee6f2;color:#003946;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="anywhere"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Can you scatter ashes anywhere?</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>You can scatter ashes almost anywhere. However, there are a number of laws and guidelines you should keep in mind, and these can vary from country to country.</strong> You should also double-check local laws before you settle on a place to spread ashes – your chosen spot will probably be fine, but it’s best to be completely sure. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Below, you’ll find some of the main rules you should know</strong>:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"26px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:26px"><strong>1. Ensure the executor of the will knows</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>It’s down to the executor of the will to ensure the person who has died has been laid to rest.</strong> If that’s not you, you’ll need their consent before you scatter the ashes. <strong>And, in the event that there is no will, it’s the next of kin’s responsibility.</strong> Keep communication open with the right people to make sure everyone knows what is happening.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"26px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:26px"><strong>2. There are different rules for private and public land</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">In the UK, the laws for scattering ashes are quite flexible, but <strong>public places – such as parks, beaches or tourist attractions – often have extra guidelines</strong>. For example, if your loved one wanted to be laid to rest at Stonehenge, you could only spread their ashes on the land around the stones, not in the inner Stone Circle. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Meanwhile, if you were taking the ashes to a garden or estate, there may be rules about the time of day or the areas you’re able to visit.</strong> Wherever you choose, Google ‘spreading ashes at [NAME OF PLACE]’ to see if there are specific guidelines you need to be aware of.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"26px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-left" style="font-size:26px"><strong>3. Scattering ashes at sea comes with its own set of rules</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">The ocean is a popular place to scatter ashes, and for good reason. There’s something poetic about watching your person’s ashes drift out to sea – especially if they loved the water. However, <strong>if you’ve chosen a spot that’s within five miles of the coast, the Environmental Agency asks that you stick to a few key rules. These include:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>Don’t scatter any non-biodegradable items with the ashes. For instance, personal items or plastic wreaths that may be harmful to wildlife.</li><li>Spread ashes at a spot far from buildings and where people swim or fish.</li><li>Spread the ashes as close to the water surface as possible.</li><li>Avoid windy days so the ashes don’t blow about and affect people living or working nearby.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"style":{"color":{"background":"#f9f5f2","text":"#003946"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f9f5f2;color:#003946;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="ideas"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>9 ideas for scattering ashes</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>1. Pick their favourite place</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">You can probably picture it now. If your loved one had a favourite place, and it’s possible to get to, consider scattering their ashes there. There are few better tributes than laying someone to rest in the spot where they spent their best moments.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>2. Or choose numerous places</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">If you just can’t land on one perfect place, you could scatter your loved one’s ashes across the globe. Choose various spots to spread their ashes, whether you head to favourite holiday destinations or different places they lived over the years.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>3. Create a garden tribute</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaId":4772,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/scattering-ashes-garden/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":38} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:38% auto"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/scattering-ashes-garden.webp" alt="Home garden" class="wp-image-4772 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:paragraph {"placeholder":"Content…","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">The garden is a beautiful spot to scatter your person’s ashes. It’s close to home, and you can decorate the resting place however you please. We recommend raking the ashes into the soil or burying them in a biodegradable urn. Then plant their favourite flowers, arrange ornaments or maybe even place a bench nearby.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>4. Choose a meaningful date</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">You can keep hold of the ashes for as long as you like, so if you want to, you can wait for a special date to do the scattering. Perhaps it could be on your person’s birthday or an anniversary that meant something to you both. It could even form part of memorialising them on a <a href="http://untanglegrief.com/death-anniversary/">death anniversary</a>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>5. Prepare a speech</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">If you’re scattering your loved one’s ashes as a group, it could be nice to prepare a speech. Just a few words or a heartfelt reading – or even a funny story – to bring a sense of ceremony to the day.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>6. Take it in turns</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Make others feel involved by taking turns scattering the ashes. This way, everyone gets their chance to say their own goodbye. These kinds of rituals can also make you feel closer to one another; you’re in it together to share support and pay tribute to someone you all love.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>7. Play some music</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">When the time comes to scatter the ashes, some music can be comforting. Depending on where you’re spreading them, take some mini speakers with you and play some of your loved one’s favourite songs.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>8. Scatter flowers with the ashes</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">If you’re spreading your loved one’s ashes on the water or scattering them into the wind, you could also add flower petals with a symbolic meaning behind them. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaId":4771,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/scattering-ashes-flowers/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":38} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:38% auto"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/scattering-ashes-flowers.webp" alt="Anemones, flowers" class="wp-image-4771 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Some of the most popular flowers to scatter are:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>Red roses - for true love</li><li>Yellow roses - for friendship</li><li>Anemones - for unfading love</li><li>Daffodils - for respect</li><li>Purple tulips - for forever love</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Or you could simply go with their favourite flavours, whatever they may be. Some have even scattered wildflower seeds with ashes so that their love can continue to grow.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>9. Make a day of it</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">After you’ve finished scattering your loved one’s ashes, and you’ve made your loving tributes, you may want nothing more than to go home and process the day. That said, if there’s time, you could always turn it into a full day out with those closest to you. Visit other places that meant something to you both, or maybe go to their favourite restaurant and raise a glass in their honour.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f2f7ff;color:#003946;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="stories"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Scattering ashes: your stories</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">We’re so grateful to everyone who shares their stories in the <a href="http://onelink.to/zka2sa" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Untangle community</a>. Grief can be so isolating, but by connecting with others who relate, the most difficult times in life can feel a little less lonely. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Some of our members have been talking about how they paid tribute to their loved ones when they scattered their ashes. Here are just a few of the touching posts we’ve seen…</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"className":"is-style-dots"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity is-style-dots"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><em>“It was a standing joke between my husband &amp; I that if he died before me I should bury him in the garden. So on the 1st anniversary of his cremation 12th May 2022, I was having my garden repaved so I sprinkled his ashes under the new paving slabs. So he finally got his wish to be buried in the garden. It was a very sad moment for me, but at least every year I can raise a toast to celebrate his life knowing he is right there with me.”</em> – <em>Lez</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"className":"is-style-dots"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity is-style-dots"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><em>“Went on 30th April 22 with Kevin's family to Scarborough to scatter his ashes. Never understood why people wanted ashes but now I have a small amount in a little decorative jar. When the hibiscus that I planted for him flowers, I will put a little of the ashes under it. The rest I'll keep. I hold the jar close to my heart every day. Experience helps us to understand individual needs.”</em> – <em>Tom</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"className":"is-style-dots"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-alpha-channel-opacity is-style-dots"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><em>“So I picked up mum's ashes today, and I felt weirdly happy. Maybe happy not being the right word but relief or a sense of peace, or a knowing it was the right thing to do. I drove her to my stepdad’s and put one of her favourite songs on and sang. Maybe I will crumble later, but today I feel a sense of calm.”</em> – Tara</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		 Pre-paid funeral plans: the pros and cons
		https://untanglegrief.com/funeral-plans-pros-cons/
		Tue, 29 Nov 2022 11:49:56 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4856
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Should you invest in a pre-paid funeral plan?</strong> There are definitely benefits, but before you commit to any arrangements or costs, <strong>it’s essential to weigh up pre-paid funeral plans pros and cons first</strong>.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>To help you out, we’ve made a list below of all the pros and cons you need to know. Read them through, think them over, talk to your loved ones, and decide what works best for you.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"background":"#f9f5f2","text":"#003946"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f9f5f2;color:#003946;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="info"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>The pros of a pre-paid funeral plan</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px"><strong>1. It can save your loved one from stress</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><a href="https://untanglegrief.com/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/">Funeral planning</a> can be difficult for grieving loved ones – to say the very least. Not only might they worry about what you would have wanted, but there’s the financial stress to deal with too. If you think they might struggle (and you feel able to take it on), a prepaid plan could give you all peace of mind. Discuss it with them to see if it’s something they would be open to.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px"><strong>2. You can make sure your wishes are carried out</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaPosition":"right","mediaId":4884,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/funeral-plan-pros-cons/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":47,"imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:auto 47%"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/funeral-plan-pros-cons.webp" alt="Urn on a table" class="wp-image-4884 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">If you have specific wishes for your funeral, a prepaid plan allows you to ensure they happen. </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">For example, if there’s a particular coffin or venue type you’d prefer for the service, these can be paid for in advance.<strong> Some providers will also help you arrange the celebrant, vehicles, crematorium fees, and other add-ons.</strong> It all depends on the budget available and the plan you choose.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Finer details that don’t come at a cost – like a certain dress code or reading – may not be guaranteed.</strong> However, you can still make sure they’re noted and passed on to your loved ones, so they know exactly what you want. <strong>Before you make any payments, double-check exactly what is included in your plan.</strong> That way you’ll know what needs to be arranged separately.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px"><strong>3. Rising funeral costs can be avoided</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">Inflation means that funeral prices are likely to go up in the coming months and years. However, by arranging a pre-paid plan, you can fix the balance so that you only pay the current price. <strong>You’re essentially ‘protecting’ your funeral against rising costs during difficult financial times</strong>, which means your loved ones won’t have to worry about finding the funds later on.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px"><strong>4. You can pick a plan to suit your budget</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Most pre-paid funeral providers offer a range of plans to suit every budget</strong>, so you can figure out an arrangement that works just for you. Loved ones can find it challenging to make financial decisions when emotional and grieving, so having the budget set and covered ahead of time will save a lot of upset and stress later on.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px"><strong>5. Some providers let you pay on finance</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">You don’t have to have the complete funds for the funeral ready right now. <strong>Many pre-paid plan providers allow you to pay over a 12-month period, often in interest-free instalments.</strong> There may be a small deposit to cover at the beginning, but this isn’t an additional cost; it will be deducted from your final total.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946","background":"#fff2e5"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fff2e5;color:#003946;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="behave"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>The cons of a pre-paid funeral plan</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px"><strong>1. Not every detail can be covered</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:media-text {"mediaPosition":"right","mediaId":4886,"mediaLink":"https://untanglegrief.com/funeral-plans-flowers/","mediaType":"image","mediaWidth":47,"imageFill":false} -->
<div class="wp-block-media-text alignwide has-media-on-the-right is-stacked-on-mobile" style="grid-template-columns:auto 47%"><figure class="wp-block-media-text__media"><img src="https://untanglegrief.com/wp-content/uploads/2022/11/Funeral-Plans-Flowers.webp" alt="Funeral flowers" class="wp-image-4886 size-full"/></figure><div class="wp-block-media-text__content"><!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">While a pre-paid funeral plan can cover a lot of your wishes, there are some details that can’t be included. Things like the music played, for example, might not be guaranteed on the day. <strong>The following is also not usually included in a pre-paid funeral plan:&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>Burial plot (this can cost £1,000s) and some burial fees</li><li>Headstone/memorial</li><li>Funeral notices</li><li>Order sheets</li><li>Embalming</li><li>Flowers, catering and other costs for a wake</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list --></div></div>
<!-- /wp:media-text -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Your provider should be transparent about everything you’re paying for. <strong>Keep in mind that <a href="https://untanglegrief.com/funeral-wake/">wake arrangements</a> are rarely covered by pre-paid funeral plans</strong>, so you may want to put extra money aside for this.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px"><strong>2. Plans aren’t always flexible if you move</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>If you pay for your plan and then move abroad, or even to just another part of the country, you may not be able to move your funeral plans with you.</strong> This isn’t the case for all providers, but if you think you might move, you should check with them first. Make sure you know how flexible your plan is and whether there are any surprise conditions.&nbsp;</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px"><strong>3. You have to have the money ready</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">It goes without saying that funerals come at a cost. Without a plan, they’re usually paid for from your estate, but with a pre-paid plan, you need to have enough money ready to cover the price. The good news is, (as mentioned above) many providers allow you to make monthly instalments if you don’t want to pay the total upfront. This way, you can spread out the cost over a set period of time to make it more manageable.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px"><strong>4. You can't withdraw funds once they're paid</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">When money is paid into a funeral plan, the funds are no longer accessible. Usually, they can’t be released again until death (but check contracts to be sure). You probably know this already, but it’s helpful to be aware of it before you start paying. That way you can make sure you’re budgeting correctly and not relying on that money for anything else.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3,"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"30px"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:30px"><strong>5. Funeral plans may not go ahead</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>If you pay for the funeral in monthly instalments but pass away before the total balance is covered, many plan providers will not be able to go forward with your funeral wishes</strong>. Instead, your loved ones will usually be refunded, and they will need to start plans from scratch at the current rate. If you believe your death may be imminent, consider whether it’s better for your family or friends to make the plans instead.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">We hope this pre-paid funeral plans pros and cons list helps you reach the right decision for you. It’s a personal choice, and there’s no right or wrong way to go, so take your time if you’re still unsure.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>You can also reach out to the <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Untangle community</a> when you’re looking for more advice. The <a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa" data-type="URL" data-id="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Funerals group</a> is a good place to discuss any concerns or questions you might have.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->

<!-- /wp:separator -->

		Legacy Gifting & Inheritance Tax
		https://untanglegrief.com/legacy-gifting/
		Tue, 13 Dec 2022 19:34:36 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4890
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Giving gifts of toys, jewellery, or aftershave during a holiday celebration is one thing, but if you’re considering gifting money from your estate to your family or friends, maybe to help them with buying a property or perhaps to reduce any future Inheritance Tax bill, then there are specific rules and factors to consider, as sometimes being too generous can have its drawbacks.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Nowadays, giving a helping hand financially is something that most parents and grandparents want to do for their children and grandchildren. Making gifts during your lifetime reduces the value of your estate and as such can reduce the amount of Inheritance Tax that may be due after death.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What gifts are free from Inheritance Tax?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">There are a few ‘lifetime gifts’ that you can make that are immediately free from Inheritance Tax:&nbsp;<strong> Any gifts made to your English-domiciled spouse or to UK-registered charities are tax-free</strong>. <strong>You can give up to £3000 away each tax year</strong> either as a single gift or as several gifts added together, and you can also use any unused allowance from the previous tax year. &nbsp;<strong>Small gifts of up to £250 each can be made to as many people as you wish as long as no other gifts were made to them</strong>, and l<strong>arger amounts can be gifted on marriage</strong>; up to £5000 from a parent; up to £2500 from a grandparent and up to £1000 from anyone else.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">You are also able to make gifts out of your income as long as this is a regular payment, and you are able to maintain your usual standard of living.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>For other lifetime gifts to be successful in mitigating Inheritance Tax certain conditions must be met.</strong> If you survive seven years after giving away any asset (including money in excess of the amounts explained above) and you have not continued to benefit from the asset, then the gift will be exempt from Inheritance Tax. If you fail to survive seven years but manage to survive three or more years after the gift, then any Inheritance Tax that needs to be paid may be reduced on a sliding scale.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>The rules surrounding gifting and Inheritance Tax are complex and there are a number of matters to be wary of.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">It may be that if you give away an asset but later require care, the Local Authority may allege that you deliberately deprived yourself of those assets in an attempt to avoid paying care fees.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Can I transfer my home to my children?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Families frequently contact us because they want to transfer their family home into the names of their children, to avoid future care fees or reduce any Inheritance Tax that may be due.</strong>&nbsp; As already stated, it is very likely that the Local Authority would consider this to be an attempt at deliberate deprivation of your assets and they would treat you as if you still owned the property when assessing what you need to pay.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Likewise, <strong>if you put your house in your children’s names but continue living in the house (and therefore continue to benefit from it) when you die the whole value of the property would still be included in your estate for Inheritance Tax purposes.&nbsp; </strong>And if your children&nbsp;don’t&nbsp;live in the property then when it is eventually sold they could be subject to Capital Gains Tax, if the value of the property has increased since the transfer.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Other matters to consider include the consequence of transferring your property to a child who then may be made subject to a bankruptcy order or may become unemployed and forced to sell the house to release the capital.</strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">If married, whilst your child may seem to be in a stable relationship, what would happen if they decided to divorce? The house would then form part of the divorce settlement and you could be left without a roof over your head! &nbsp;Similarly, what if your child predeceased you and left the house to their spouse who subsequently remarried?</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Whilst you may be full of good intentions when making gifts to your loved ones, it is important to seek professional legal advice so that your kindness and generosity doesn’t lead to disappointment and despair.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:group -->

<!-- /wp:separator -->

		How to Manage Debts after a Bereavement
		https://untanglegrief.com/how-to-manage-debts-after-a-bereavement/
		Tue, 03 Jan 2023 12:07:51 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4917
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">The death of someone close to you is bound to have devastating effects on your entire life. During bereavement, many people are affected emotionally, mentally, and financially. <strong>If you have been left with debt after a loved one passes away, it is important to take steps to manage this debt in a way that is responsible and sustainable.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">It is understandable for you to feel unsure about what happens to a person’s debts or assets when they die. We have provided some guidance below around taking those first steps at managing debts after a bereavement.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>What is debt?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Debt is an amount of money that is owed by one person or entity to another. This can be in the form of a loan, a credit card balance, or any other type of financial obligation. <strong>When someone takes on debt, they are agreeing to pay back the money that they have borrowed, along with any associated interest or fees.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Debt can be useful in certain situations, as it allows people to borrow money to make purchases or investments that they may not have the cash to pay for upfront. However, if not managed properly, debt can also become a burden, as the borrower may have difficulty making the required payments.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>My loved one has left debts behind after they died. What do I do?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">First, it is important to understand what debts your loved one has left behind. This may include things like credit card debt, mortgage debt, car loan debt, and personal loan debt. It is important to carefully review all these debts and to understand the terms and conditions associated with them.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Once you have a clear picture of the debts your loved one has left behind, it is important to prioritise them.</strong> Some debts, such as mortgage debt and car loan debt, may be secured against assets, which means that the lender has the right to repossess those assets if the debt is not repaid. In these cases, it may be necessary to prioritise these debts and to make sure that they are paid on time.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>In some cases, it may be possible to negotiate with creditors to try and reduce the amount of debt that is owed.</strong> For example, if your loved one had a credit card with a high interest rate, you may be able to negotiate a lower rate with the credit card company. This can help to reduce the amount of interest that is being charged on the debt, which can make it more manageable. It is also important to consider your own financial situation when managing debt after a bereavement.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>If you are not able to manage the debt on your own, you may need to seek help from a financial advisor or a debt counselling service.</strong> These professionals can provide you with guidance and support to help you manage your debt in a way that is sustainable and responsible.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>When should I get help?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">It is important to get help with debts as soon as possible after a bereavement, even if you are not sure how you will be able to manage them. There are a few key reasons why it is important to seek help with your debts after a bereavement:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>To understand if/how this affects your own financial situation</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>To prioritise certain debts: Not all debts are created equal, and it is important to prioritise them in order to manage them effectively</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>To inform and potentially negotiate with creditors: The creditors should be informed as soon as you feel that you are able to discuss the debts</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Debt concerns can add a high amount of stress during such a difficult period of your life. <strong>Although it is important to seek help with your debts as soon as possible after a bereavement, you must go at your own pace.</strong> If you do not feel like you are able to discuss the matters over the phone, it is possible to communicate with creditors online.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>The emotional impact of being in debt</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Whether you have to manage a loved one’s debts after they have died, or whether you are managing your own debts, you will likely experience a significant emotional impact. The burden of debt can weigh heavily on individuals and can lead to feelings of hopelessness and despair.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">One of the major emotional impacts of being in debt is the sense of financial insecurity it can create. If you are in debt, you may worry about how you will be able to make your monthly payments, or how you will be able to pay off your debts in full. This is extremely normal and is called <strong>debt fatigue</strong>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">In some cases, the emotional impact of being in debt can be so severe that it leads to mental health problems, such as depression and anxiety. These conditions can make it even more difficult for you to manage their debts, as you may be unable to think clearly about your finances.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>How can I get help?</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">There are a variety of ways that you can seek out help and support.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li><a href="https://iehub.co.uk/untangle/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">IE Hub</a> is a free, online tool that can help you manage your finances. Not only can you budget your own finances, but you can also communicate with creditors in your own time, without long and stressful phone calls.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li><a href="https://www.stepchange.org/debt-info/bereavement-and-debt.aspx" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Step Change</a> is a debt charity that can provide free and confidential advice whenever you are ready. They will be able to advise you on what your next steps may be in managing yours or your loved one’s debts.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

		Making a Will – what are your options?
		https://untanglegrief.com/making-a-will-what-are-your-options/
		Tue, 03 Jan 2023 13:05:30 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4923
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Making a Will is a positive act which will greatly assist your loved ones when you pass away. By making a Will, you can have peace of mind in the knowledge that your wishes shall be carried out. <strong>With a little planning, you can ensure that your wealth and the gifts you wish to make reach the right people at the right time with tax being minimised where possible.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Without a Will:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>Your assets shall pass in accordance with the Intestacy Rules, which does not necessarily mean that your assets shall pass to those whom you consider closest to you.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>You will not pass any assets to people who are not directly related to you, including step-children, common law spouses, or to your favourite charities.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>If you are separated but not divorced, your estranged spouse could still inherit and be responsible for administering your estate.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>You will have no say in who will look after your children if they are under 18 when you die.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>You will have no control over the age at which your beneficiaries shall inherit.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>There could be increased cost and delay in administering your estate.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">It is not practical for couples to make “joint Wills” as, with these Wills, both parties must be in agreement for the Wills to be changed or revoked. Thereafter, when one partner dies, the joint Will automatically becomes irrevocable, meaning the survivor’s Will cannot be changed from that point on. <strong>Couples are advised to make individual Wills, even if both Wills say the same things</strong>, and these are commonly known as “mirror Wills”.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Executors and Trustees</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">These are the people who will have the legal authority and responsibility for administering your estate and carrying out your wishes. If your asset base is complicated, this can be quite an onerous task covering a whole range of matters. <strong>You should appoint people who are over the age of 18, who you trust implicitly, and who are financially astute.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">It is not uncommon for independent professional Executors and Trustees, such as a solicitor or a solicitors' firm, to be appointed either for the assistance of their beneficiaries or to ensure that there is fairness in executing the terms of the Will in practice.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">The people who you appoint as your Executors will usually also be appointed as the Trustees of any trusts which might arise under your Will. However, separate people can be appointed to perform these roles if desired.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Options for your estate</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">It is important that your Will sets out who is to receive whatever property has not otherwise been dealt with in your Will. <strong>All of the assets you own at your death that have not already been gifted in your Will, after any liabilities have been paid, form your residuary estate</strong>.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">When thinking about who should benefit from your residuary estate, please remember that it cannot be predicted in what order people will die. <strong>Accordingly, you might want to make provision for your beneficiaries’ families, should a particular beneficiary die before you.</strong> This is often thought of in the context of somebody leaving their estate (or part of it) to their grandchildren if their child has pre-deceased them. As such, you need to consider what age you wish younger beneficiaries to inherit.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>There are two main options for dealing with your residuary estate in your Will.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>First, you could create a basic Will</strong> which passes your estate outright to your chosen beneficiaries (at a predetermined age, if appropriate). A basic Will is simple and the benefits are that the beneficiary will have unrestricted access to and absolute control of the assets they inherit.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>However, it is important to consider the fact that you do not know the date on which you will pass away, and you therefore do not know what your beneficiaries’ circumstances will be at that date</strong>. There is a considerable danger your beneficiaries will inherit a sizeable amount when a number of factors might make that inappropriate. For example, the beneficiary may be going through a divorce or a breakdown in relationship, tax issues, bankruptcy, gambling/alcohol/drug addiction, etc.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>In order to offer more protection for your estate once you have passed away, you could instead incorporate a trust structure within your Will</strong>. The trust would be designed to benefit your chosen beneficiaries, but with the ability for the people managing the trust (the “Trustees”) to decide when/if funds are distributed. This can be extremely valuable, as the Trustees can provide financial support as appropriate, but whilst retaining/restricting access to the capital if there is good reason to do so.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>A Will of this nature would be accompanied by a “Letter of Wishes” – a document setting out your intentions.</strong> This is not legally binding (as making it binding would undermine the discretion which is crucial to the protection), but it is highly persuasive.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Other matters to consider when making a Will</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">You should also consider whether you would like to leave any specific items or specific amounts of money to certain individuals. Furthermore, if you have children under the age of 18, you should ensure that you appoint guardians in your Will to set out who you would intend to take parental responsibility for those children in the event of both parents passing away. You can also set out your funeral wishes within your Will, if you should so wish.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Not only does making a Will give you peace of mind that you have adequately accounted for your wishes for your estate after death,</strong> but Wills can also be extremely useful for mitigating against tax for both your own estate and the estates of your chosen beneficiaries for generations to come.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

		Probate without a Will - Letters of Administration
		https://untanglegrief.com/letters-of-administration/
		Tue, 03 Jan 2023 18:31:59 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4931
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">When somebody passes away without having made a Will, the rules of intestacy apply and so the law will dictate who has the authority to deal with the estate and benefit from the estate. <strong>The rules of intestacy are extremely strict and often leave people’s estates being dealt with by and distributed to individuals that the deceased had never intended.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Somebody who passes away without making a will is known as “intestate”. The individuals who are entitled to deal with the estate are called the administrators and the individuals who are entitled to benefit from the estate are called the beneficiaries. Other than spouses, civil partners, and adopted children, only close living blood relatives of the deceased can benefit from the intestate’s estate.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Spouse/civil partners</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Where an individual was married or in a civil partnership when they passed away, the surviving spouse/civil partner will inherit the first £270,000 of the estate, half of the remainder of the estate, and all of the personal belongings of the deceased. For example, if somebody’s estate was worth £300,000 when they passed away and they were married at their death, the surviving spouse would receive the first £285,000 of that person’s estate (along with personal items). If the deceased had children, they would be entitled to the remainder of the estate. If the deceased was co-habiting with their partner, and they were not married or in a civil partnership, they would not be entitled to any of the estate under the rules of intestacy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Children</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">If the person who has passed away was not married but had a child or children who survived them, then the child or children would inherit the entire estate (in equal shares if more than one child). Children do not receive their inheritance immediately if they are under the age of 18. They would only receive the inheritance upon turning 18, or if they got married or formed a civil partnership before that age. The administrators would deal with the inheritance on behalf of the child until they were entitled to the funds themselves. It should be noted that children born from unmarried relationships rank equally with children born in marital relationships.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Step-children are not entitled to a share of a deceased step-parents estate, unless they had been formally adopted by the deceased.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Grandchildren and great-grandchildren</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Under the rules of intestacy, a grandchild or a great-grandchild would only be entitled to receive a share of a deceased’s estate if their parent or grandparent had died before the intestate person, or if their parent is alive when the deceased passes away but dies before reaching the age of 18 without marrying/forming a civil partnership.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Other close blood relatives</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">If the deceased passed away leaving no spouse, civil partner, children, grandchildren or great-grandchildren, then the next closest living relatives who will be entitled to inherit are the intestate’s siblings (including half-siblings), parents and grandparents, uncles and aunts (or cousins where the deceased’s uncle or aunt has passed away before them) and half-uncles and half-aunts (and again, half-cousins if the deceased’s half-uncle or half-aunt has passed away before them).</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Where there are no surviving relatives</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">If somebody passes away without a Will leaving no surviving close blood relatives, that person’s estate will then pass to the Crown. This is known as “<em>bona vacantia</em>”, which is a term that refers to unclaimed goods.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading -->
<h2>Dealing with the Probate of an intestate person – “Letters of Administration”</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Whoever is entitled to benefit from the estate (with reference to the above) would then be the individual(s) with the authority to deal with the estate – namely, the administrator or administrators. <strong>The administrators would need to apply for Letters of Administration (often referred to as Probate) so that they can be formally appointed by the court to deal with the affairs of the deceased.</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">The administrator would take responsibility for dealing with all aspects of the estate including:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>Notifying relevant organisations about the death;</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>Ascertaining the assets and liabilities of the deceased;</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>Making an application for the Letters of Administration;</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>&nbsp;Paying any inheritance tax that is owed;</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>Collecting assets and paying liabilities;</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>Producing estate accounts to set out the assets and liabilities in the estate as well as what will be due for distribution to the beneficiaries; and</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<ul style="font-size:17px"><li>Making distributions to beneficiaries.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px">Dealing with an estate can be burdensome, and administrators have the option of appointing professionals, such as a solicitors firm, to assist them with the process if required.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p style="font-size:17px"><strong>Passing away without a Will can often lead to devastating consequences if the rules of intestacy do not accurately reflect what the wishes of the deceased would be.</strong> Not only this, but distribution of an estate in accordance with the rules of intestacy can have significantly adverse tax implications.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

		Lasting Powers of Attorney (LPAs)
		https://untanglegrief.com/lasting-powers-of-attorney-lpas/
		Thu, 12 Jan 2023 12:48:35 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4939
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Lasting Powers of Attorney (LPAs) allow you (the Donor) to appoint one or more people (known as Attorneys) the legal authority to make decisions on your behalf, about your financial affairs and health and welfare, if you were to lose mental capacity.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Many believe that Lasting Powers of Attorney are only needed as you get older – but this is simply not the case, as it may be an accident, or sudden illness that renders you unable to make your own decisions.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A Lasting Power of Attorney can only be made while the person making it is deemed to still have the mental capacity to make their own decisions and understand what they are agreeing to. If no attorneys have been appointed, and the person’s mental capacity deteriorates to a point where it is no longer possible to make an LPA, the Court of Protection would have to appoint a Deputy to deal with any financial matters, and medical staff and Social Services would be responsible for making Health and Welfare decisions on the person’s behalf. This can cause untold distress to both you and to your loved ones, creating problems that could easily have been avoided.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are two types of Lasting Power of Attorney:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Property &amp; Financial Affairs LPA</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This allows your attorney (who will be a responsible person or persons of your choosing) to manage your financial and property affairs. This means you can authorise them to write cheques on your behalf, pay bills or claim benefits for you. By planning ahead, you are able to give your instructions while you are of sound mind, and in anticipation of the possibility of not being capable at some future date. This provides invaluable peace-of-mind in the unfortunate eventuality of you being rendered incapable of managing your own affairs.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Health &amp; Welfare LPA</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>This allows you to authorise someone to make health and welfare decisions for you and can only be used if you lose the necessary mental capacity to do this for yourself. Your attorney will be then able to make decisions about where you live and your day-to-day care, having already discussed this with you.&nbsp; They will also be able to refuse or consent to medical treatment on your behalf if you desire.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If mental capacity is lost and there are no Lasting Powers of Attorney in existence, then any bank accounts would be frozen, even if held jointly, and an application would have to be made to the Court of Protection which is a lengthy, expensive process during which time no money can leave the account to pay bills or fund care.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>An LPA can be made at any time but has to be registered with the Office of the Public Guardian before it can be used – and in current circumstances this can take up to 20 weeks.&nbsp; However, once it is registered it is available for use as soon as it is needed.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you were struck down by sudden illness or disability (for example, from a stroke or an accident) and did not have Lasting Powers of Attorney in place, there would inevitably be considerable delays before any financial matters could be dealt with or important decisions about your care could be made.&nbsp; An application to the Court of Protection for a Deputyship can only be made once a person with no Attorney in place has lost capacity, which means a delay of 6 months or more before the Court Order is issued and the Deputy can be of any assistance – a time-consuming, expensive and frustrating exercise which could have been avoided.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Think of it like travel insurance - you hope you won’t ever need to use it but would not consider going on holiday without it. Your Attorney may never need to use the LPA, but if you were unable to look after your affairs and do not have one in place, the alternative does not bear thinking about.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It’s never too early to make one, just don’t leave it too late!</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

		Do you need to put Lasting Powers of Attorney in place?
		https://untanglegrief.com/do-you-need-to-put-lasting-powers-of-attorney-in-place/
		Thu, 12 Jan 2023 14:13:29 +0000
		team
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4942
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A Lasting Power of Attorney is a document that allows you to appoint people or professionals that you trust to manage your affairs and make decisions on your behalf. A person who makes a Lasting Power of Attorney is called a donor, and a person or a professional who is appointed under a Lasting Power of Attorney is known as an attorney. Lasting Powers of Attorney can be extremely useful for planning for your future, for example if you were to ever have an accident, or suffer an illness such as dementia, heart disease or a stroke.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>There are two forms of Lasting Powers of Attorney, one which covers Property and Financial Affairs and a second which covers Health and Welfare.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A Lasting Power of Attorney covering Health and Welfare<strong> </strong>allows your chosen attorneys to make health and welfare decisions on the donor’s behalf but only at a time in the future when the donor lacks capacity to make such decisions. Such decisions may include those concerning what medical treatment you receive and whether you should receive life-sustaining medical care. Attorneys appointed under a Health and Welfare Lasting Power of Attorney can also make decisions about where you live (i.e., whether you should move into a care home) and decisions about your daily routine.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>A Lasting Power of Attorney covering Property and Financial Affairs<strong> </strong>allows your chosen attorneys to make decisions about your finances and property either straight away (once the document is in place), or at a time in the future when you are unable to or lack the capacity to make such decisions.&nbsp; Under this document, your chosen attorneys can manage your bank and building society accounts, sell your property (where necessary), pay your bills and collect your pensions and benefits for you. You might feel more comfortable appointing a professional attorney to act for you under this type of Lasting Power of Attorney, as they would have particular knowledge and expertise that could help to reduce the burden on your family and friends.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you do not put Lasting Powers of Attorney in place when you have capacity, and then you later lose capacity to make decisions on your behalf, the only way that your trusted individuals will be able to manage your financial affairs would be for them to make an application to court for a Deputyship order. This process is likely to be both extremely lengthy and costly. A similar application is (in practice) almost impossible to achieve for health or welfare decisions.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>If you want to ensure that your trusted individuals can make decisions for you on your behalf in the future when you might not be able to make them yourself, you should definitely consider putting Lasting Powers of Attorney in place.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:group -->
<div class="wp-block-group"><!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946","background":"#fbe0c3"}}} -->
