		Eulogy update
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4639
		Tue, 01 Nov 2022 14:56:33 +0000
		ryan.stafford
		https://untanglegrief.com/?p=4639
		
		<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>One of the most challenging parts of <a href="/our-advice-for-planning-a-funeral/">funeral planning</a> is writing a fitting tribute to your loved one.</strong> </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How can you find the words to capture just how much your friend or family member means to you? It’s harder still because you’re grieving, so emotions are running high, concentration is low, and the pressure may be overwhelming. <strong>That’s why we’ve created this guide on how to write a eulogy, complete with examples to get you started. </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Jump to section:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><a href="#tips">How to write a eulogy - 6 tips</a></li><li><a href="#structure">An example structure</a></li><li><a href="#parent">Eulogy for a parent</a></li><li><a href="#sibling"><a href="#not">Eulogy for a sibling</a></a></li><li><a href="#grandparent"><a href="#not">Eulogy for a grandparent</a></a></li><li><a href="#grief"></a><a href="#friend">Eulogy for a friend</a></li><li><a href="#examples">More eulogy examples</a></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","fontSize":"large"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-left has-large-font-size"><strong>What is a eulogy?</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>A eulogy is a short speech given at a funeral or <a href="/how-to-memorial-ceremony/">memorial service</a> for a person who has died. </strong>The tradition originates from ancient Greece, and the word literally means “praise”. The key is to write the eulogy in a way that does their life justice and respects their loved ones’ memories and feelings of grief.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","fontSize":"large"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-left has-large-font-size"><strong>Who should deliver a eulogy?</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Speaking about someone who has died in front of their family and friends is a courageous thing to do. If you feel daunted by the prospect, ask people around you for support. <strong>While a close relative or friend usually writes the funeral speech, it can also be delivered by an official, such as a religious leader.</strong> Do what feels right and keep it flexible. For example, if you want to write the eulogy but worry about <a href="/preparing-yourself-for-the-funeral/">breaking down in tears</a>, ask someone else to be on standby to read it for you if need be.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"left","fontSize":"large"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-left has-large-font-size" id="tips"><strong>How to write a eulogy - 6 tips</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>1. Make it personal</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p><strong>Introducing yourself in relation to the person you are remembering can be a good place to start.</strong> Describe what they meant to you, and what qualities defined them in your eyes. This will establish a connection with other people at the service and put you in the picture for those who might not know you very well.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>2. Cover the essentials</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>When thinking about how to write a eulogy, it’s a good idea to structure it with a beginning, a middle and an end. And while it is not the same as an obituary, <strong>it usually includes brief aspects of the late person’s life, such as their early beginnings, their education and career, and particular skills, achievements or interests.</strong> Saying something specific about their family life, and mentioning their partner and/or children by name, can feel particularly important to their closest relatives.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>3. Get personal stories from others</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Just like our relationships with a particular person differ, so do our <a href="/stages-of-grief/">feelings about them when they die</a>. To make sure you write a good eulogy that will feel meaningful to others, <strong>ask a few close friends or relatives to contribute by sharing a favourite memory, personal story, or anecdote</strong>. A range of perspectives will enrich your speech and help strike the right tone right with your audience. You might also discover a true gem in the process, like a beautiful quote that perfectly captures your loved one’s personality, qualities, and quirks.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>4. Consider the length</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>How long should a eulogy be?<strong> Some funeral speeches are very brief and there are no set rules for length, but 3-5 minutes is common.</strong> Make it long enough to properly honour the person and say what needs to be said, in proportion to the rest of the funeral service. To get it right, try reading it out loud a few times while timing yourself and editing accordingly.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>5. Make it honest</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>It is possible to talk about someone’s achievements and qualities without glorifying them and mention shortcomings or disappointments in a kind and accepting way. None of us are perfect, and we remember those we have lost in all their human complexity. <strong>Follow your instincts, even using some gentle humour if it feels right and relevant.</strong> And if you’re not sure, ask someone else for their honest feedback before you finalise your eulogy.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:heading {"level":3} -->
<h3><strong>6. End on a touching note</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Ending a eulogy on the right note can be tricky. <strong>One option is to finish with a poem or <a href="/the-35-greatest-grief-quotes/">quote</a> that feels consoling and meaningful, even if it happens to come from a movie such as <em>Pretty Woman</em> or <em>Lord of the Rings</em>!</strong> You might find inspiration in famous eulogies, such as Matthew’s tribute to his partner Gareth in <em>Four Weddings and a Funeral</em>, Oprah Winfrey’s speech for Rosa Parks, Mona Simpson remembering her brother Steve Jobs, or in books and online quote collections.</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:separator {"style":{"color":{"background":"#e8e8e8"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-alpha-channel-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#e8e8e8;color:#e8e8e8"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center"><strong>Eulogy examples</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"background":"#fffdea","text":"#000000"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fffdea;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="structure"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>An example structure</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px">With the tips above, a ‘template’ for your loved one’s eulogy starts to come together. But if you’re not quite sure how to structure it, here’s a framework you can follow when you start writing:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Introduction</strong>:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li><strong>Give a brief background on the person who has died.</strong> Mention any nicknames they might have had; talk about their work or the things that were most important to them.</li><li><strong>Mention your relationship</strong> to them and what they meant to you and others. </li><li><strong>Talk about some of their best qualities</strong> and values they held dear. </li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Mid-section:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li><strong>You might want to include an anecdote here.</strong> Depending on the tone, you could make this funny, heart-warming, and/or even inspirational. </li><li><strong>Dive deeper into the things they cared about most</strong>: this could be family, friends, a pet or even a hobby. </li><li><strong>Cover their biggest accomplishments or life events.</strong> If they have a partner and/or kids, talk about them. You could even speak directly to them in parts.</li><li><strong>Capture what that person meant to others.</strong> This would be a good place to add personal stories or short quotes from their friends and family members.</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Closing:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li><strong>Start closing the eulogy with a final takeaway</strong>, whether it’s a saying your loved one often used or something that ties back to the eulogy’s overall theme. </li><li>At this point, you could speak directly to the loved one you have lost, and tell them ‘thank you’ and that you love them. </li><li><strong>You could also thank those at the funeral</strong> or memorial service for being there, and remind them how much your loved one admired them all. </li><li><strong>Think about ending with a quote, a poem, or a lyric from your loved one’s favourite song. You can keep it short and meaningful, a touching end to a funeral speech.</strong></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join Untangle's free grief community</a></strong> - </p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#cee6f2"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#cee6f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="parent"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","level":3,"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h3 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Eulogy example for a parent</strong></h3>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Talk about: </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li>What your mother or father <strong>meant to you</strong> and your siblings</li><li><strong>What they did</strong> both for your family and a living</li><li>How they raised you and the <strong>values</strong> they passed on</li><li><strong>Funny stories</strong> or <strong>touching memories</strong> that you’ll always remember</li><li>Something they once told you or <strong>a saying they had</strong></li><li><strong>The people who meant the most to them</strong></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Example eulogy:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>My dad was my hero. No matter how busy things got, he always made time for the people he cared about, and showed us that family always comes first – no matter what. Everyone who knew him knew how proud he was of the people he loved, of his dog, Buddy, and of his car… of course. You never had to ask what he was doing on a Sunday – he’d be outside washing the car </em><strong><em>again</em>. </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>I’m going to miss my dad so much, <strong>but I’m grateful for the wonderful memories I have of him.</strong> The happy trips to Cornwall when we were kids, the walks we used to go on, even just sitting on the sofa watching TV together. He made everything fun, and he knew just how precious our time on Earth is. <strong>He was always reminding me and my sisters to “enjoy life”, and that’s what he did, every day. </strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>I know a lot of you will be feeling as heartbroken as I am right now, and I also know that if there was anything my dad wanted me to say today, it’s this: thank you, to all of you. Everyone sitting here today meant so much to him; his work friends, his childhood friends, his whole family. He often talked about how lucky he was to have you all. I hope he knew how lucky we were to have him too. <strong>I love you Dad, thank you for being the best father we could have ever hoped for. </strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:spacer {"height":"21px"} -->

<!-- wp:group -->
<div class="wp-block-group"><!-- wp:columns {"align":"wide"} -->
<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#fbe0c3"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#fbe0c3;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="sibling"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Eulogy examples for a sibling</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Talk about: </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li>What your mother or father meant to you and your siblings</li><li>What they did both for your family and a living</li><li>How they raised you and the values they passed on</li><li>Funny stories or touching memories that you’ll always remember</li><li>Something they once told you or a saying they had</li><li>The people who meant the most to them</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Example eulogy:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em><strong>There will never be enough words to sum up my big sister. She was funny, kind, smart, determined… In the eyes of me and my parents, she lit up every room she walked into.</strong> [Name] threw herself at every opportunity – she never did anything by halves. When she was 21, she signed up for the marathon because she’d seen some running shoes she liked – and, of course, she smashed it. When she was 26, she went to the dog shelter ‘just to take a look’, and came home with two pups, Charlie and Bubbles, who adored her. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>So it was no surprise that she took so naturally to becoming a mum. I can’t describe the joy of seeing [Name] raise her two girls – my two favourite people – with the same care and kindness she had always shown me as her little sister. They were her pride and joy, and there is so much of [Name] in both of them. They share her generosity, fierce loyalty, flawless sense of style, and quick wit. [Kids’ names],<strong> I know nothing will ever erase the heartbreak of losing your mum, but I hope you know that we are all here for you always. </strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>[Name] was also a brilliant friend. She knew anyone and everyone. Sometimes it felt like there was nowhere we could go where she wouldn’t bump into at least one person who saw how brilliant she was. People were drawn to her, and her passion for life. But no matter how many friends she made, she’d never be without her best ones: Amy and Scott. She loved you both so much, and your wild stories will live on forever. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>[Name], thank you for everything. For being the life of the party, for always knowing how to make us all laugh, and for showing us how to live life to the fullest. <strong>There will never be a day we don’t miss you, but we’ll carry your love wherever we go, and your girls will never stop hearing stories about their magical mum.</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join Untangle's free grief community</a></strong> - </p>

<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#f9f5f2"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#f9f5f2;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="grandparent"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Eulogy examples for a grandparent</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Talk about: </strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li>Your grandmother or grandfather’s life and the people they loved</li><li>Their personality, their humour and their values</li><li>The role they played in your upbringing</li><li>Heartwarming memories of time spent with them</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Example eulogy:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em><strong>There was nobody funnier or more quick-witted than my grandmother. </strong>She was a force of nature who never failed to surprise people with her sharp one-liners and her teasing sense of humour. But she was also incredibly warm and kind. I’ll never forget our visits, Frank Sinatra playing in her living room, bowls of sweets on every surface, and her asking me, “so, what’s the latest gossip?”</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>She loved to chat, travel and see friends. Nan had a more active social life than anyone I know, and was always the ‘hostess with the mostest’, finding literally any reason to throw a party. <strong>Her love for her family was such a gift; something that my brother, parents, cousins, aunts, uncles and I were so lucky to experience every day. </strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>But Nan’s love for people didn’t just stay in her family. She was extremely charitable, hosting fundraisers, volunteering at charity shops, and offering help to anyone in need. When our grandad passed, she dedicated so much of her time TO raising money for the hospice that looked after him, as well as the RNLI in tribute to his time as a lifeguard. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>My nan and grandad’s love is something my brother, cousins and I all aspire to. Their adoration for one another was clear, and I can still hear them singing together in the kitchen. <strong>I like to think that now they’re finally back together again, having a song and a dance and big knees up.</strong> We love you Nan – thank you for everything.</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"center"} -->
<p class="has-text-align-center">- <strong><a href="https://onelink.to/zka2sa">Join Untangle's free grief community</a></strong> - </p>

<div class="wp-block-columns alignwide"><!-- wp:column {"verticalAlignment":"top","width":"","style":{"color":{"text":"#000000","background":"#e8f5ee"},"elements":{"link":{"color":{"text":"#000000"}}},"spacing":{"padding":{"top":"2em","right":"2em","bottom":"2em","left":"2em"}}}} -->
<div class="wp-block-column is-vertically-aligned-top has-text-color has-background has-link-color" style="background-color:#e8f5ee;color:#000000;padding-top:2em;padding-right:2em;padding-bottom:2em;padding-left:2em" id="friend"><!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center","style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"34px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center has-text-color" id="single" style="color:#003946;font-size:34px"><strong>Eulogy example for a friend</strong></h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:separator {"opacity":"css","style":{"color":{"background":"#000000"}},"className":"is-style-wide"} -->
<hr class="wp-block-separator has-text-color has-css-opacity has-background is-style-wide" style="background-color:#000000;color:#000000"/>
<!-- /wp:separator -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Talk about:&nbsp;</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list {"style":{"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"},"color":{"text":"#003946"}}} -->
<ul class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><li><span style="font-family: -apple-system, BlinkMacSystemFont, &quot;Segoe UI&quot;, Roboto, Oxygen-Sans, Ubuntu, Cantarell, &quot;Helvetica Neue&quot;, sans-serif;">How you met your friend and what your first impressions </span>were</li><li>What made them such a wonderful friend</li><li>Their passions and hobbies</li><li>Their other friends and family</li><li>Funny stories or memorable anecdotes</li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><strong>Example eulogy:</strong></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>I’ll never forget the first time I met [Name]. I’d just moved into our halls at uni and found him in the kitchen, wearing nothing but a towel, panicking because he’d flooded his shower on day one. I quickly realised that these kinds of mishaps followed him pretty much everywhere, from the time he turned up at the airport three weeks late for a flight, to when his dog really did eat his coursework. There was always a story with [Name].</em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em><strong>But beneath the constant jokes, mayhem and penchant for Hawaiian shirts, [Name] had the best heart. </strong>He was a true friend who backed all of us – even when we were definitely in the wrong! [Name] was the first person who called me when my dad passed away, the most dedicated best man at 3(!) of our friends’ weddings, and when he found [partner’s name], he became the most devoted boyfriend and fiancé. </em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:paragraph {"align":"left","style":{"color":{"text":"#003946"},"typography":{"fontSize":"17px"}}} -->
<p class="has-text-align-left has-text-color" style="color:#003946;font-size:17px"><em>Anyone who knew [Name] knew how much he adored [partner’s name], how strong his bond was with his brothers, and how he loved nothing more than a hungover Sunday roast at his parents’ house. <strong>We’ll all miss him terribly, but it’s impossible not to smile when we think of him. [Name], you were a true friend. We’ll keep on making mischief in your honour.</strong></em></p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph --></div>
<!-- /wp:column --></div>
<!-- /wp:columns -->

<!-- wp:heading {"textAlign":"center"} -->
<h2 class="has-text-align-center" id="examples">More eulogy examples</h2>
<!-- /wp:heading -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>The short eulogy examples above will have hopefully given you some inspiration on how you can structure your loved one’s funeral speech or the kinds of things you can talk about. We also wanted to share some well-known examples to give you extra ideas to work with. Here are a few that have stuck with us, and might help you too:</p>
<!-- /wp:paragraph -->

<!-- wp:list -->
<ul><li><a href="http://www.nytimes.com/2011/10/30/opinion/mona-simpsons-eulogy-for-steve-jobs.html" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Mona Simpson’s eulogy for her brother Steve Jobs</a></li><li><a href="https://www.instagram.com/p/CXHMhmookOd/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Stacey Heale’s eulogy for her late husband Greg</a></li><li><a href="https://www.funeralwise.com/celebration-of-life/eulogy/irwin-bindi/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Eight-year-old Bindi Irwin’s eulogy for her dad Steve Irwin</a></li><li><a href="https://www.standard.co.uk/news/uk/mother-s-eulogy-for-daughter-iris-goldsmith-15-at-funeral-love-like-she-loved-and-live-like-she-lived-a4193786.html" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">Kate Rothschild’s eulogy for her 15-year-old daughter Iris Goldsmith</a></li><li><a href="https://www.funeralwise.com/celebration-of-life/eulogy/chapman/" target="_blank" rel="noreferrer noopener">John Cleese’s eulogy written for George Chapman</a></li></ul>
<!-- /wp:list -->

<!-- wp:paragraph -->
<p>Looking for more advice on dealing with a loss? Read our guide on <a href="/what-to-say-someone-grieving/">what to say when someone dies</a>. If you’re planning a funeral, our round-up of the <a href="/funeral-songs/">most popular funeral songs</a> will also be useful to you.</p>

Closing Household Accounts
 
















































Utilities
 

British Gas
Who can do this?

●	Anyone, with the executor's details What is needed:
●	Death certiﬁcate (copy)
●	Details of the person who has passed away - their address, the date they died and their Customer Reference Number (if you can ﬁnd it).
●	An up-to-date meter reading for the property.
●	Details of whoever's responsible for getting all the affairs in order - their full name, address and phone number. This will probably be the executor if there's a will, or the administrator if there isn't.
 

British Gas (continued)
●	Step 1
○	To close the account or put it in another name, call their bereavement support team on 0800 294 3125
○	Or write to them at:
○	British Gas
○	PO Box 227
○	Rotherham
○	S98 1PD
●	Step 2
○	A copy of the death certiﬁcate will need to be sent by post after initially reporting the death
●	Step 3
○	If there’s someone still living in the property who had a joint account: You can change the name on the account.
○	If the property is going to be sold: You need to supply a meter reading from as close to when the customer passed away as possible. If you can't get this, we can use a current meter reading or estimate the reading based on previous readings from the property.
●	Step 4
○	The ﬁnal bill will be sent to the solicitors or whoever's dealing with the account. This bill is to give you the information you need to apply for a grant of probate. They'll put a hold on the account.
 

EDF Energy
Who can do this?

●	Anyone, with the executor's details

What is needed:

●	Your name and contact details, including your phone number and an address where EDF can write to you
●	The EDF Energy account holder’s details
●	Contact details for the solicitor who’s administering the estate (if you have one),
●	Up-to-date meter readings
●	(In some cases)
●	Death certiﬁcate
●	Coroner’s certiﬁcate
●	Grant of probate or letters of administration.
 

EDF Energy (continued)
●	Step 1:
○	Fill out this online form https://www.edfenergy.com/form/bereavement-notiﬁca tion-form?width=700&height=700&popup=1
○	OR Call 0808 101 4115
○	OR inform in writing at Freepost: EDF Energy - Plymouth
●	Step 2:
○	Account will move to the responsibility of the executor and the account can then be closed once the ﬁnal bill is paid
 

Npower
Who can do this?

●	Anyone, with the executor's details

What is needed:

●	Your relationship to the deceased
●	The date the person passed away
●	The customer's address and account details
●	A contact phone number for you
●	Details about who'll be responsible for the account moving forwards
 

Npower (continued)
●	Step 1:
○	Fill out online form https://www.npower.com/ui/forms/bereavement.html
○	OR call 0800 197 4033
●	Step 2:
○	Account will move to the responsibility of the executor and the account can then be closed once the ﬁnal bill is paid
 

Eon
Call 0333 202 4841 or email bereavementsupport@eonenergy.com

●	Details of the individual taking responsibility for the supplies moving forwards is required
●	If the property is being sold or is rented:
●	Details of the person responsible for managing the affairs are required until they’re able to close the account

○	Final bill will be sent to the person who is now responsible for the property

Amazon Prime
Who can do this?

●	Anyone with the executor's details What is needed:
●	The customer's name, address, email address and login details if known
●	Death certiﬁcate (copy)

Next Step:

Email bereavement-support@amazon.co.uk and attach the copy of the death certiﬁcate


*If you have an Amazon.co.uk account and would like any gift certiﬁcates to be transferred to your account, please provide the email address and last purchase associated with your Amazon.co.uk account. We may need to verify that you are entitled to the gift certiﬁcates, so if you are not mentioned in the death certiﬁcate please provide some proof of your relationship with your lost loved one.

●	Proof of death (e.g. an obituary or news article)
●	The date they passed away

If you decide to delete account you will also need:

●	Veriﬁcation that you're an immediate family member e.g. The deceased person's birth certiﬁcate, The deceased person's death certiﬁcate or Proof of authority under local law that you are the lawful representative of the deceased person, or his/her estate.

Helping you navigate life after loss 
Your personalised guide 

Hello [name], 
Welcome to your personalised guide, helping you navigate life after loss. 
We know how overwhelming it can be to work out what to do when someone dies. 
To make it easy, our team of experts have created this personalised guide for you. 
Use it like a checklist, to steer you through the practical steps you need to take. 
All the information in here is based on your personal needs. 
If you need any other speciﬁc information, you can always reach out to us by 
clicking here .
We are constantly improving the support we offer would love to hear your 
thoughts. We will be in touch via email in a week’s time to ask how you are 
ﬁnding the Task Manager. 

We want you to ask us questions! 
The tasks are laid out in order of what to do ﬁrst, 
but you can jump back and forward to a speciﬁc 
sections by clicking on the slides via the navigation 
on the left of the page. 
Navigating through the tasks 
Sometimes you will see a chat bubble on the right of 
the page. Here, you can ask us questions about the 
task you on. We aim to reply within 24 hours, and 
you’ll see our response underneath your question. You 
will also be notiﬁed via email.

Step 1:  understanding The Death Notiﬁcation Service 
Are there any ﬁnancial organisations 
the DNS doesn’t cover for you? 
The following of your organisations are not covered by the 
DNS: 
● [Provider] 
● [Provider] 
● [Provider] 
● [Provider] 
Don’t worry, we have curated simple contact instructions 
for each of these providers for you to notify them yourself. 
Head to page ---  for these. 
To start the process of notifying ﬁnancial organisations, we recommend using The Death Notiﬁcation Service (DNS).  
This will allow you to inform several banks & building societies of your loved one’s death at the same time. 
All you have to do is ﬁll out one form and it will notify  all the providers for you. 
Which of your ﬁnancials, can the 
DNS notify for you?

certiﬁcate.

Next task:  Claiming life insurance 

● The Will (if there is one) 
● Bank statements 
● Ask their solicitor (if there is one) 
This is a database of thousands of life 
insurance policies, unclaimed pensions, 
shares, dividends, dormant savings accounts 
and lottery winnings. 
It costs £25 to run a search for a life policy. 
To access this, follow this link : 
https://www.uar.co.uk/  
Step 1:  ways to ﬁnd out if there is a Life Insurance Policy 
First, try checking through the 
following: If not, try visiting the 
Unclaimed Asset Register 
The ﬁrst step of making a claim is to contact the insurer to let them know of your situation and that you are 
going to make a claim. 
What is needed 
If your policy number is in the format 123456-0001-5N or  
1234567-0001-A : 
Call : 0800 756 5869  
(lines open 8.30am - 6.30pm Monday to Friday) 
From abroad call: +44 1392 366 685. 
If your policy begins with a letter A, B, C, F, L, RN, T, U, V or X : 
Call: 0800 550 050 
(lines open 8.30am - 6.30pm Monday to Friday) 
From abroad call: +44 1392 366 685. 
To make a claim 
Where to start? 
●The policy number (this can be found 
on the policy documents, or a bank 
statement) 
●Medical reports from a doctor if you 
are claiming for a terminal illness 
●An original death certiﬁcate (they will 
return this immediately) 
If you cannot ﬁnd all this 
information, call them anyways with 
what you have.

Probate:  do I need it? 
What is probate? 
An Executor of a person’s will needs to obtain a Grant of Probate to be legally entitled to distribute their loved one’s assets 
in accordance to the will.  Grant of Probate should be applied by the executor for within the ﬁrst few months of your loved 
one’s death, as it may be necessary to obtain in order to access and close certain accounts that your loved one held. 
How do I know if I need to do it?  
You will likely need to apply for Grant of Probate if any  of the 
following apply to you: 
● If your loved one had any assets overseas - this includes 
property or ﬁnancial accounts 
● If your loved one had assets over £10,000  that were not 
jointly owned e.g stocks, shares, savings 
● If the value of the your loved one’s estate (everything they 
owned) is more than £10,000  - this includes property, money 
and possessions. Each bank has its own threshold to 
determine whether you need Probate to access your loved 
one’s account with them. The information about 
thresholds for each bank are on the next page. 
You don’t need to do it if: 
●The person had no assets outside 
the UK 
●All assets were jointly owned (eg. Mr 
& Mrs Jones’s bank account) 
●The value of the estate is less than  
£10,000  - but make sure you check 
with the ﬁnancial providers! 
 If this is you, you have come to 
the end of your tasks. Well done! 

Thresholds for each bank 
●Aviva -  £50,000 
●AXA - £10,000 
●Bank of Ireland - £10,000 
●Bank of Scotland - £50,000 
●Barclays -  £50,000 
●Birmingham Midshires -  £25,000 
●Britannia -  £30,000 
●Cheltenham & Gloucester -  £25,000 
●Clydesdale Bank - £30,000 
●Co-op Bank - £30,000 
●First Direct - To be decided on a case-by-case basis, and 
varies if the beneﬁciaries are children or a spouse/civil 
partner. Contact First Direct directly. 
●Halifax - £50,000 
●HSBC -  To be decided on a case-by-case basis, and varies if 
the beneﬁciaries are children or a spouse/civil partner. 
Contact HSBC directly. 
●Lloyds TSB -  £50,000 
●Metro Bank - £25,000 
●Monzo -  £5,000 
●M&S Bank -  £15,000 
●Nationwide -  £50,000 
●Natwest -  £25,000 
●NS&I -  £5,000 to £15,000 depending on the will and 
the number of executors 
●Post Ofﬁce - £10,000 
●Royal Bank of Scotland - £25,000 
●Sainsbury's Bank - £20,000 
●Santander -  £50,000 
●Skipton Building Society - £15,000 
●Starling -  £1,000 
●Tesco Bank -  £25,000 
●TSB -  £25,000 
●Virgin Money -  £35,000 
●Woolwich -  £15,000 
●Yorkshire Building Society - £30,000 
If the amount in your loved one’s account is more than the threshold, you will need a Grant of Probate to access it. 
Find out more about this process in Step 1. 

Probate:  doing it on your own vs using a solicitor 
On your own 
You could save a large amount of 
money. The application fee costs 
£215, and there is no charge for 
estates under £5000. 
The process can be relatively 
straightforward to complete if you 
have all the right information to 
hand, and you can apply online 
You have full control of any 
decisions that need to be made 
The forms contain a lot of legal jargon 
and can be complicated to understand 
Getting access to certain accounts can 
be easier when represented by a 
solicitor 
If you make a mistake you will be held 
accountable,  and this can  delay the 
probate process 
Using a solicitor 
Using a solicitor can ease some 
of the strain of dealing with the 
paperwork and save you time 
They are much better equipped to 
deal with complicated estates 
Grant of probate is a legal 
document, using a professional 
might give you peace of mind it’s 
done correctly 
Solicitors can be expensive, 
and fees can quickly mount 
up 
Sometimes it can be hard to 
ﬁnd a solicitor you trust, 
with a good reputation. 
Untangle can help you with 
this- head to slide - 

What is included in the estate? 
An estate is everything your loved one owned. This includes property, money in their ﬁnancial accounts and possessions. 
Once you have a rough estimation of your loved one’s ﬁnancial situation , continue to the next page. You ﬁrst need to value the money and ﬁnancial assets your loved one owned 
1. You might have already contacted all the ﬁnancial organisations your loved one held accounts with. 
Just as a reminder, organisations to contact often include: 
○ Their bank or building society - ask them to freeze any payments into or out of the account 
○ Their pension provider 
○ Any companies with which they held stocks or shares 
○ Their employer - they may be owed wages 
2. For each of the organisations you have contacted, ask for a statement of the value of their assets and any debts 
they held. If they had a mortgage, ask the mortgage lender if they require payments to continue whilst you are 
completing the Probate process. 
3. Make a list of all the information you receive from the ﬁnancial account providers. Make sure to include any 
lump sums from pensions or life insurance. 
Probate Step 1:  estimate the value of the estate (Part 1) 

Add everything up from Step 1 and 2, and you now have an estimate of the value of your loved one’s estate. Step 3 is 
working out if you need to pay Inheritance Tax, you can ﬁnd information about this is on the next page. You now need to value your loved one’s possessions 
1. Make a list of all the possessions they owned, and whether these were privately or jointly owned. Things to list 
could include: property, furniture, artwork, jewellery and cars. 
2. Next, estimate the value of each of these possessions on the day that your loved one died. This is a rough price 
that each item could be realistically sold for, not the price they paid. You can research this online, or get a 
professional valuation 
3. For jointly owned assets, divide the value by 2 if it was jointly owned with your loved one’s spouse or civil partner. 
For any assets owned by more than 2 people, divide the asset by the number of owners. 
4. To value a property: 
a. If you know the value is not close to the Inheritance Tax threshold of £325,000, you can value the property 
yourself by searching for it on Zoopla , or searching for the value of similar properties in the same area 
b. You can use a local estate agent, but if you think the property may be valued near to the Inheritance Tax 
threshold (£325,000), it is recommended that you use a chartered surveyor as they will have more 
experience valuing a property for Inheritance Tax purposes 
Probate Step 2:  estimate the value of the estate (Part 2) 

What is it? 
Inheritance Tax (IHT) is a tax you have to pay on the estate of someone who has died. It includes all their property, 
possessions and money. It needs to be paid by the Executor. Normally, IHT needs to be paid or partially paid before 
probate can be issued. However, there are some exceptions to this. 
If you need to pay Inheritance Tax, follow the step 4. If you do not then head straight to step 5. How do I know if I need to pay it? 
Probate Step 3:  do I need to pay Inheritance Tax? 
The amount of inheritance tax you need to pay will depend on a lot of factors that are unique to your situation, however 
there is normally no tax to be paid  if:
● The value of your estate is below of £325,000 - this is known as the Nil Rate Band (NRB) 
● You leave everything above the threshold to your spouse or civil partner, or 
● You leave everything above the threshold to an exempt beneﬁciary such as a charity 
If this is correct for you loved one’s estate - you still need to report this to HMRC. You can do this here: Valuing the estate of  
someone who's died: Report the estate's value to HMRC . Then, you can skip to Probate Step 5. 
If the estate is valued at over £325,000, there is usually tax to pay  on anything over this threshold at a rate of 40%. 
However, there are many exceptions to this. For more information, follow this link to the government website: Inheritance  
Tax - GOV.UK 
● Sometimes banks or building societies will release 
money out of your loved ones account before probate 
has been issued, if it is being used to pay IHT directly 
to HMRC. 
● if you are paying IHT on property, HMRC may accept 
staged payments so you can pay back IHT over a 
longer time frame. 
● If you pay for IHT out of your money, you can get a 
refund from the estate when probate is granted.

Where do I get the money to pay 
Inheritance Tax? 
● Inheritance Tax (IHT) must be paid by the end of the 
sixth month after the person’s death. 
● HMRC will start charging interest on any unpaid tax 
after the 6-month period, so you should begin even if 
you haven’t valued the estate fully. 
● If you pay too much or little, it will be corrected after 
you receive probate (this is called payment on 
account). When do I need to pay it? How to pay Inheritance Tax: 
Probate Step 4:  paying your Inheritance Tax 

What do I need? 
Before you begin the Probate form you will 
need to gather the following: 
● The original will 
● The original death certiﬁcate or an 
interim death certiﬁcate from the 
coroner 
● A completed estimation and report of 
the value of the estate from HMRC, as 
completed in Step 1 and 2. 
● A notice from HMRC saying that you’ve 
either paid inheritance tax or have no 
tax to pay, as completed in Step 3 or 4 . 
○ This can be corrected if 
necessary after the Probate 
application is completed 
Ready to apply? The application fee is £215 if the value of the estate is £5,000 or over. 
There’s no application fee if the estate is under £5,000. 
Extra copies of the Grant of Probate cost £1.50 each. It is worth getting a 
few copies - we would recommend one for each account you still have to 
close, so you are able to send them to different organisations at the 
same time. This should help you to complete the process faster. 
Once you have gathered all the documents from the list on the left, 
you need to complete the PA1P form. You can check whether you are 
eligible to apply for a Grant of Probate online here: Apply for probate  
online 
If you are not eligible, you will need to submit the forms via post. You 
can ﬁnd the PA1P form here: Form PA1P: Apply for probate by post if  
there is a will 
Things to note: 
Probate Step 5:  it’s time to apply for Grant of Probate 

● Probate usually takes around 4 weeks to be granted, but may take longer at the moment due to coronavirus. 
● You may have already contacted ﬁnancial organisations to inform them of your loved one’s death, and the 
accounts should be frozen to stop payments going in or out of the account. You can now contact your loved 
one’s ﬁnancial account providers to inform them that you now have a Grant of Probate to act on their behalf. 
● Once you are able to access their accounts, this means you can now make a correct assessment of the value 
of their estate. If you have over or underpaid Inheritance Tax with HMRC, you can now correct this. If you are 
doing this without a solicitor, you can ﬁnd information on how to do that here: Pay your Inheritance Tax bill:  
Pay early to avoid paying interest 
● Depending on the ﬁnancial situation your loved one was in, you can now pay off any debts from the estate. 
The next task is to distribute their assets according to their will. You can ﬁnd more information and advice 
around how to do that here: Dealing with the estate of someone who's died 
Probate Step 6:  what happens next? 
Probate:  tips for using a solicitor 
Time is Money 
Some solicitors charge hourly rates, whilst others will 
charge a percentage of the total value of the estate. 
Most solicitors will give you a cost estimate at the 
start, based on how complex the estate is. 
Often the fees won’t include court or any application 
costs, so expect the ﬁnal bill to be higher than the 
estimated ﬁgure given at the start of the process. 
Time is money, so make sure your solicitor doesn’t 
waste time chasing you, and try to communicate via 
email as phone calls can last longer. 
Try to gather the 
documents yourself 
Having everything that your solicitor may need to 
hand will make delays much less likely. Most 
solicitors will ask for - documents. Make sure you trust them 
Sometimes it can be easier to use the solicitor 
who drew up the will, but if you have a preference 
for another provider, go with your gut instinct. 
Communication between you and your solicitor 
is important, so look at reviews online or ask for 
recommendations from friends and family. 
Don’t be afraid to ask 
questions 
The solicitor should check with you to make sure 
you’ve understood what they’ve said. Ask them to 
explain anything you don’t understand. Take notes 
of what is said or, if you are able, bring a friend or 
family member along to take notes for you. At the 
end of your appointment, make sure you know 
what the next steps are.

Letter of Administration:  do I need it? 
What is it? 
If your loved one died without making a will, you will need to apply for a Letter of Administration to be able to deal with 
their estate and distribute any assets. There are rules about who can do this, it is usually the deceased’s next-of-kin, such 
as a married partner or a child. You should apply for a Letter of Administration within the ﬁrst few months of your loved 
one’s death if you need to access or handle their accounts. 
How do I know if I need to do it?  
You will need to apply for a Letter of Administration if any of the following 
apply to you: 
● If your loved one had any assets overseas - this includes property 
or ﬁnancial accounts 
● If your loved one had assets over £10,000  that were not jointly 
owned e.g stocks, shares, savings 
● If the value of the your loved one’s estate (everything they owned) 
is more than £10,000 - this includes property, money and 
possessions. Each bank has its own threshold to determine 
whether you need Probate to access your loved one’s account with 
them. 
The information about thresholds for each bank are on the next page. 
You don’t need to do it if: 
●The person had no assets outside 
the UK 
●All assets were jointly owned (eg. Mr 
& Mrs Jones’s bank account) 
●The value of the estate is less than  
£10,000  - make sure you check with 
the ﬁnancial providers! 
 If this is you, you have come to 
the end of your tasks. Well done! 

Thresholds for each bank 
●Aviva -  £50,000 
●AXA - £10,000 
●Bank of Ireland - £10,000 
●Bank of Scotland - £50,000 
●Barclays -  £50,000 
●Birmingham Midshires -  £25,000 
●Britannia -  £30,000 
●Cheltenham & Gloucester -  £25,000 
●Clydesdale Bank - £30,000 
●Co-op Bank - £30,000 
●First Direct - To be decided on a case-by-case basis, and 
varies if the beneﬁciaries are children or a spouse/civil 
partner. Contact First Direct directly. 
●Halifax - £50,000 
●HSBC -  To be decided on a case-by-case basis, and varies if 
the beneﬁciaries are children or a spouse/civil partner. 
Contact HSBC directly. 
●Lloyds TSB -  £50,000 
●Metro Bank - £25,000 
●Monzo -  £5,000 
●M&S Bank -  £15,000 
●Nationwide -  £50,000 
●Natwest -  £25,000 
●NS&I -  £5,000 to £15,000 depending on the will and 
the number of executors 
●Post Ofﬁce - £10,000 
●Royal Bank of Scotland - £25,000 
●Sainsbury's Bank - £20,000 
●Santander -  £50,000 
●Skipton Building Society - £15,000 
●Starling -  £1,000 
●Tesco Bank -  £25,000 
●TSB -  £25,000 
●Virgin Money -  £35,000 
●Woolwich -  £15,000 
●Yorkshire Building Society - £30,000 
If the amount in your loved one’s account is more than the threshold, you will need a Grant of Probate to access it. 
Find out more about this process in Step 1. 

LoA:  doing it on your own vs using a solicitor 
On your own 
You could save a large amount of 
money. The application fee costs 
£215, and there is no charge for 
estates under £5000. 
The process can be relatively 
straightforward to complete if you 
have all the right information to 
hand, and you can apply online 
You have full control of any 
decisions that need to be made 
The forms contain a lot of legal jargon 
and can be complicated to understand 
Getting access to certain accounts can 
be easier when represented by a 
solicitor 
If you make a mistake you will be held 
accountable,  and this can  delay the 
probate process 
Using a solicitor 
Using a solicitor can ease some 
of the strain of dealing with the 
paperwork and save you time 
They are much better equipped to 
deal with complicated estates 
Grant of probate is a legal 
document, using a professional 
might give you peace of mind it’s 
done correctly 
Solicitors can be expensive, 
and fees can quickly mount 
up 
Sometimes it can be hard to 
ﬁnd a solicitor you trust, 
with a good reputation. 
Untangle can help you with 
this- head to slide - 

What is included in the estate? 
An estate is everything your loved one owned. This includes property, money in their ﬁnancial accounts and possessions. 
Once you have a rough estimation of your loved one’s ﬁnancial situation , continue to the next page. You ﬁrst need to value the money and ﬁnancial assets your loved one owned 
1. You might have already contacted all the ﬁnancial organisations your loved one held accounts with. 
Just as a reminder, organisations to contact often include: 
○ Their bank or building society - ask them to freeze any payments into or out of the account 
○ Their pension provider 
○ Any companies with which they held stocks or shares 
○ Their employer - they may be owed wages 
2. For each of the organisations you have contacted, ask for a statement of the value of their assets and any debts 
they held. If they had a mortgage, ask the mortgage lender if they require payments to continue whilst you are 
completing the Probate process. 
3. Make a list of all the information you receive from the ﬁnancial account providers. Make sure to include any 
lump sums from pensions or life insurance. 
LoA Step 1:  estimate the value of the estate (Part 1) 

Add everything up from Step 1 and 2, and you now have an estimate of the value of your loved one’s estate. Step 3 is 
working out if you need to pay Inheritance Tax, you can ﬁnd information about this is on the next page. You now need to value your loved one’s possessions 
1. Make a list of all the possessions they owned, and whether these were privately or jointly owned. Things to list 
could include: property, furniture, artwork, jewellery and cars. 
2. Next, estimate the value of each of these possessions on the day that your loved one died. This is a rough price 
that each item could be realistically sold for, not the price they paid. You can research this online, or get a 
professional valuation 
3. For jointly owned assets, divide the value by 2 if it was jointly owned with your loved one’s spouse or civil partner. 
For any assets owned by more than 2 people, divide the asset by the number of owners. 
4. To value a property: 
a. If you know the value is not close to the Inheritance Tax threshold of £325,000, you can value the property 
yourself by searching for it on Zoopla , or searching for the value of similar properties in the same area 
b. You can use a local estate agent, but if you think the property may be valued near to the Inheritance Tax 
threshold (£325,000), it is recommended that you use a chartered surveyor as they will have more 
experience valuing a property for Inheritance Tax purposes 
LoA Step 2:  estimate the value of the estate (Part 2) 

What is it? 
Inheritance Tax (IHT) is a tax you have to pay on the estate of someone who has died. It includes all their property, 
possessions and money. It needs to be paid by the Executor. Normally, IHT needs to be paid or partially paid before 
probate can be issued. However, there are some exceptions to this. 
If you need to pay Inheritance Tax, follow the step 4. If you do not then head straight to step 5. The amount of inheritance tax you need to pay will depend on a lot of factors that are unique to your situation, however 
there is normally no tax to be paid  if:
● The value of your estate is below of £325,000 - this is known as the Nil Rate Band (NRB) 
● You leave everything above the threshold to your spouse or civil partner, or 
● You leave everything above the threshold to an exempt beneﬁciary such as a charity 
If this is correct for you loved one’s estate - you still need to report this to HMRC. You can do this here: Valuing the estate of  
someone who's died: Report the estate's value to HMRC . Then, you can skip to Probate Step 5. 
If the estate is valued at over £325,000, there is usually tax to pay  on anything over this threshold at a rate of 40%. 
However, there are many exceptions to this. For more information, follow this link to the government website: Inheritance  
Tax - GOV.UK How do I know if I need to pay it?
